content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								While perhaps more of a "design and program" game over an engineering simulation, Space Engineers is a very approachable, fun space sim that gives you far more creativity over other space sims. The game offers two modes - Survival and Creative - both allow you to build your own space ships and space stations, one of which actually requiring you to mine, refine, and assemble materials into parts before welding them into your ship. The game is a little slow and meaningless if you play it by yourself but if you can find some friends to share a base with, and create factions to fight each other, the game is very entertaining due to the number of possibilities. The limited number of game functions at the moment is offset by the Workshop, which seamlessly (YES, NO ISSUES!) integrates hundreds of new blocks and backgrounds into the game without a hickup, only requiring a slightly longer load time. If you can manage to find people you like (or hate) to play the game with you, you will have a blast. However, single player doesn't offer too many fun possibilities, as building a ship doesn't really accomplish anything without having something to use it for - you will be alone in space in the most literal sense. While it lacks some more advanced mechanics calculations and possibilities for real engineers, it does offer those with a knack for programming and configuring controls the opportunity to customize features and design complex mechanisms to accomplish various tasks ranging from opening a door to operating a complex automated train line. It is a load of fun when you design things you can show off to other players (and attack them with), but be prepared to not be very useful at the beginning - some things aren't too intuitive, and PvP can be brutal.

number of helpful: 26 of 35 people (74%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								After Reviewing many many reviews, most of which were negative, I asked myself why this game was so hated. I have stuck with the game since a few days after its initial release and, while it does have a few shortcomings, I am extremely impressed with this game and plan on continuing to play it, and while it does have some shortcomings, the game itself is an extremely good game for an early access game. I look forward to seeing what the official release will bring.Before jumping into a constructive breakdown of what I have experienced in this game I wish to note the main source of negative reviews on this game. People are voting negative because of the games networking issues and general bugs, however what many people who posts those reviews fail to realize is that THIS GAME IS NOT COMPLETE! Please avoid making reviews directly based upon bugs until the game has been officially released!Positives and Reasons To Buy This GameSandbox: Obviously this games number one purpose, those who play Minecraft, Starmade, Kerbal Space Program, No Man's Sky, or even Garry's Mod should at least find some measure of satisfaction with this game, if not immense satisfaction. You are able to mine ore/terrain in a completely destructible voxel environment, or simply throw down a few warheads to blow up a massive hole to live in, while at the same time being able to make ships or even automated machines to do the mining for you. You are able to build ships and stations from scratch, and automate their construction and semi-automate their repair even when some sections are missing. (thank you projectors!) With that same block you are able to create saved ships from a projection as well. When this game was in its earlier renditions, I even went so far as to develop a miner that could eat a smaller asteroid in nearly two passes. Back then I was sad because I couldn't share the project with anyone or easily remake it, but now you are able to save it locally or upload it to the workshop! (wish I wouldn't have deleted that save!)Development: Every Thursday, whether or not I am looking to play the game, I always check the update notes, because every Thursday Keen does a software update on the game. This is the only game I have ever done this with, and generally I ignore update notes unless its a multi GB update. Why, you may ask, do I pay attention to the more numerous and minor updates instead of paying attention to other games with fewer, more comprehensive updates? The answer is simple. This game has gone above and beyond my expectations when I first bought it, added many more features than I expected, and even added some features the devs said they probably wouldn't add *cough* planets *cough*.  Never before have I been so tied to a games development. Not only that, but with each update comes assurance that the devs are always working on the game and always moving it forward, however so slowly it may be going at times. Beyond that, the game itself has come a long ways from its initial relase. In the above section, the miner that you see in the picture used to make it so pretty much no one could move effectively because the simulation speed was brought down to 0.3 out of 1 every time it turns on. Now, however, after remaking a similar miner on a much more crowded server, the simulation speed was staying stable at around 0.8.Workshop Integration: This is the biggest, and best reason to get this game. As of the time this was typed up, space engineers has 193,072 items on the workshop ranging from small ship blueprints, to mods that add drills the size of your entire starter ship! The community is constantly adding many cool and new mods and creations that it is doubtful you will tire of it soon. From the well known Azimuth mod, to the more specialized SANCHINCORP hoverbike mod, or even to creating your own mod so you can have what you want in the game!Combat: "Now whats the point of having this big destroyer if you dont have a target for it?" you might ask. Well there are plenty of places to prove your mettle in combat if building massive stations or designing mining ships just isn't your thing. EVE online players, be careful as you may get sucked into this one. Not only are you able to engage and defend agains hostile NPCs, but factions get taken into effect and you may very well find that you and your faction/friends are being assaulted by another faction or group. Or, maybe you were on a mining trip and stumbled upon a well tucked away base. You mark your location and come back with the big guns to neutralise the defenses, then loot their containers while they are away or even salvage the entire station/ship. All in all, these are the primary things that I believe contribute and make up this game. Believe me when I say that there are many other things that are awesome to this game that I haven't included.Negatives and Reasons To Avoid The Game For NowNetworking and Stability: One of the games biggest faults is its networking and communication between peers. I cannot tell you how many times I have spent hours upon hours or even days making ships, mining for resources, and welding them, only to have them completely destroyed by an errant small ship de-syncing and tearing through it like an ICBM. This issue, while not nearly as abhorrent as it was before, is still present and continues to be a source of fear and greif with this game. I have ragequit more than once because of something getting destroyed due to de-syncing.Exiting Planet Gravity: While seemingly a small thing, the simple act of exiting a planets gravity is near impossible to do if you started on the planet in the first place. Planets are abundant in pretty much every ore, however they do not have platinum, which you need for making the non atmospheric thrusters. Hydrogen thrusters, while fast and capable, run out of fuel so fast its not even funny. It took me over 43 different ship designs, from the ground up, before I finally gave in and snagged a ship from the workshop, which still didnt get me to where I needed to be because I ran out of fuel shortly after exiting the atmosphere.Time Consumption: This game can and will EAT your time up as my friend TwoPheat is a great example of. Your game will go and go and you will continue to perform tasks slowly reaching your goal, then you glance at the clock and realize that you probably should have been asleep 3 hours ago. While some people might see it as a great sign, I find it quite irritating coming into work an hour late because I got used to performing the same menial task over and over and over, that I lost my sense of time. Needless to say, after that happened a few times I, setup an alarm to let me know when to sleep and that fixed it.Performance: While not nearly as intensive as it used to be, Space Engineers is still a very demanding game. Expect it to eat up your system performance, especially when dealing with ship to ship combat engagements.ConclusionSpace Engineers, despite still being in Early Access and not being a complete game, can give you immense satisfaction and enjoyment despite still being plagued by a few unavoidable bugs. There are many things that you can do, and an almost exponentially higher number of things you can make so long as you are willing to invest the time to make it.I would highly recommend getting this game if you are looking for a good sandbox game.Note: Your ships may end up looking Phallic in nature, don't worry thats normal, just dont make them pink.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								I desperately wanted to enjoy this game. I did everything I could to make the game as playable as possible. But in the end, this game is an unfixable wreck that Keen has left us with. Few new features are getting added, and we're left with a broken mess that is Space Engineers. For starters, this game is incredibly unfriendly to people who don't have a top of the line computer. Besides for how high the requirements to smoothly play this game are (I probably should have payed more attention to that before buying), the game also only goes as low as "normal" for graphics IIRC, and has very few graphics options. In addition, they stopped supporting the dx9 version which turns this from a game my computer can barely run to a game that makes me feel like I'm watching a slideshow.The overall idea though is great, and I loved the idea of building fleets of drones to do stuff for you, a little bit of which I actually did before they dropped dx9 support, and even though I still have the dx9 version, I got tired of 15 FPS constantly so just stopped playing.If Keen ever takes measures to reduce lag, then I might consider trying this again, but until then, I'm just going to have to thoroughly regret buying this game. If you do have a good enough computer, then I'd somewhat recommend this, but this game still has a whole array of other problems mentioned in other reviews.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								It's like Lego in space!You can create spaceships and land vehicles and explore, fight and colonize.But it's so much more if you want it to be - there is also power management, weight distribution and proceduraly generated asteroids and whole planets and moons! Yes, Space Engineers did it first, and although they do rush some of the features in order to be first, I really believe they are pushing the game industry forward with their ambition.If you want a big challenge - there is a punishing Survival mode - where you have to mine, produce and assemble all your creations. Imagine having to actually create all the blocks before assembling them. This makes you design efficient, realistic vehicles and spaceships.Some of the players complain that the game is what it openly states it is - an Early Access game. Some features simply don't work  yet. My solution to this is to play with the features that work perfectly and I couldn't be happier. The team gives weekly updates to the game, and there is a very strong modding and blueprints community that pushes the format of this game to the limit.It's been a fun ride so far and I believe there is a lot in store for this game in the future. It's ambitious, it's serene and I keep returning to it - playing it for years now. Definetly worth your money!

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game isn't perfect, and it doesn't have kerbal space program physics, but it is still really fun, especially on multiplayer. The developers are awesome. They care what the community wants, and they are keeping it a really good game. Originally, the developers were not going to add planets, but so many people requested it, and guess what? They added them!The community is awesome as well, however, like any community there is the bad part of it. Try creating a public creative server, it won't work too well, it'll just have spammers. At least until mod api supports more. Aside from the creative servers, you can find a community you love being around, just takes time to find one.Missing content to the game? Look to the modding community, there is tons and tons of content created for the game. Pros:- Infinite worlds, just explore or create a huge empire.- PLANETS!!! They are beautiful in every way, they're just gigantic, I mean like... MASSIVE. Oh, and... The best part, The ENTIRE planet can be destroyed, sure that takes up a lot of resources, but its possible. You could make a hole from 1 side to another.- Building mechanics are awesome, many decoration mods to make ships feel like they're actually a space ship.- Enjoyable if you play with your friends, teamwork can make things a lot faster.- The game sort of has a goal now, starting on a planet, and moving up into space, and jump drives being end game. The alien planet is far away, and is dangerous and very exciting to be on, and be eaten alive!- Planets do not support DX9, why is this a Pro? Because DX9 is like extremely old and outdated. Cons:- The game is getting better at optimization, still laggy, but getting better. Consider the scale of the game, and what it has now.- Some patches released can break the game a bit, but generally they're getting better, after all, it still is Alpha.- The game pushes limits, so don't expect it to run on your 2005 dell computer, it's not going to. The game requires nice hardware, but at the same time, the game is pushing the limits by adding  content that has never been done before.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is like a relationship you love and hate at the same time. You know, a person who looks great and you can have a lot of fun with, but ruins every moment with annoying nagging and sudden emotional explosions. This person knows how stressful this is for you and promises to change this attitude, but simply won't do that. To hide that, this person makes you presents in order to make you forget those flaws. But you don't want those presents... You want this relationship to work!That's pretty much this game.Heck darn, it's fun to play.. or it WOULD be fun to play! Establishing a base, building ships and do things with other players? Sounds awesome! But all thouse freakouts in multiplayer makes it almost unenjoyable. Recently I found a server and played hours on it because the performance was bearable... Yeah, you can call hourly server crashes, violent twitching of objects and other bunches of bugs 'bearable'. Singleplayer or private MP runs almost flawless, but that's not the space adventure you want to have. You want to communicate with other people! Trade with them, explore with them, fight with them!Trust me, I'd LOVE to give this a positive review, but I can't. Not with all those problems. The developers made me have hope for this game, but that hope vanishes with every session i play. As long as it stays like this, my thumb stays down.

number of helpful: 17 of 20 people (85%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Space Engineers is one of the greatest space games I've played, and considering how far its come since I bought it, I can't even begin to describe the leaps and bounds this game has achieved to someone who hasn't played this game prior to.Needless to say, the latest addition is by far one of the greatest crowning achievements, while the game was quite fun prior, it did lack some sense of adventure and diversity considering everything was just empty space with YAY another damn asteroid. Now the game is strikingly beautiful on top of being and intense build it game. Going over specifics of this game is hard, theres far too much complexity to the base game to sum up its gameplay into a less than novelistic review, that doesn't consider the vast mod base this game has either, which is equally pumping out awesome new things daily.If I had to pick one bad  thing to say about SE, it would have to be the "static" celestial environment, granted planets are only barely coming into the game, but even with unlimited universe, high density, planets, meteor showers, random AI, theres still a missing feeling given everything is in its relative positions static, which for me takes away from a space gaming experience. Additionally, the multiplayer could still use a lot of stability work, dedicated servers are still a myth in my book, with regular crashes, and continual "update screwed the server files" from server operrators, I find it hard to play this game multiplayer(less I'm hosting) and annoyingly lonely considering I always seem to be kicking everyone shortly before they crash a giant ship into my space station...LOLWith that said, I've got to give this game a 9/10. leaving room for the obvious improvement the devs will be making in future updates.When you're done stealing your mothers credit card, hook yourself up with a copy of SE STAT!

content:
Posted: January 1
Early Access Review
								I've seen some reviews calling this minecraft in space - this couldn't be further from the truth.There is a learning curve but playing around with a few of the pre-made ships for a bit will teach you most of what you need to know. You bring your creativity to the table and take it from there. This game has provided me with one of, if not the most, memorable moments in PC gaming:After a bit of resource gathering and getting myself acquainted with my crappy little wreck of a ship I start to feel confident and go off futher and further. While drilling for uranium on an asteroid I foud myself being watched by a ship. The ship got closer and closer and then to my dismay I found that it had weapons. The ship fired on me. I had not thought to put weapons on my peaceful learning ship so I had no way to defend myself - or did I? I jumped from my ship with my jetpack and managed to avoid getting shot. I locked my magnetic boots to his hull and started grinding a hole in his armor. Once inside I saw his vital components. The ship flung itself wildly as I cut away at reactors, gyroscopes, and the like. Soon he was dead floating in space. I felt like I had killed Moby♥♥♥♥♥♥ ...five minutes later his friends showed up and I had a bad day.Would space-whale hunt again 10/10

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's a great game if you like building stuff (at certain times, differs greatly per alpha version). Sadly, it's overall EXTREMELY buggy, unbalanced and it does not perform in multiplayer, not even with a state-of-the-art-super-server (180-500$/month) and it seems that this game will never finish.In Singleplayer there isn't really anything to do besides building stuff, but everything you build bugs/corrupts. It's really terrible. Some bugs are as old as the first public release... That alone should say something about this company.They have fantastic ideas. But their ideas are too big to materialise and they have this habbit of adding more 'ideas' before even prototyping/finishing the previous ones.Restrictions & LimitationsOriginally posted by Silver:In sandbox games you want to build, be creative and be free.But the freedom is limited by the server performance which is killed really easy w/o rules that limit your freedom.Yes servers MUST apply serious restrictions to all players (like deleting all ships with more than x blocks). And yet you can still crash any server you want without hacking/cheating. But you can't even make a medium-sized-battleship without crashing or at the very least lagging out even the most expensive and modern servers.Another example: there is a hidden block limit for each ship, exceeding it will cause a crash. Official reply from Keen stated (literal copy-paste): "We will try to take a look at it. But it will not probably be fixed.".Singleplayer is a lot more stable and performs better but it's still pretty bad.PlanetsThe new planets release only made things worse. EVERYTHING I touch bugs.  You literally die from jumping on a flat surface or touching a players corpse.One hour of playing, over 10 serious (as in corruption, server crashes, ships blowing up, etc) bugs and at least 2 exploits. 2 years in alpha + years of development + 8 figures in budget and still a big mess. They still release patches and updates that are totally flawed instead of waiting until they get it right. After playing some more hours the amount of bugs becomes extremely annoying.Server Performance, no matter what you do...At capped FPS, at max server simspeed, with the server using less than (literally) 1/10th of it's resources the game still becomes a slideshow with more players. The whole optimization is totally absent after years and years of development.Servers are unable to perform no matter the hardware you put in it. And in singleplayer you can make it perform to a certain degree using mods. But those break roughly every week and I noticed that my machine is still rendering lights and blocks that it can't possible see. Even after the planets update...But there is so much more...There are so many more problems (like the weekly updates that introduce more bugs than fixes and that break the mods you need to get around existing bugs...) and pages filled with bug-listings. But it's too much to all sum up in a review.Project management & communicationI seriously frown upon how they manage their project in Keen. It's all done extremely unprofessionally, even for an Indie team. Also the questions asked during streams seem pre-made, too politically correct and the important questions are ignored (and most likely not fixed/implemented).Example: We suffer for so long from a rapidly increasing world filesize on servers. They can grow very fast and makes connecting to the server insanely slow (which can grow in just 1 day to the point where it gets nuts) with no build-in way to decrease it.However, at 15 january 2016 Marek in the live-stream about the "roadmap Q&A" hears about this for the very first time... Now I know why they never solved that issue before and why he plans on creating persistent servers without fixing this first (among others)... Their management appeared to be unaware of such very important issues even though it has been reported many times over the last 2 years... But yet they are the ones creating the 'todo-list' and the priorities for 2016...The people who see nothing and blame 'my pc' for itIt works for me! I have (almost) no bugs! Game is fine, must be those other people!Our server runs just fine. I don't see the 'big' problem.Maybe try having more than 2 people on the server, use more complex blocks and more complex designs. And pray that people who are like that, never join your server. Or people who know the bugs&exploits and who can crash your server anytime they feel like it through legal means. Don't use programmable blocks, don't use rotors, don't drill, etc. Sure at some point you can make it work... Just limit yourself enough in a sandbox game and tell everyone that this game works just fine. And if not, tell everyone it's an alpha game that excuses all the design&management failures that this game company made.Just look at the memory leaks alone... It's enormous. But hey, if you don't see any bugs, if you don't see the epic failures from their management and if you are not worried that this game is unlikely to ever reach the finish line, then this game is for you!It's your PC!... I have no words for this level of 'stupidity'... Maybe my RAM has a hole in it... Me and other admins literally see the memory leaks on the servers. But it must be my client PC that somehow leaks memory because my CPU is bad right? And what about all the bugs? Also caused by my 'bad CPU'?And when I look at the server I sometimes see that the CPU runs at like 1-40% capacity and 30GB free RAM left and a good ping and free disk space and etc. But still we got a slideshow caused server-side? Maybe... just maybe.... it's the game? Just at least consider it?But it's alpha.. How can you downvote anything in alpha?(quote is not mine)You post a review on the state of the game. Not the state you think the game will be in. I think it's fair people are made aware of the limitations of the current game. Especially those wanting to play MP.

number of helpful: 39 of 61 people (64%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								Space Engineers is a very promising, inspiring and creative game. If you like playing alone in an empty universe, then you must definitely try this game. You won't regret it. It is one of the best single-player sandbox games I have ever played.Everything is great until you try the multiplayer.Extremely unstable, insanely laggy, frustratingly buggy.No, it's not my internet connection (I have a very fast connection) and no, it's not my pc (I have a very high end pc).It's just that the game is severely unoptimized. Whenever I join an online server, the game switches to s**t mode.There are so many things not working in multiplayer that I can't possibly list them here, some of which are:- Lag gets so extreme that you must wait for 30 seconds for even the most simple action- Game freezes for 10 - 20 seconds for no apparent reason- Player jumping all over the place, without any chance of controlling it- Lag stuttering gets so intense that can give you a seizure- On planets, player suddenly starts sinking into the ground, free falling to the center of the planet and ultimately dying- Sudden death for completely inexplicable reasons- Parked vehicles explode for no reason- Stationed ships explode for no reason- Drills and rotors explode for no reason- Merge blocks explode for no reason- Parked vehicles jumping all over the place for no reason- Stationed ships jumping all over the place for no reasonYou get the idea.Overall, great for single-player, unplayable in multiplayer.Yes, it is in early access but there are serious bugs that remain unsolved for 2 years and I don't think they will be ever solved. Looks like this game suffers from the eternal-early-access syndrome, which is very common these days.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								Keeping this short. Space Engineers has a lot of promise. First however, it needs a lot of fixing. Server side I am aware of a nominally fixed memory leak caused by voxel updates (we think, hard to be sure). Not ACTUALLY fixed, despite patch notes: our server admin has tested this thoroughly.Client side... I don't know where to begin. Sometimes my oxygen won't replenish, or my energy, when sitting in a pod with both supplied. Sometimes objects literally destroy themselves while I build them. Just now I lost almost two hours of solid work because things I build don't always default to BELONGING TO ME.My advice is pretty simple. Wait until the devs iron out most of these things before giving them money for the project. Currently it is frustratingly prone to glitchy behavior, and while the game is playable you will see tons of things go wrong.Tl;dr, Dark Souls 3 is more rewarding and less frustrating than this. Infer what you will from that.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								For quite some time, I had to say the Space Engineers was one of the more fun sandbox games that you could get in a self-hosted multiplayer fashion, but over time the developers have really dropped the ball. The game's weekly updates have been steady, and new features added constantly, but stability has been an absolute nightmare due to the apparent focus on feature creep and lack of developer testing.  Releases are almost always followed by immediate patches for widespread gamebreaking issues, mods are broken often, and there is no apparent interest from the developers in moving to a slower and more stable approach. The game may be in Early Access, but developers should never use this as a reason to provide absolutely zero quality testing.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm more addicted to this game than Minecraft lately. When my friends are off doing their thing in games I don't have, I'm usually in this. I'm only just scratching the surface of potential, too. Creative if insanely fun, and Survival is harshly challenging. If you want more challenge in either mode, the recent addition of Meteor storms has seriously kicked things up a notch. If you feel the need you can change your world settings from Survival to Creative, you can change the frequency of Meteor showers, and adjust the realism of Survival if you're having a hard time with the masochistic default survival settings.Not a true Sandbox game yet, but I imagine that is a possibility in the future. The plyable objects and terrain is also fun, you can drill into things, blow it apart with rockets, or stockpile warheads and set it all on fire!I left out that I found the Music rather fitting and epic, but to summarize the rest: Buy this game if you like building things and space ships. It's still in-dev so there's definitely more to come!-Addendum 10/10/2014 GET THIS WHILE IT'S ON SALE! This game is PERFECT for the creative minds out there and the people who enjoy space sandboxes. It has it's limits still for me, but once I get a new computer I intend on writing a completely new review. Play it while you can and try and get it while it's on sale!

Early Access Review
								Short "review": Wait a year and see if this game is (still) in active developement. In it's current state it's more of a tech demo with a lot of performance issues. But it can be a great game in the future for sandbox and survival game lovers.Good things+ Looks good.+ Fun to design and build ships, station and cars.+ Cool with Star Systems, especially in Survival mode.+ Got battle mechanics for those interested (can be turned off).+ Pretty good damage and physics modeling - stations, ground and vehicles can break in a neat way. + It's like Minecraft with mods with better graphics but a more shallow tech tree (you can get the coolest stuff in a matter of hours in survival).+ Lots of potential, can be a really great game.+ Strong modding community, you can find a lot of good mods in the Steam Workshop.+ Lot's of options on how to play the game. For example, do you want to start on the moon? Or in the outer space with only a crappy ship? The not so good things- Crashes, freezing your computer. According to the devs they have problem with AMD beta GPU drivers, AND Nvidia drivers. So what should we use? An old Matrox GPU? Anyways, sometimes you can play for 2h without a complete freeze, sometimes you can play 20 minutes, sometimes you get away with "only" restarting the game. But be prepared to reboot your computer. I have tried different drivers and settings, and the game crash (most often also freezing the computer) sooner or later. So saving and fully restarting the game every 45 minutes is a work around.- Performance - This game is pretty taxing on your computer and the game has a sluggish feeling to it (even with 120 FPS).And when fun stuff are happening (like destruction of ships/ground) it will get pretty nasty on the frame rate and general flow/speed (often called simulation speed in this game). So if you want to build a massive space station or planet base, be prepared for a single digit FPS and/or playing in slow motion.- Save game corruption. You start up a new game in Survival, you decide to start on "Earth" in a Star System with Mars, the Moon and a Alien planet. After let's say 12h when you want to explore the star system you notice that the other planets are gone. You verify this with a save game editor. The moon is gone, Mars is gone, it's only "Earth" left. So save games can be corrupted (happened to me at least twice now). You can manually edit new planets in, but that's not the same and they will probably dissapear too. - Progression: If you want the game for a strong Survival experience like in Minecraft (with mods), forget it - you wont find it here. There is no real progression other than mining, no tech tree, nothing to discover since all resources can be found everywhere (besides platinum that can't be found on "Earth"). This means that there is practically no reason to explore or play this like an adventure, you have everything you need where you start (or at least in 1-2h of play time). - Developement cycle. At this rate I wonder if the game ever will be finished. There are weekly updates that bring new cool stuff. I would prefer if they focused on performance and stability before adding all the "fun" stuff. I know it's fun to add graphical updates and stuff like that. And bug fixing is a boring job. But sooner or later you (the devs) have to do the boring stuff too. So, yeah. This game is in early access, developed by a small studio in a slow pace. It got huge potential and besides save game corruption and all the crashes I had fun with it. You should probably wait for your own sake, or get it now on a sale and play it when (or if) it ever get completed. Thumbs down for now but I will be back and hopefully be able to recommend this game.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Let me preempt this by saying this is from a multiplayer perspective.The game, while beautiful and full of promise, is currently a broken pile of chips.For the past month we spent every Tuesday on this for hours (with vods if you must see for proof) full of broken physics, stupid deaths and suicidal AI.  And the planets, while awe-inspiring, are only that way ‘til you ‘land’ on them.My deaths have been many and glitchy...and since this game doesn't keep items on either death or relog, they can be detrimental if you were trying to build something and had items in hand.  Oh, let me say that last bit again, just to be clear: on relog, if you have items in hand, they are GONE.  So I hope you put your stuff away, 'cause what you had is poof!  But I digress...let's actually look at my experiences!My last deaths are as follows: - Walked into a tunnel, touched a pebble.  Fell through the earth to my doom. - Walked up to an AI ship that crashed into the surface, jittering wildly...got touched by it, almost died from the contact (okay, not technically a death, but close). - Used a jetpack to fly up to a mountain top, couldn’t slow down, crashed. - Same, but tried landing on smooth surface. - Walked across the ice.  That’s it.  Was walking across the ice.  The flattest, most benign surface you could imagine.  Tripped on NOTHING and died. - Reloaded server, couldn’t move on spawn...slowly suffocate to death.  REPEATEDLY.This is not to account for the multiple times I ended up somehow falling into the center of the planet from touching a pebble...those don’t count as deaths because I’d have to teleport up to a fellow player (I count one because I didn’t have the ability to TP for that one...used backspace).  Just about any physics object can easily become a glitchy mess...I saw breakdancing vehicles, floating body bags and playing kickball with a ship...before suffocating inside where the ship ACTUALLY was.  Oh, and don't try actually digging down into the earth...you know, where everything is, because trying to point DOWN and hitting the rock with your actual drill is near impossible!  And this is supposedly the EASIEST way to mine right now.  This is all very recent, and after a week of ‘fixes’ for planets.And about those planets...I foresee further issues once it’s realized that the planets have indestructible trees, no fluids (water is ice atm), no caves, and a surface devoid of life.  Each one of these things getting eventually added (as I’m sure the populace will demand them) will each in turn break the game yet again.PLAY EARLY ACCESS AT YOUR OWN RISK.If and when this game leaves Early Access, I will retry it to see if it is playable, but I assure you...I will NOT be touching this game until that label is removed.

Early Access Review
								So...sold as 4-packs, multiplayer barely works past making a few ships then the server starts to choke.   -Solution: buy a better computer, the game can't be optimized.                     Wait, no, its probably your internet connection (because 6 ms is pretty bad latency)    So play single player!  The game sells itself by showing you that you can ram ships into eachother.  So you can either paste them in via creative mode, then have a minute or so of fun for $20, or you can try survival mode, spend hours on one ship, then hours on another, then crash your ships into each other by yourself. On a certain genre of interent sites, $20 you could get you a whole month of crashing into yourself, and it would definitely be a lot less frustrating.I can't recommend this game.  Its certainly circling the drain, just waiting for the standard early release "this is 1.0 release, we've fullfilled our contractual obligations with valve, we're out.Honestly, 3 years and millions in development and its a modicum better than it was when it slid on to the steam store. And like most early release titles, that initial groundwork was so poorly and ineptly laid (as one would expect) that years of improvements and a 50 MAN TEAM can't update more than a FEW BUGS A WEEK, with no new content.Save your money and your future frustration and look for a professionally developed game, because early releases are on the same level you'd expect if some guy in his garage built an airplane. It may fly, but I wouldn't count on it being particularly stable or an alltogether enjoyable experience.

number of helpful: 36 of 57 people (63%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is very fun when it's working as intended, but i can't recommend it for people who want to play it with their friends, which was the main draw for me. The game seems to be a much less bug-ridden experience if you play solo and perhaps in a creative mode, but networked and survival gameplay is very much unpolished.I've owned this game for years now and i've played it at multiple stages during it's development, which makes me feel like i have a decent grasp on it's issues with it's rate of development and bugfixing, which motivated me to write this review.I had a lot of fun with this game. I've played it for near 100 hours. After KSP it's probably the best space sandbox game.But despite all of it's potential i can't really recommend the game, especially as a person who likes multiplayer and playing with friends.I've always thought that this game was great, but after having it for years i'm not seeing much improvement in terms of bugfixing and networking optimization.If you want to buy this game, even despite all the bugs, in hopes that the developers will fix it.. I'm saying, don't do it. There is no guarantee that they'll fix anything, since they haven't really fixed any of the core networking issues since i first played the game. Everything is still jumpy, permanently desyncing, crahsing, etc.The game is ridden with bugs that can break your server unless you clean it up occasionally.It's also full of bugs that have you or your buddies constantly restarting the game.Most of the game's issues are networking-related, for example clients not receiving the same information, even at <100 ping, which spirals out of control for some reason, ending at a point where clients may not see interactions of some objects at all, or they see everything 10km away from where it really is. These are really common occurences.The conveyor system is full of bugs as well, sometimes pulling items in and out of inventories where items shouldn't even be allowed to flow due to the system not being in a loop, just a one way linear set of sorters, cargo boxes and assemblers.Even though the maximum speed in the game is limited to a grueling 100m/s, supposedly in order to prevent the physics from breaking, it still constantly breaks, while making travel to other planets a journey that takes HOURS unless you mine for just as long of a time for resources to make and use a jumpdrive.Starting scenarios are kind of a mess as well, there is no option to just start in a star system with asteroids and limited resources, essentially allowing you to play a survival mode where you can't spawn in new ships. There are some scenarios but they may not include some other generated features of the game. So you either modify server settings on the fly, or tweak your world with the editor in order to have a non-creative, survival experience with all the generated feautres (planets/moons/asteroids) of the game.If you are completely new to the game you may miss out on these features entirely if you just start one of the scenarios that seem good.I have the most stable computer i've ever had, reaching 10 weeks of uptimes regularily while playing games and using various heavy applicatios.I don't think any game has ever crashed my system consistently since i've built my rig 2-3 years ago, yet space engineers manages to do it 2 times in an hour.So, in closing... People who have played DayZ can understand a situation like this, where the game can be SO FUN yet so RIDDLED with bugs even after years of development, which is what makes this game really hard to recommend, because i DO want to play games with friends.The DayZ developers worked with a proprietary engine that is very much known to be bug-ridden.I'm not sure what the excuse of Keen Software House is, as they've been working this engine engine from the ground up, starting with their previous games.Now they're also working on a game called medieval engineers...?Why?

Early Access Review
								This game has one of the more innovative and interesting construction mechanics i've seen, and has had an opportunity to do what tekkit and its ilk never could; It could have let engineers fight not just with combat skill but with their skill in engineering. The vast creations of players could have dueled where factories in Feed The Beast could have only refined the materials you threw into them. The joy is in the puzzle of maintaining the unwieldy system you yourself built.But this game has none of that joy.With rare exception, Engineering does not matter, only guns and armor matter.With rare exception, piloting does not matter, only guns and armor matter.With rare exception, being smart does not matter, only time spent working matters.It is my firm belief that progress in a game should not be marked by time spent, but by mastery achieved. A grind is no substitute for gameplay.(oh, also, Keen software somehow managed to one-up minecraft's wolves update, by making an update with EXPLODING CYBER WOLVES whose role in the game could have been filled in many different ways using any number of systems already in place. KSWH have, design wise, forgotten what they have.)

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								I don't know where to start with this review. With nearly 200 hours, I can say I fell into this game with a Minecraft level addiction. It's been sitting in my library unplayed for a while because the game seemed to lack any real goal, or formal challenge. This changed when they implemented planets.My first and only real run at SE lasted pretty much the bulk of my playtime. Not having any real reason to play the game up until that point. But this go-round I instituted my own goal; I would crash on a planet in a starting ship, I'd get off planet and build an orbital base, from the base I'd build a ship that'd allow me to travel to another planet.Not a complicated goal, but it kept my interest in the game up. I had just gotten the step where I build my own ship, a mobile base it you may. By that time I had left my orbital base to explore. I had a half-build mothership, a mining ship, and a ship for landing planet-side.I decided to leave my base behind and explore since I now had functioning thrusters, and even better, a warp drive. However, as I moved around my mothership, I noticed some really strange things happening with my docked ships when I moved my mothership. While staying docked they'd still manage to shift in my hangar hull.Well that was kinda annoying. After nearly every jump and every ship repositioning (even after lowering my gyro power to 2%, as I thought that might be doing it) I had to go back to my hanger and re-dock my ships.Anyway, after hours and hours of work, I've given up on the game. Last night I left my ship saved right after a jump heading towards the moon. When I logged back in, I was dead, and my ship was hurling through space at about 42 m/s with no explanation. It was stopped when I saved last night. Sorta, I noticed more and more after I'd jump somewhere that my ship would 'drift' even after inertia dampening it back down to no thrust, it'd accelerate back up to 0.01 m/s.After having to respawn twice and do some quick jetpack work, I was able to get my ship stopped. My mining ship is gone, my lander is destroyed and my hangar has a huge hole in it. No explanation. Hours of work destroyed by a bug.Like any early access game, wait till it's released.UPDATE: 06/02/2016 Gave it a try again, spent a considerable amount of time building until eventually I had two unwarranted ice explosions. Containers full of ice in two ships spontaneously exploded. This game is still not ready for prime-time. I'd recommend steering clear of it.I'd suggest not buying it at all. I doubt it will ever be fixed.I doubt I'll be trying it again. I was also greatly looking forward to Medieval Engineers, I can say with all certainty that I will be passing on it completely. From the mostly negative reviews it's currently getting, I guess it's not a huge surprise.

number of helpful: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								"If Minecraft is LEGO, then Space Engineers is LEGO Technic." Key Features:-Survival game with a focus on building efficiently-Voxel based terrain which allows for landscapes to look smooth and realistic-Can build vehicles like cars, ships, rockets, etc.-Has multiplayer-Players can traverse planets or take to the stars. Possibly discovering other planets-Space piratesPros:-Fun and addicting survival mode-Even if you're more interested in survival mode, creative is still useful for making prototypes and blueprints-Multiplayer is extremely easy to set up-Game gets prepetually updated with new features and bug fixes-Active workshop community creating new blocks, vehicles, scripts etc. -Lots of potential playtime-Good tutorials-Blocks are NOT locked to a universal gridCons:-Game can be confusing at first. Reccomend checking out some "Getting Started" guides before jumping in-Building good vehicles is hard and an improperly built vehicle can be the loss of alot of resources. If you're new, test them in creative first-The games physics don't always play nice. Especially in multiplayer. This is a problem the devs are actively working on though.-Can be demanding for weaker machines. Once again, the devs are doing their best to get rid of this.-Rather buggy-Gets stale without friends. Make sure you have a friend to play with before buying. The multiplayer is a major focusOverall. Space Engineers is a really addicting game for those who are willing to put the time needed into it. It takes a few hours of building before you get your first viable vehicle but once you get past that initial difficulty curve, things will go alot smoother and you'll be pushing out amazing creations in no time. And even if you don't like designing vehicles and bases there's an entire workshop full of blueprints which you can import to the game. This game get an 8/10 for bringing a rather unique twist to the survival building genre and keeping it very fun for a very long time despite being full of glitches.

content:
Posted: January 28
Early Access Review
								There is a lot of fun to be had in this game if you like building things in space. OR IF YOU JUST ENJOY GOING INSANE. It is a patience test the likes I have never seen. I like hardcore/challenging games but this goes into absurd territory too often. Once the initial cool factor of space building wears off, it is just a futility/space madness simulator, which it excels at in every way imagineable. Cool graphics and neat functions are very addictive at first, time will fly incredibly fast. Spending many hours throughout the night just to get that next thing built, it will only take a few minutes, you keep putting off bed. Then out of nowhere some inexplicable, random explosion sends all of your stuff that took time to mine, refine, assemble, transport, weld, and configure to be scattered about and deleted as the server detects you're not within some tiny range of the objects. Boy that was fun, it's now 5am all for nothing. Not once, but a couple dozen times this has basically been the case over the years of coming and going every few months. Like a fool, I keep trying to give it a chance. For just maybe one more time I'll get lucky or I just have to put that one extra ounce of effort in and things will be just dandy.Yeah, I know what you're saying. It's all my fault, x catastrophe happened for a perfectly explainable reason. blah freakin blah. But after almost 900 hours and careful investigation of causes I know the difference between what is my fault and what is because of the game. I don't use pistons, rotors, landing gears, nor any mods beyond experimentation and I'm being as careful as possible, one thing at a time, graphics on lowest, on an empty server, <50 ping, good server settings, and i have 16gb ram, 8core 4ghz cpu... but nope, still not good enough? Don't build too much, don't use this, don't do that, must do this before that then this then that...then that's it. Actual large ship combat is a pipe dream, starting a decent foundation to commence such is loaded with constant setbacks. I don't mind figuring out a long list of getting things done, or dealing with a bit of stuttering, and of course my own mistakes and bad planning, but it is extremely tedious and limiting to have to trial and error everything to avoid nonsense issues and there to be little to do otherwise, trying to avoid whatever random BS will happen next.  It is walking on thin ice, all the time. I know what you're saying. It's space, it's dangerous, it's this it's that. Or it's a complex game, it is very hard to program blah blah. Yes, I know. Things will work just fine just enough to get your hopes up that you can move on to the next operation only to bring you down again, having nothing to do with the dangers of space or your actions, just purely the game being stupid and requiring a million band-aids to hobble things along. Usually thanks to processing a stupid amount of data that could be more efficiently handled as well as crappy networking. But that's understandable when things go bad, when there's a lot going on. I'm talking about when you're by yourself and performance is grand, you still get SNAFU's that will make you pull your hair out and cuss furiously. Unless that sort of thing gives you the warm fuzzies.It is loaded with a million features and complex layering of which can seem amazing at first that it works at all, until you realize there's simply too much, making the mp performance terrible and otherwise glitchy as all hell.  The most fun you'll have is exploring workshop entries and messing around in single player in my opinion, but that gets old quick as there is no game otherwise to work towards. The AI is non-existent. Just some cheesy simple spiders and wolves and aimbot ships. No AI characters or factions. Just scripted ships with red signals. It's more of a base/ship making sandbox sort of interactive editor with no real depth of goals to fulfill beyond the chores of mining, fixing stuff/rebuilding and making workarounds because of all the ridiculous conflicts. This is all besides the fact that there is no true physics in the game except locally floating components/ores and ship controls. Planets do not rotate, the sun is geocentric (revolves around everything in the skybox), there are no orbits, etc. No basic temperature of any kind except thruster damage. Things that are essential considerations to space travel. But of course those are the most minor of complaints.Multiplayer: Unless you're lucky to have a few friends on a good LAN, multiplayer is a complete sh!tshow unless you're a masochist. Stuff which took forever to build since most servers want super realism rates as well as having to find some safe space to not get looted immediately. That is IF you don't have the beacon/antenna bug that broadcasts to everyone on the server your location no matter the distance or settings, the items of which are required to keep ships on most servers ironically enough, the thing that allows you to be ignored by cleanup scripts is the bait that attracts the looters. Not to mention all of the horrific lag spikes and sim speed issues, where there is yet to be any decent multithreading to be seen. Then you can't rejoin the server since it's not updated to the latest version or it went off line for a while and you usually lose all your stuff. I simply don't play much anymore, it's always infuriating, a waste of time. Then add  the community is plagued with a lot of complete d!ckheads. I can't count how many times I've been crapped on just for asking a basic question or voicing a normal concern that would come from anybody who doesn't base their entire life around the game. I can understand tough love for mindless curiosities but if you're not in the cult of understanding all of the esoteric ways in which this game screws with you, then the asperger-ridden, spoiled d0uchebag geeks and their equally braindead sycophants drop in and cut you off at the pass eager to start sh!t and troll you away, taking whatever issue you're having personally because their life has nothing else invested, apparently. How they tolerate each other is beyond me. *cough* FOUNTAINCORE *cough*  Most of the nice people I've met are those that play this crap as rarely as I do.We keep getting excuses that it's early access blah blah blah but how long is this going to drag on for? How many years has it been now? We're going on 4 years and it's been in open development how long and where are the significant improvements? There's simply too many hands in too many cookie jars with this clusterfuc|< for it to be a game worth wasting time on any time soon. For all the good press the game has received for their ability to keep pushing updates consistently and have as many sales as they have and the awards given...how do they still not have the programming/director talent required to get this out of dev hell? I know they are an indie dev unit and programming isn't easy but at what point do you graduate the amateur sphere and move to become/hire professionals when you're raking in the money?Right now the game is only for uber geek fanboys with supercomputers who enjoy never ending bugs and zero criticism. Pin the blue ribbon upon their chests for masochist excellence. If you want a better, real in depth review check this one out: http://steamcommunity.com/id/leewells2000/recommended/244850/Also, I see a lot of reviews recommending Empyrion. It looks better in general. Time to get in the escape pod and jump ship, but i'm not holding my breath.

content:
Posted: March 17
Early Access Review
								Space Engineers is a game which I don't really know how to explain. It's a sandbox game, a building game, a shooter game, and an exploration game. Space Engineers takes you out into the galaxy as a space engineer (obviously), starting you off with anything from a fully kitted out base with a large red ship, to nothing but empty space for you to just fly around in until you find something. The game incorporates what I assume to be a randomly generated universe with randomly generated planets and asteroids. Players can choose to play however they want in Space Engineers, you can be a military commander with a giant armored behemoth to a simple farmer, tending to his asteroid (by that I mean mining resources). The game does not have a story to follow, in fact when I was dumped into the world I wasn't given any direction as to what I'm supposed to be doing, so naturally I just went around and blew♥♥♥♥♥♥up.Building in Space Engineers is very easy, as blocks all snap together seamlessly. There are many different types of blocks that can be used, my personal favourite being military orientated blocks which include heavy, armoured pieces that allow ships to take large amounts of damage. Unfortunately, these heavier blocks require a lot more materials to be able to build, and when my ship took a hell of a lot of damage in a battle with another friend I cried myself to sleep because I had nowhere near the required amount of steel to repair even the tiniest part of my beloved ship. Military oriented blocks also refer to the weapons that ships can use  to destroy each other. To my knowledge, there are four blocks that allow ships to attack; Missile turrets, missile launchers, gattling turrets, and sentry turrets. Missile turrets are best used as asteroid defense and to directly attack smaller ships that may be attacking yours. Missile launchers are best used to attack other capitol ships such as battleships, cruisers and carriers as they can be grouped together closely, and can do a large amount of damage in a small area. Gattling turrets are best used as a missile defense, and  the sentry turrets are best used to fend off enemies that may board your ship. The lighter building blocks are useful for creating mining ships to gather resources, as they are light, easy to repair and allow for increased mobility in ships.Mining in space engineers is a very well done system. The jackhammer tool that the player starts off with does a very good job of mining different ores in order to create your ships. Building a ship and attaching drills allows for a much easier mining experience, as larger areas can be mined at one time, and the player does not have to worry about running out of oxygen when going to other asteroids to ,mine.Overall, I'd give this game an 8.5 out of 10. There are a few bugs I have encountered but overall it's a great experience, even though it's only in Beta.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2016
Early Access Review
Review 01.159... Oct 28, 2016I write this review from the perspective of enjoying to build structures and crafts as I have little interest in PvP, and people should learn to be creative together rather than destructive.Briefly about the gameYou start your game stranded in space in a rescue ship with just enough fuel to carefully navigate to nearby asteroids, or on various planets with a starting base. A number of scenarios are available and can be customized.Your first order of business in space is to find uranium to keep going, then you can search for other ores. Through the use of the rescue ships equipment you can refine ores and create components that will allow you to build, assemble and repair your vessel using a welding torch. Components can be salvaged using a grinder to tear them apart. An ancient hammer drill is used to locate and mine ores ( not very space age ). You can build almost anything your imagination can dream up, using various shapes, however not all combinations will allow you to control everything correctly ( for example the last time I played wheels mounted to pistons could not be controlled).Pro's:Multiplayer allows you to share your game with friends and the server aspects are done in the background. You unfortunately loose your inventory when rejoining a friends game, unless you stored it before exiting. So much for crash situations, or network failures where saving is rarely an option.The physics are fairly real, and components that fall off downed ships can be salvaged for reuse.You have the options during setup to increase the inventory size from realistic to 3 or 10x, however this is still very small, and you'll make many many trips. You can build constructor ships to expedite this with much larger inventories and assembly speed.Currently you don't have to be concerned with eating, you only need oxygen, hydrogen, energy and the materials required for those to carry on.All constructions in the game have structural integrity so if a piece breaks off, it floats or falls a way for later disassembly (limited by item settings).You can switch between Creative and Survival and adjust settings on already started worlds, which is a great idea to save time.Metals can be crumpled and damaged by impact, however its at a performance hit.You can still mine ores in Creative mode, which allows basically an infinite inventory, however great care must be taken when changing back to lower inventory levels, or you risk losing those ores.Blueprints allow construction of additional vehicles using a projector.Cons:The performance is BAD, and gets worse the larger the base, even with far more than the minimum requirements. Moving an item from inventory to storage chest can take several seconds, which is totally ridiculous, compared to the tutorial (an instant drag).You must make many many trips to build anything significant at even 10x inventory, unless you build a constructor ship. Generally its just a slow slog in survival.Controls leave much to be desired, complex, and you can easily get disoriented, using the mouse.All blocks must be welded together in place with is very very slow, you may die of boredom first.You must keep pressing the pickup key to obtain ores before they float away ( in space ) or get underfoot on planet.Textures, colours, etc.. are limited.No Terra-forming tools exist beyond the hammer drill, which is very crude. So much for filling annoying collision holes caused by crashed ships or creating a better seal against a rock face.You have zero sense of surroundings, and your vision is very tunnelled perhaps due in part to the helmet, which can never be removed only opened.If a item gets damaged or you removed it ( a wheel for example ), you may have to go to great lengths to replace it while on a planet, since agility is off the table (at least a piston can be used as a jack stand).Unfortunately I got so frustrated with the poor performance that I removed the game, before evaluating any new features or added parts. Why on earth or anywhere should I be waiting for items to move from my inventory to a storage chest, when I'm the most important thing in the game and all mobs are turned off. The inventory I was looking at, kept showing the entire inventory of oxygen bottles instead of paying attention to what I was doing moving ores from inventory to storage.PS.. Comment to steam... life is not black and white... we need a star rating system in addition to Yes/No 7/10 stars.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2013
Early Access Review
								AWESOME!!!!!!!! (This was all I could come up with back in Nov 2013, only a month after game release)Now its nearly May 2016 and I have got over 5200hours playing this game, I still think its awesome.In the last 2 years or so this game has come a long way from what I remember it was like not long after release. We now have planets to visit and build on as well as a world that is 1Billion K's across to explore. Although, much of it is empty space with asteroids throughout, each and every world can be customised to suit your gaming wishes. There is 100,000's of mods available on the workshop that you can use to make your game experience how you would like it. If you enjoy Star Trek for example, there is many Star Trek themed mods that you could have in your world so you could build the Enterprise or maybe a Klingon Bird of Prey. There is over 200 planets that have been created by the modding community that you could populate your world with. The choices of gamemodes suit many different players, Single Player Creative mode where you can build whatever you wish without the need for resources. This is a great mode for designing and building ships or stations for blueprint creation for use in other worlds and also learning about all the functions of the many choices of in-game blocks. Single Player Survival, with this gamemode you can challenge yoursef to find the resources you need to build your hopes and dreams. There are several scenarios to choose from, each with differing setups to start a game, for example the Easy Start Scenarios give you a station on a planet with 3 basic ships to get you started in the game. in the setup for each game you can customise the setup to make it however challenging you want. From inventory size, crafting speeds to settings like pirate drones and even cyberhounds and alien spiders which will attack you or start chewing through blocks on your base to get to you.Then there is multiplayer, you can host your single player game on your own machine to invite friends to join in, or there is many dedicated servers to choose from. I have been running a dedicated server myself for over 2 years now (spaceengineers.com.au). Now, I will be honest and say the multiplayer Netcode is still a WIP and at times, issues in game will frustrate you to no end. Don't let this put a dampner on how you feel about the game, the developers have stuck to their weekly update schedule and slowly but surely everything is getting better. As with all Alpha development games, some patches can end up breaking the game for some, but be patient as the team will surely have the issues patched up soon.Overall, I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys building, using and showing off their creations. There is a plethora of player creations on the workshop, including blueprints that other players have created that you can build in game. You are only limited in this game by your own imagination. Search for Space Engineers on youtube too, if this review hasn't been enough to convince you, i'm sure some of the fantastic videos of player creations, machinima and the like would be enough to push you over the edge and make you want to buy it.Hope to see you in game one day, and if you found this review helpful please give it a thumbs up.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is a great and fun game but it's getting old. The idea behind this game is great and so far they've done a good job in making this game, however, this game has been in early access for quite some time now and the stability and functionality seem to be decreasing. They have added a lot of things which were in high demand by the community, like planets. But the coding and the work behind the curtain is questionable. They seem to be adding content and patching stuff that really is not important right now instead of actually fixing game breaking bugs. After some time playing you will realize that mostly everything you will build needs to be pretty big. This however doesn't correspond with the game engine, as you will lag... a lot. The problem may not even be your PC (I have 30-45 fps with multiple HUGE (200x100 blocks or bigger ) creations and the proccessor is fine, but the Simdrop is there, and once you fire up your refineries, assemblers, grinders, welders or even weapons, the game will drop down to less than 0.5 in Simspeed which results it in being unplayable. Thus completely breaking large creations. This is even worse in multiplayer. The AI in this game was never supposed to be part of it, just like planets, now they added it but its just a joke. It's always exactly the same thing with every NPC you see. You don't even need a ship to take most of them down. You spot a ship, you approach it and it will open fire once your inside it's turret range, which is max. 800 meters. Other ships warp in, sit several kilometers away and pump out very frequent drones to harass you, which a couple of turrets take easy care of, if they happen to function correctly. Other than that those drones are nothing but a waste of ammo. The world is infinite yet there are only 3 planets accompanied by their moons. So you can go away from those planets, but there is nothing else out there except some astroids if you set up your game that way. Cyperhounds on planets are also a joke as they randomly spawn behind you every few minutes and are near to impossible to sound spot. They are bugged too, as they're bodies most likely will disregard the earth's gravitation and drift off into space. Spaceships are also extremely fragile. Well, nearly anything is.There are also other things which turned me off from this game after doing some research on the developers. I really hope that Keen Software House will spit in their hands and pull themselves together and get back on track with this game. But I've been patient for a long time and I think the time for Keen to hide behind the "early access" is about over. Really hope it's gonna get fixed and be amazing in the full release, but my hope of that ever happening is nearly gone.--Update--Keen is still sitting on their♥♥♥♥♥ feeling good that their fanboys, who apperantly have no idea what a GOOD game looks like, praise them for useless sound patches and minor bug fixes. Mean while, the major problems within the game are still present. Multiplayer is still broken. Do yourself a favour and DO NOT BUY this game.Buy EGS instead, its better in just about every aspect and hasn't been around nearly as long as Space Engineers has. Now some may call EGS a rip off (altough I disagree), but seriously.... who cares if they deliver the product in a much, much, MUCH better way?

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is EARLY ACCESS, so bugs are to be expected. The problem I have is with the trend of updating the developers pursue, causing the light at the end of the tunnel to grow dimmer all the time rather than brighter.I love this game and have put many hours into it. You can create space ships, rovers, starbases, and a myriad of other things with well-thought, intelligently-designed blocks. This is one of the best games I have ever played--ever.However, I cannot recommend it currently. While they constantly update the game weekly, I have noticed a trend in updating where more content will be added or existing content will be modified in some way, but bug fixes to the game-breaking issues remain unchecked after months of waiting (some I hear from friends have been there for over a year). They do of course fix minor bugs, but they seem to constantly miss or avoid the major ones affecting gameplay. On top of this, more and more bugs seem to be introduced as the game is updated and those bugs also remain unchecked. Some examples of bugs I've encountered:-If you turn the power off in your ship, the engines will eventually freeze up when you try to turn the power back on and won't work again. If you're parked in a port, your ship will drop and likely break into many pieces. The current workaround is not to turn the power off at all (it took awhile to figure this out), but it caused so much frustration for me.-Disengaging the landing gear from terrain (with gravity only, as far as I know) will sometimes cause a catastrophe, making half of your ship explode due to a physics engine error.-In multiplayer the movement correction will sometimes cause your character to appear inside a wall, killing you instantly.-Mining drill stops working after a minute or two of use. This is a new bug, so hopefully they do manage to clear this one up quickly.-Entering a search string in the inventory screen now causes it to show no results even though there should be some. This seems to be a scroll bar error, so as long as you scroll to the top of the inventory screen before searching it will work. Again, this is a relatively new bug.-Standing on the icecap of mars causes you to slide around in multiplayer. Everything just slowly 'drifts' in one direction. We had to abandon an entire base eventually because of this one.-Long connections of blocks will cause the game to stutter each time you place a new block in that grid. This effect will get progressively worse the longer you connect the blocks. This is a long-time known bug by the developers that is related to the electrical system, and yet it has stayed there for the months I've been playing.-The most recent patch has given me my first Blue Screen of Death on my computer. It has frozen the game completely once, and it has caused the game to crash to the developer report once. This was only 30 minutes of gameplay, and unfortunately I can't continue to play the game like this.It's not to say they haven't done some good things, of course. They've added a hardware-rendered particle system (it used to be software-rendered) which increased how well the game ran. They modified the block placement system and cleaned it up a lot (which some debate it worse than before.)Please be cautious. This game is awesome when it's functioning well, but right now it just isn't.

Posted: February 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								Alright, close your eyes and picture Minecraft. Now, replace the pixelated visual style with crisp graphics that rival Bioware titles. Good, now replace the medieval fantasy setting with the depths of space. Then, add the physical properties associated with space, and a building mechanic that not only lets you build architecture, but also space craft ranging in size from small fighters to gargantuan carrier vessels. Add blocks of various shapes and components for complicated mechanisms such as motors and gravity generators. Let's also throw in a destruction engine that lets every block deform with stress and damage in the most realistic manner conceivable. What you'll have is the wet dream of every creative gaming enthusiast, only this isn't a dream.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								     Space engineers is simply a fantastic game for the gamer who is into creation in a sci-fi atmosphere. Basically, the point of the game is single/group/multiplayer (vs) survival (or sandbox) creation of ships and stations in space. Player vs. player combat is virtually nonexistent, as the point of the game is to create ships and bases to do the combat for you. The building possibilities are relatively endless, as new parts are added with each update. It is somewhat 'HD Minecraft'-esque in that all parts are geometric (though the asteroids are not). It is rather graphically demanding for the texture quality, however this is somewhat expected in a game where hundreds of objects  are rendered constantly, at once. The multiplayer experience is so-so, in that private servers are a ton of fun, but public servers ultimately lead to griefing of your structures the moment you log out. There are other space games other there, like KSP, but it is hard to compare the two in a which-is-better way, as their playstyles are far too different.tl;dr: 8.5/10 Fun sandbox creation game.
