content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								As always, buying a game that is still in early stages of development is a risky move. It was not without hesitation that I bought this game, and that was even at a 50% sale. Well, after the three first days I had amassed an impressive ~30 hours of playtime simply because I couldn't stop playing!It should be said that I have not put much time at all into the Survival mode, I've almost exclusively been playing Creative mode. If you even consider buying this game I advise you to check Youtube for gameplay videos - there are lots of channels that give you a good perspective on what this game is, and what you can do within it.Well, on to some pros and cons!Pros:+ Vanilla game offers wonderfull possibilities when it comes to construct your ships and bases.+ The modding community is outstanding and expands vastly on the vanilla game.+ The Dev-team seems to update the game in regular intervals. (They even released a major one on X-mas day!)+ In my opinion fairly cheap for what you get.+ Out of ideas for what to build? Youtube is full of incredible channels that feature user created content from Space Engineers that continue to inspire for a long time.+ The ability to save your designs and "paste" them into new world. This is togglable when you create a new world.+ Easy to get started with and a world of more complex constructs awaits you if you dive deeper into the game.Cons:- The maximum travel speed ingame might feel pretty slow if you are playing on a large world with long distances to cover.- Game is still in a pretty early development stage, so bugs and glitches are bound to be around for a while.- Public multiplayer can seem infested by griefers unless you are playing with people you know or trust.- Easy to spend way too many hours playing, forgetting other stuff like sleeping or eating...To conclude this review, I would like to say that I most heartily recommend this game to anyone who wants to let loose their creative side when building awesome stuff in space.Just my few cents!/Trobbel

number of helpful: 12 of 15 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								Let's clear the air. I've been playing this game in 1-2 month fits since about 2014. In that time, I've made everything from hover bikes (using player mods) to full length battle-cruisers. From small orbital mining platforms, to acre-spanning planetary bases. I've made cargo ships, mining vehicles, a replica of the SHIELD heli-carrier, and essentially anything else I felt like.The Good:-Great selection of mods from the community keep this already massive game perpetually new-Great graphics for a voxel game-Continually adding new features and mechanisms. Life support was a game changer.-You can build in creative mode, save the game, and turn that game save into a server.-Despite other reviews - multiplayer *does* work - it's just glitchy. I typically keep persisten objects down to double digits and limit players to about 8. Not super fun, admittedly - but you gotta' work within the constrains of whats possible in the game. I see a lot of reviews here harping on things the game just isn't designed to do (yet, if ever), and it's silly to me because its analagous to complaining that Red Dead Redemption doesn't have lasers and cyborg ninjas.The Bad:-AI is stupid. Last I played, you had roughly 3 options for "enemies"/NPCs. A) drone ships that are a bit OP if I'm honest. B) These weird spider things that literally jump so high they kill themselves upon landing. C) These odd cyber-tiger looking things that destroy your base while you're off not paying attention. None of them are fun, none of them really add anything to the game, and only seem to be there as a token gesture, like "ok. here. something to shoot at other than your buddies."-Game slows down to unplayable depths if you overestimate your computer's ability to handle this game.-Lots of features need tweaking if not outright revamping, but devs seem to have their own agenda/priorities on what gets fixed first.-The planets are MASSIVE! Which would be awesome if there were any sort of reason to visit them. Other than a change of scenery (which in itself is a bit bland and repetitive), mining on planets is a mostly-hands on job as building a reliable vehicle to do this can only be done in creative mode. There isn't as much as liquid water on any planet. And so far - I've been unable to find more than stone iron and ice on a planet.With all this said - I still highly recommend this game to anyone who's ever enjoyed building their own spaceships, stations, or just wants an excuse to float around in space. Just stay off the planets.

number of helpful: 12 of 15 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25
Early Access Review
								With all negative reviews because of bugs around here I think it is only fair that I share my experience, I play this game since the early alphas before the survival mode even existed, before wheels, jump drives, docking, beacons, turrets, programmable blocks,conveyor systems, projectors, welding/grinder ships, planets, and oxygen/hydrogen.I have not played as many hours as some people here but I have a fair amount of experience and I say that in this two years (maybe more) I never had problems with bugs, not even once. There is people saying it is unplayable, that's absurd, such a shame people that don't get the meaning of "alpha" and "beta" flaming such a good game because they had a one in a million problem that is probably fault of their own computer, drivers, OS.Im not saying that bugs don't exist, of course there are bugs, this game is not finished yet, again, people complaining about them don't know what "alpha" and "beta" means. Most complaints about bugs I saw here are because of landing gears,rotors,and pistons. I personally never had issues with them that I could call a bug, but I didn't made anything really complex using them either, most of my ships have landing gears and they always worked for me, in one of my survival games I attach all my small ships to my refinery ship using their landing gears to take them with me when moving elsewhere.If you want this style of game ("minecraft in space") kind of game, this is the best one I found so far, at its current state and as a programmer it surprises me how optimized this game is. For a voxel game with a infinite universe, asteroids and actual planets of such size and complexity where you can dig and build on each planet and asteroid and even code in-game scripts for ships it runs extremely well, while other game of same style I tried that had inferior graphics and small square planets sent the processor usage to maximum, making me lock in 30 fps to avoid overheat, space engineers run smoothly with 60 fps without big differences to temperature, even near planets that in SE case are round, way bigger and actually look good.This game updates weekly with sometimes a patch on the following day to address bugs discovered after the update reached the users, there are times with lots of new features, and times where the devs stop releasing new features or only do minor ones to focus this updates in bug fixing, this is a game Im very happy to see the way it evolved on the last years, and how the community took part in it, planets where not a feature they were going to introduce, that was a community request.For the ones complaining how new features bring bugs, That's how coding and developing works, and it will happen until the game is finished. This game improved dramatically while other similar games barely changed, and actually reached beta. In my opinion the best of its style, I had to make this review because some of the bad ones around here are really unfair in my opinion and experience with this game.

content:
Posted: March 31
Early Access Review
								With over 500 hours of gametime on this game I can honestly say that this was a really good game that had great potential. I know alot of people are complaining about bugs and whatnot but those will hopefully be looked at in time. I really REALLY loved this game, the freedom to build whateveryou liked, the realism in when crafting a ship if it wasn't built well in terms of having enough thrust to leave a planet or just build a ship that won't crash because it's not balanced out. Things like this really made me love this game and I had a blast both crafting and fighting other players and NPC pirate ships. Hell I even made a vehicle that ran like a tank because the ground vehicle wheels are buggy (last time I played) and don't work in multiplayer games, BUT! if you use Rotors instead it works perfectly.. just assigned the left rotors on button 1 and the right rotors on button 2 and then just turned the rotors on and off to move and turn it.. like you drive a tank bacically... What killed the game for me is bacically the lack of dedicated servers. Playing solo get's boring fast and playing on someone elses server, some servers just vanish and the same can be said about all the hours spent on building something there and you have to start from scratch again somewhere else and hope that server will be up longer. Bacically I think everyone that likes crafting/building games will have a blast with this game for a few hours, but after that I fear you will lose interest because you either end up having nothing to do or you lose everything and have to start over again and again and that in itself get's really boring after a while. Another issue with private servers is the simspeed and latency, having dedicated servers from the developers means they are finetuned to run the game as well as it can be run.Bottomline... if the devs decide to startup some dedicated servers then I think this game will be one of the best games ever made. It has great potential so I hope they get some servers up in the future or if they never planned on doing it I hope they rethink that decision.

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								The alpha that keeps on giving.  Space engineers is a sandbox style game in which you are placed in space and can build to your hearts content.  It shares the same genre as minecraft being a sandbox but is not Minecraft.  Think of it this way, Battlefield is a first person shooter but is in no way the same as Counter Strike.  Sure, each has similarities in that you are in first person mode with a firearm, but beyond that, the mechanics are very different. Space Engineers takes on this same style.  It seperates itself apart from the rest in that it is in space, is not completely block based, and has a modern/futuristic feel to it that takes some getting used to.  Building is easy in this game, there are many different types of items but the foundation is always a block, slope, inverted corner, triangle, or a landing gear for a ship.  You can make stations, ships, capital ships (larger ships essentially), opening and closing doors, hidden turrets behind a set of lights, etc.  The possibilites are endless and the weekly updates make it even better.Uranium is your life force and your refinery and assembler are your tools.  Without these three things nothing happens and you end up respawning inside a yellow ship with these basic things and nothing else.  Turning things off like a gravity generator and the engines may be necessary at first just to preserve what little uranium you do have.  Do not fret however, almost all materials needed are not difficult to find...for the most part.  Some places you might find entire sections of uranium while other areas may contain traces of the ore but also have spots of other ore like gold, magnesium, silicon, nickel, iron, and silver.  Each has their uses of course.Bugs are apparent in some instances of the game.  It is an alpha so it will have issues but as said before, weekly updates are releasing new content and fixing old content that may not work properly.  Dedicated servers are an option or you can just run it from your local machine as you see fit.  The dedicated server that I run is locked down to my group only and consumes very little resources.  In fact, my machine is running a mumble server, a minecraft server, and Space Engineers and the machine is an old AMD Atlhlon x3 x64 system with 4 GB of RAM on windows 7.  So anyone can run a server!Performance wise, the game engine has a bit of optimization needed.  Sometimes it lags other times it is fine.  I run a very clean system that is top notch performance with dual SSDs in RAID 0 and 16 GB of RAM with dual video cards and a high end processor and still experience issues from time to time.  Nothing serious, but still, they are there.  Overall, the atmosphere of the game is great.  The sound effects, music, graphics, everything is great.  The controls are a bit wonky at first but you get used to them.  You can just remap controls if you really get irritated though, so keep that in mind as an option.  Creative mode and Survival are a blast although the latter is my favorite.  Playing with friends is fun and hunting down those armed mining ships and military ships is a blast.  Physics play a role, so that means mass is also important and how many thrusters you have overall will make a difference.  Everything from reactors to guns and stations to capital ships are present in this game.  Nothing here is poorly executed aside from the menu system which can take some getting used to.  At this point on the timeline, I would say this is a good buy for those looking to play something unfinished but worth their time.

My only complaint is how demanding planets are.  I'm sure they'll optimize in the near future, but it's absultely insane how demanding it is.  I have an i7 4790 and a gtx 960 with 8gb of RAM and I STILL can barely run it at medium settings.  Do I recommend this game?  Yes.  BUT, only to people with good enough computers and how enjoy being creative.

We shall be victorious!"One lunged at Two, he took the gun from Two and shot him. There was only one Cosmonaut now.He looked at the course set by his comrade. It was too late. content:
Posted: April 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								After I got sick of minecraft, I started looking for a replacement. I bought space engineers a long LONG time ago but never had the ability to play it due to potato PC's. A little later I got a new HP Envy, still was a potoato to run this game. So still was never able to play it. Ever since planets came out made me feel left out because of my PC. I still never touched the game though. After a recent update I decided to give it a try and see what I can get out of it, well since they added the option to turn off shadows really helped! I ran the game on the lowest settings possible, lowered the resolution to the minimum that looked best, not enough to mishape things, still even with the screen. and well I was able to play away!I managed to get a fast smooth framerate with a Intel HD 4600 GPU!! I would build cool things after I did the tutorial, and would build from little rovers to space stations! I would ask my sister who was very addicted to minecraft: "Can you do this in minecraft?!" maybe with all the redstone stuff but would be very bulky.I don't know why people complain about running this game on beast PC's on low settings and would only get around 10 to 5 fps. I managed to get this game running nice and smooth on a potato! (this is all including planets) Now people do say that this game is minecraft in space. Well that is accurate. Building is similar to minecraft, but more complex. Minecraft is everything blocks. Blocky world too. Space engineers has blocks to smooth out your creations to make them NOT so blocky. The planets are more planet-ish also!This game has a high learning curve too. Which I'm sure people don't like, but I do! I like to learn how to play complex games like this. Feels really fun and challenging at the same time! After you build some pretty rad things in this game. You'll never complain about your house being griefed on minecraft agiain! :)The only thing I don't like about this game is that there is not too much to do here. Besides building ships and bases and well stuff like that. Thats why I set my own objectives to reach a certain planet or moon.I also hear that multiplayer is really buggy. Well I can't say anything about that because I'm more of a anti-social person, so I NEVER play multiplayer. (Unless with a friend)I also never seemed to encounter much bugs with this game also. (In singleplayer of course) The only bug I have encountered is the gamma or contrast messing up when the game auto saves. (The screen would be really bright or really dark)Now all I have to say is if you buy this game after reading my review. Keep your expectations low. This is just my expirience with this game and I can't guarentee anything to anyone else.Thanks for reading this rambling review! It may not prove usefull but It will get my word out!Thanks again! :)

number of helpful: 11 of 14 people (79%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								Simply amazing, and with the magnitude of updates that comes in each week; with tutorial videos to go along. Just buy it already! Multiplayer is fun, building is a dream with control interfaces that most games wish they had. The sheer number of items, blocks and designs you can create is staggering! It also has a very nice XYZ mirroring features, copy and paste - real-time of ships and objects. Offensive weapons! Such detailed and rich environment and object / ship damage. Build big, build small, build a station to house them all! Gravity, Mass, Velocity, etc all apply here and it makes for some great physics fun! With gravity generators, you can make any direction and adjustable field sizing for direct gravity on objects and players. Lighting / shaders are top notch, and the effects you can experience are background / image potential for sure.It is well worth the money for this, and if you ever want to build together - just shoot me a message!*This game has only gotten 10x better since my review back in Febuary - customization and amount of addons and changes is too numerous to begin to tell you - the videos on the Store page don't do justice - they are mostly old. Just look up the weekly dev blog that in-depth explains the newest features and keys to get a better feel at current state. The MP is solid and full on space battles are just about seamless. Wonderful are the latest changes to make ships and stations interchangable with docking ports, and now conveyor systems for item transfers, passenger seating, color scheme on everything is RGB / Hue / Sat customized, Turrets both interior and exterior, artificial mass blocks and gravity generator modifications. I could go on and on, or you could just check out their weekly videos since release. The real-time damage system is SOOO great, and detailed. There is something for everyone - whether you are into pitting two dogfighters at each other and record it, hundred people in your own spaceport RP system, or simply want to solo design an epic space station in the side of an asteroid you blew a chunk out of. IF YOU ARE ON THE FENCE AT ALL ABOUT THIS GAME, BUY IT! You will not be sorry.

number of helpful: 21 of 33 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								First off, I'd like to start out by saying that after I originally wasted nearly 26 bucks on minecraft (DO NOT BUY THAT GAME), I bought this game for just under 20 (should have bought when half off) and I got to say that "awesome" is the grandest of all understatement on a way to describe this game.  This game doesn't come without its early game problems though, which i have serveral ideas.1. You can't build road vehicles (disregard, it has been pointed out to me that artificial mass gives gravity to road vehicles)Though you have wheels and suspension, you can't really build a small vehicles because they end up floating away, not that you need small road vehicles considering the concept of the game, but the wheels should be pulled down by gravity like the player is, otherwise, like i said before, it'll float away, i'm not sure why wheels exist in this game as of now, but adding gravity affect to wheels, and steering assemblies wouldn't hurt, it would really be as much usefull as much as it would be novelty, unless you have a REALLY large ship, which is what i'm working on, there will be a core of the ship because you'll need a vehicle to get to and from really fast.2. Server lag.I feel that the multiplayer servers and the way everything is handled when sharing maps could be done more efficiently, so much lag and is very network intensive, i work with networking and computers and the way everything network in this game is being handled, is not doing so very efficiently, i'd have people join my maps, complain about the extreme lag, and leave, like clockwork.3. Some of the cubes are limited.For example, on large ships you can only place large cubes, and for small ships, you can only place small cubes.  When you are configuring your toolbar, there is a category for large cubes, and a category for small cubes, they aren't really large or small, the size of your cube is completely dependent on the type of ship you're building, so the "small cube" "large cube" categories are somewhat confusing, i think it could have been thought out a little better.  Another note on the cubes are the passage way cubes, i forget exactly what they're called, but there are only strait peices, no T or L or + peices, so you kind of have to figure a sollution to make that cube work.There are a few little things that bug me, but not enough to state them here, and yes, i am aware it is still an early access game, the 3 ones that i posted above were problems to me that i felt needed to be pointed out, overall, the game is super awesome and i would recommend this game 3 times over plus another time, definitely the best $20 i've ever spent thus far.  Another thing i'd like to note is that it's also not as processor intensive i though it would be, as of now (12-11-2014), i have a pentium G630 on an asus p8h77-v and 3.5gigs of ram (32 bit OS) and a geforce 9800gt.  The graphics card does become quite the convection oven though during gameplay it goes up to around 210 - 220 farhenheit, and that fan gets LOUD, if i didn't have the cooling i did, it would probably already be dead, it's minorly concerning, i have a second 9800gt that i might put into an sli but with only a 430psu, it would concern me.

								Don't buy it!  This game is not ready for consumption and has not gotten any closer in the two years I've owned it already.  In fact its even further from being ready than when I bought it. The idea of the game is great and if it actually worked it might be fun, but it doesn't.  ITS FULL OF GAME BREAKING PHYSICS BUGS.For instance:I build a structure with 4 landing gears on top of my station on a planet on it and engage their locks.  While I am grinding I accidentally grind out the block under one landing gear, so I try to put it back.  Placing a block back under the landing gear causes the whole thing to launch into the air and tumble over sideways, despite the fact that there were 3 landing gears locking it down to the ground.I am attacked by cyberhounds so I jump up on my platform and shoot them.  They fall over dead then disappear under the ground where I cannot loot them.I build a car and try to drive it.  The ground is ridiculously rough despite looking smooth.  My car flips over.  I spend time building some pistons and rotors to jack the vehicle up and flip it back over.  I try to walk in next to my vehicle with my welder to repair it.  I walk between the two tires and my vehicle suddenly flies like 100 feet into the air and crashes into pieces.

More puns? Shoo, nobody likes it when you project your wants unto them.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								Honestly? THE best early access game i have ever bought. The developers listen to feedback from players e.g. Solar Panels and then later on Rechargable battery packs. It's easiest to describe this game as "Minecraft in space" but that doesnt cover it. Minecraft is about setting up a sustainable base and then eventually defeating the Ender-Dragon or in creative mode seeing what you can build using cubes of various materials. Space Engineers is about seeing what you can create using nothing but the resources dug and refined from nearby asteroids, making them into various parts for assembly and then constructing anything from makeshift cars to fighter ships all the way up to an Eldar Craftworld (although that will lag a LOT its Early access.. c'mon what would you expect?) The only limit in Space Engineers is your imagination. With an active community that uploads items onto the workshop on a daily basis you can never run out of inspiration or other ships to test your latest deadly weapon or attack vessle against. Apart from the occasional lag issues when your world starts to fill up with failed experiments/enormous ships/enormous space station/ thousands of your corpses cause you failed to recharge your suit in time, this genuinely feels like a finished product. Except it isn't. With updates coming every week on a Thursday with simple things like Bug fixes or (more often than not) completely new content this is an enjoyable, constantly in motion game for all the family... Well maybe not, I wouldn't invite little Cousin Jimmy into your world for him to then fly around blowing your beautiful constructs up because he figured out how to make warheads and "The boom noise is too funny!" Damnit Jimmy... Anyway at £14.99 its difficult to say no to this game. Unless you hate sandbox construction games in which case go back to CoD or Battlefield or whatever it is you popular people play these days.

Early Access Review
								tl;dr 12/10Never compare this game to any other early access product. This is something beyond the - A list of features is growing continiously. Every feature is not just a feature to mentoin, but a thing YOU will use.- Sandboxiest sandbox. Create space stations, large and small ships. Become an artist, a designer and an engineer.- Computer systems of the future. Every block that have computer component in it will fight on your side until destroyed, unpowered or hacked. Create a defense system that will kill anyone trying to sneak into your base, while keeping your base open to your friends and their ships.Create manned, automated remote-controlled systems.- Every block count. Everything you see is not a decoration, but a fully working part of system.- Survival. Mine asteroids, explore space and survive meteor storms.- More and more things to tell- Limitless amount of situations and space traffic accidents.- More cool things coming! Upgrade your old ships with brand new blocks from new updates.Also you could try Miner Wars 2081 - not a best game, but it shares the same spirit with space engineers.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								With only 50 hours in this game, I'll base my review on what I've learned so far.Build StationsBuild ShipsLoose ship cuz you didn't realize it needed to be stuck to Landing Gear while buildingCreate weird and complex structuresDie cuz you forgot to recharge energyTake your first flight, loose the ship cuz you forgot thrusters somewhereRedesign your ship to get more weird things on.Make your first LARGE shipStart dreaming of controlling your own Serenity, Enterprise or an Klingon Battlecruiser.Play around with Rotors, Pistons, commmand blocks and more to make it even cooler....Watch the tutorials :D .. The first hour I spend not understanding what to do at all! As the super tech guy I am ( I thought ) .. This was no prob to play. .. untill I actually started it. Back on the tutorials to get the basic, then on youtube to watch some tips and tricks, and now ... now the game is just awsome. I'm trying out new ways to build ships, trying my best to make copies of ships like X-Wing, Serenity and more. Building a space station, and just make it bigger .. more complex way to utilize the station .. just to see where it takes me .. I love every aspect of it.It does have bugs .. all games do .. This is an Early Alpha .. remember this.The bugs that are in Creative mode is  more as small hickups .. the funny glitch when you mine something, and suddenly you see through the whole asteriode for a second, then return to the mining again .. can be weird, fun and annoying .. all at once :DIn survival mode I've had one bigger issue .. and it was that my miningship sometimes just broke during flight .. or lost a container or reactor .. once I lost 5 thrusters ... but ... even as annoying this is, I recommend NOT using the autosave .. but rather save at your own so you can get back and redo if you crash or loose something due to a glitch.I have only a few hours in multiplayer, so I will not comment much regarding this. The little I've played have been flawless. I would believe that some of the survival mode glitches might appear in MP survival aswell..Pros:Total freedom in what you want to build, where to go, what to do.Grahpics are pretty good. Lots and lots better than minecraft.. ( I know .. stop comparing it lol )Lots and lots of mods to play around with.You can have a singleplayer survival or creative mode save, and turn it into a LAN/MP world if wanted.Devs are doing weekly updates, from new items/armor and more, to bugfixes and optmizing.Cons:You get thrown into space, not much help there. ( unless you watch tutorials and youtube )Glitches and bugs, but this is a part for ALL games...Unless you KNOW what an item does, there's no helpscreen about the item. ( example: you have rotor, but unless you know what to do, you won't get it to work right... )But!!! All in all. .. I'm very happy I got this game gifted to me. So far I have enjoyed my 50 hours into the game, an I know I will enjoy atleast the next 100 hours. Unless I have figured out how to use ALL things ingame, I will keep playing and playing.I've already made a 10 player dedi server for me and my friends to play on :D10/10Go get it :D

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								Space Lag…One man dev team can do better, it’s called Starmade.  Get it, its cheaper, and better.I like so many others, want to like this game.  I've played off and on for quite some time now, waiting for things to be fixed.  Great idea if the game would run right.  Dev's release new gimmicks all the time, cool features even, if it worked.  Multiplayer?  Not really.  False advertising there... multiplayer is super broken.Many years, much money, and problems this game had at its start are still present.  It looks like a polished game, it's not.  The bugs in this game have prevented me from buying their other one, midevil engineers.  I was worried when they started that project that they were dumping Space Engineers.  It seems devs are working on both with equal incompetence.DEVS - Stop releasing gimmicks to sell the game and fix the existing game!  PLAYERS - Everyone needs to start posting negative reviews on this game at regular intervals to bring its rating down so it stops selling.  Maybe they will abandon it, maybe they will fix it.  If they stop selling the game, perhaps it will encourage them to do something about the bugs and the total neglect of optimisation. Would be a great game if it would run on something less than a university super computer and things didn't randomly explode around you.

Early Access Review
								~Updated 07 JAN 2017~To be honest, I don't really enjoy this game anymore.  I had hope that it would grow into something with the popularity of Minecraft, where communities would form and different playstyles would flourish.  The progress is slow and it feels like they break as many things as they improve half the time.  I still stand by recommending it as it's is loads of fun, IF you're into these sorts of games.  It's just that there are other offerings (that I will not name here) out there that are a bit more polished as far as space simulation/exploration go as well as survival crafting.  The fact that they were able to put the two together in such a way and not have it all crash and burn is very impressive.  So yes, still a recommendation, but only if you're interested already.  I can't solidly try to sell you on this game.  Good luck!~Original~Simple, Intriguing, Thought Provoking.What a delightful experience.  People refer this game to those who like Minecraft, but there really is something in it for everyone.  From ship design, to base design, to dabbling with engineering and physics; this game is looking to be the next big thing.  Note: Best played with friends.  Oodles of fun.Recommendation:  Pick up a 4-Pack and share it with friends.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								SpEn has a lot to it. It's an amazing world with absolute player's freedom of activities. I remember thousands great in-game moments, where I was having fun with friends. SpEn could be my most favourite game for the whole my lifetime, but...But gameplay development isn't thought out. KSH introduces what seems the most fun and arcade for them. Once upon the time they even introduced randomly spawning and exploding dogs, with no backthought of, for example, instead using coders for redesigning communications to be more comfortable and fun to play with, or implementing just a simple volumetric map.Then multiplayer, the reason of this game should be even played, experiencing hundreads of different player-made environments with old- and new-made friends, it's completely dead. The whole netcode, server and data management were randomly put up together, occasionly breaking down and falling apart with whole dedicated servers almost every weak, even though those servers are being hosted sometimes on huge mainframes.And physics. Oh... Those were crashing, exploding, lagging out, torning apart thousands and thousands of my ships, I've been working on for many weeks, for all these 3 years. Pulling run out of power ships against the gravity from ground to the stratosphere, insta-killing my characters million times, who just stepped in the wrong time in the wrong place, breaking out of sync - those are just dumb ways to die.The most fun part is that, devs say, they are fixing physics and multiplayer, that they are making a progress. Well, I believed them for the last 3 years until now. And now I'm just too tired to continue holding on these hopings.I saw felt so far no code improvements or reworks even by a tiny bit for the last year. Every single 'fix' of every single older bug just pops out bunch of newer bugs. It's the product of coder's lazyness to go deeper in their own code, I suppose. I'm not kidding, coding proccess is really awful. Sometimes I even think, coders put bugs in on purpose, to just fix them later, for the work proccess imitation.Why is it so? Well, my guess is, teamwork has became hulking. KSH grown out in a bigger studio, but it's leading style stayed as small-team one, which is unable to control or monitor coding forces with required flexibility.It feels painful to give it thumbs down for the game with this variety of features, because they are ruined for the comfortability of players experience by some primitive management issues.

number of helpful: 18 of 28 people (64%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								Edit 7 April 2016: Went back last week and started a new SE game after throughly enjoying Empryion Galactic Survival (big thumbs up for EGS!) the last couple months. Space Engineers hasn't changed. Still broken; pistons, wheels, power 'grid' still broken, etc. Hand mining after Empryion's much better system is incredibly bad in SE. Very very short interaction distance means lots of grief/frustration and due to still broken 'moveable bits' like wheels & pistons, trying to make a working mining truck is hopeless. NPC/PvE is -so- much better in Empryion! SE's idea of PvE on starting 'Earth' are jihadist exploding 'dogs' that would make Isis seem like a sweet old grandmother. Pointlessly OPed. Still have to "engineer -around- the game" not -with- the game. Some simple things that Empryion got right and SE devs seem too depressed to even consider; EGS uses Hovercraft instead of wheeled starter vehicles (hovers work great in EGS), Empryion has elevator blocks to get up & down (and they work when un-powered!) SE just has ramps. EGS starting survival is very nicely balanced with well done Hunger/Health/Oxygen systems, and NPCs -add- to immersion & are useful to boot.Bottom line: I can easily recommend Empryion at full price but can't bring myself to recommend SE even at this weekends sale price of $7.49.--Original review--To be fair there is a lot to like about Space Engineers.  But the 'engineering' part leaves an awful lot to be desired.The game in general is 'box' based, similar to Minecraft, though natural parts aren't restricted to cubism & landscapes on moons & planets is very nice.  My main dislike is the lack of things like hinges, winches, cables, etc.  Basically the only moving blocks are a piston and a rotor.  Pistons have basically been broken since I bought the game in Feburary.Oh, almost forgot wheels.  arrr, maybe I should have.  Wheels, well they'll just drive you nuts.  Especially in a gravity field like a world.  Their behaviour isn't even close to what you'd expect & never has been.  Which leaves me repeatedly trying to 'engineer' around the game, not -with- the game, and that's not only silly, but non-rewarding as well.  So I've learned to not use pistons or wheels, and only very carefully (and not on ships, only bases) to use rotors.They're not cruising with the game, they've added many significant & large features since Feb, like oxygen, hydrogen and new thrusters for H, also Planets, some with cool alien spiders, and just today Cyberhounds to attack you on Earth (which, "you won't be able to turn off for a few days" a forced "Test this!" I'm not happy about).It's their game & they decide what & when to implement; I get that.  It's Alpha, so not everything works & things will change.  Got it.  Reason for my thumbs down is I'm free to desire a real engineering challenge, which I don't get with the game as it is.  Yes, I've had some fun, but hours played on my profile don't reflect at the keyboard time.  You need to mine then refine ores to then make components, then put those together to make blocks.  Refining takes quite a while and at least half my 'played' hours were simply me leaving game running all night, refining.Now -design- challenges?  Sure.  There are enough different blocks to make some astonishing ships.  And they fly in space!  Just bear in mind that you can't make a simple hoist that will hook a cable to a crate and move it.  Yes, you can make a rigid arm, use a landing gear to magnetically lock onto a block and then move that, but any pistons you use are likely to explode on next game load if left under pressure.There are many many mods for the game, someone even made a hinge that folks swear by.  But I only play vanilla, and that's what I'm reviewing.I really do hope that one day the game will have solid working movable bits like gears and jacks and cable hoists cause I really need an elevator to get 400m down to the valley floor from my hillside retreat.  As soon as they do (if I'm still around) I'll happily change to a thumbs up.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game was a revolutionary concept back in 2014, and even now it is a pioneering project in the game industry, with full voxel based sandbox system in space with high detail graphics, planets, asterodis, mining, industry building, mechanic systems etc.Unfortunately it became too big for the developers to finish as a quality game, and the underlying multiplayer concept is not working, it is too late to move to a professional netcode like raknet. This implies, that the concept of faction based, persistent, multiplayer game with lots of players (30+) will never be realised, which makes the game a pointless, unfinished sandbox. It can be considered as an abandonware, stuck in early access, with constant pretense as being fixed, while underlying fundamnetal problems never get fixed.

Early Access Review
								Although many people say this game is broken, and it is, this is still a diamond of Sandbox games in the Steam Store rough. And although it's such a highly detailed game KSH still finds time to update this and their other game Medieval Engineers every week, always adding something new and fixing problems, I orginally tried the game a long time ago during it's free weekend, and when it was over I vowed that someday I would get it, and I did, and it is even more fun every time I play it. The only thing I hope they add is maybe some more innovative weapons and tools, but that's just my oppinion.

number of helpful: 13 of 19 people (68%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 1
Early Access Review
								I've been having a real blast with this one. The level of customization is pretty awesome. You build all of your ships and bases from scratch, peice by peice, and they are simulated with physics. Amazing work.There are now planets with stuff living on 'em, too, which is pretty cool. Flight controls are very nice, and you can turn off your inertial dampers at any time for vectored flight.The enemies are pretty simple. This is more about creating than surviving (though you do need oxygen and power). Hope there's an upgrade to the PvE element later on.Awesome setting fine-tuning. Create exactly the sort of map you want to play on.Programmable blocks! Ok, yes, the API is kinda (very) clunky and unintuitive. Also the documentation (or lack there-of) is shameful. But it's early access, so I put that down to something that'll get worked out over time. The important thing is that you can actually program your creations to do anything you want. It's a mind-blowing level of customization. And it uses a limited set of standard C# - you don't have to learn some niche language to use 'em. Of course, you can just download scripts in the workshop, too ;o)Anyway, lots and lots of thumbs up on this one. Great game.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								Updates come out every thursday evening like clockwork, and each week makes the game better.What with planets and DX11 in the pipeline this game is promising to be something truly amazing.I can understand that a lot of people have trust issues with alpha releases and developers, but the guys at KSH really have done a stellar job, and have kept up a consistently good job for nigh on two good years with this game, it has got to the point now where, if they promise something, I trust them to stick to it.However, it is very important that when people buy this they remember that this is still alpha, and as a result optimisation in both single and multiplayer has not been tackled yet, and hence larger online servers are rather unstable and filled with many occurences of rubberbanding, or lag, although with a complete re-write of multiplayer on the way I can see these issues soon being a thing of the past. I see buying into this game not for it's playability factor now, but as an investment. Even so at it's current stage the game is more than worth the money they ask, with basically infinite creative possibilities single player is fun and can eat hundreds of hours into building things that look really great, and in multiplayer small 'race to eliminate the other team' competitive servers with a few friends are one of the most fun experiences I've actually had with a game.All in all, even if you don't feel like its an amazing game now, (which it is by all means) check back every now on then on the KSH forums, see what they've added, see what's on it's way, because this game really does get better every week.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								I will start out by saying i have spent an extensive amount of time in this game and have loved nearly every hour of it. Those that need structure and plot to guide you through a game this game wont be for you,  it is truely open free-form gameplay.  anyone who loves sandbox play however will get lots of enjoyment out of this im betting.  There are limitations on this game like any alpha stage early access game.  Im going to try and cover some of the pros and cons of this game in its current state.  The Cons:: Audio issues,  multiplayer sync issues but still very playable,  a lack of direction or set goals can be frustrating to some,  no obvious "enemy"  to work against/attack/defend against, not optimized graphically yet,  game breaking bugs do exist but none that cant be worked around ussually.  You can expect a distinct lack of "polish" being an alpha so just make sure you look at it in the view that this game is /not/ finished so keep that in mind when a frustrating issue pops up. The Pros:: Price! (14.99),  FREQUENT updates (every thursday it recieves content updates with new fixes,  blocks,  game mechanics), very active community modding support via workshop,  multiplayer host shares mods with anyone joining so people without your mods can still come and go easily.  Survival and Creative modes are distinct and each offer their own entertainment values offering freebuilding or resource gathering and piracy of npc ships, support for pvp via factions and ownership privileges that allows you to form a team of other players to fight with/against, intuitive controls,  nearly limitless building options! If you can dream it you can build it in this game..  from a giant carrier to little mining pods,  stations to sprawling solar farms. The pros outweight the cons i promise,  this game is very highly recomended to anyone who loves sandbox building,  or playing with legos lol.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game has huge potential, which I'm fairly confident at this point, it will never meet.  If the game performed and worked as intented, it would be one of the best games I have ever played, but it doesn't, and I'm failry certain it never will.I just went back to the game after shelving it for about 10 months, with some hope that things would have at least improved somewhat.  In about 20-30 minutes of play time, I ran into about a half dozen extremely frustrating bugs while playing on a private dedicated server.  The thing is, most of the issues I ran into are for the most part the same issues the game had when I first played it 2 years ago, the ones that haven't been around that long have still been around for many months without fixes.  These devs just don't seem capable of fixing things.  They haven't been able to get basic gameplay systems and mechanics to any sort of stable state.  I expect a game in early access to have bugs, but I also expect the devs to work on fixing them and at least make some progress.A game like this really shines in multi-player, and gets old really quickly while playing it by yourself.  If I only played single player, I could probably avoid some of the issues I ran into, but it would be a medocre gameplay experience at best while playing by myself.Edit:  The most furstrating part about this game has been watching week by week, and month after month as "Improvements and Bugfixes" patches are released, yet all the same substantial issues still exist that where there one or two years ago.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is magnificent. With weekly updates and a development team that really cares about what the players want, few can compare.A short list of things you can do:=========================* Build a space fairing bohemoth of a vessel to explore the universe.* Build space stations to replicate any sci-fi metropolis of your dreams.* Build a small ship that can even take a family of 4. (But you don't have one... because you're in space...)* Become the CEO of a space mining conglomerate with a legion of AI programmable drones at your disposal (Once you've built them of course).* Have a soul searching journey into the depths of space. (Hans Zimmer track not included)* Colonise an asteroid* Colonise a moon* Colonise a Planet!* Have a bundu bash on said moon or planet. (Seriously these things are huge! Planets have an average diameter of 120 km.)* Build a fort and protect it against invading AI like pirates or sabiroids.* Enjoy the vistas of these different worlds* Settle down on your favorite space rock.* Make a weapon using gravity generators and artificial mass blocks.* Play multiplayer with your friends so you can build, explore, raid and fight pirates together.* Go on servers and enjoy the different game setups available.* Torment your friends with the gravity weapon you made.* Lose your friends...* And find them again using a well built communication relay. (Once you've built that as well)* Just kidding I still haven't found them, I just like to fly around in my intergalactic space ship (I designed it myself. Let me show some of the different lengths of wire I used.)* Write a review to praise it's ingenuity. (Just like I did right now, yay)This isn't for the faint-of-hearted when it comes to sandbox games though, but the final payoff with any project is always awe-inspiring.Also with the addition of planets as well as other goodies like a thriving modding community, you can customize your game according to your taste.This game isn't a virtual world, it's a virtual universe!Honestly, buy this game, get your friends to buy it too. Space sure is quiet without a familiar voice.If I could give a numeric score it would be the same as the possibilities this game possesses:∞/∞ (Apply L'Hospital... or not)TL;DR - This game is REALLY great, buy it.

number of helpful: 22 of 37 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								 As of this writing, no. It's a glorified tech demo. A very well done tech demo, but nothing more. If you think I'm being harsh, let me explain. First of all, there's very little to actually do. Planets are an unfinished, glitchy feature with lots of half-baked ideas shoved into them. Ship to ship combat is... There, but there's no real point to it. There's no auto-repair systems and the structure of your ship is tinfoil, so unless you're fighting in creative (You know, being a child smashing his toys together) you'll spend maybe a minute trying to shred an enemy and the next two hours patching holes in your hull and replacing damaged equipment. True, there is survival, and early game survival is fun, but sooner or later one of two things will happen. If you're playing with the enemies disabled, you will struggle to find power and oxygen. Resource managment is gonna be difficult. A minor mistake in piloting a mining ship will cost you dearly. It's actually pretty tense and you'll have to think about how to survive... But then you'll tip. You'll build a bigger base, then a bigger ship, and you'll feel accomplished. Then you'll upscale again. Then again. Then again. Resources are no longer an issue, so it now becomes a case study in how much of a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥welding every single hull plate of a capital ship can be. If you're brave enough to play with enemies on, you will die. The resources required to make even small arms ammunition are scarce. Very scarce. Every time I've ever played I built building-sized mining vessels before I had bullets for my rifle. That might actually be an interesting choice if the enemies appeared when you met some abitrary condition, but they don't. If you're in space, a big Argevantis cruiser is gonna show up and raze everything you spent hours building because there's no way you can adequately defend yourself against it. If you're on planets, have fun, because space spiders and cyberhounds are going to rip you a new ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ as soon as you land. "But I'll join a cooperative ser-" No you won't. In a game as horifically glitchy as this, you won't play with more than 2 or 3 friends at a time. Physics has always been SEs biggest failing, and though they've made major strides there's still a very long way to go. Even if you could find one, there's no asset protection outside of a big gun. If you didn't play for 3 weeks with no sleep and build a deathstar, someone is going to come along and take everything from you. While I'm thinking of Physics, Spacecraft design is all art and no science. If you've played KSP, Robocraft, Gmod, or any similar games, you know the challenge of balacing your CoM and CoT. You know that long ships have high rotational inertia, but thrusters mounted further from your center of mass generate more torque. There's a million different engineering tradeoffs you can explore. Space engineers has... None of this. Rotation is handled exclusively by gyros, so even if you try to build manuvering thrusters they will do nothing. The physics engine simply cannot comprehend that applying thrust on unbalanced vectors will impart a rotation. The only engineering challenge you face is "But how much of this crap can I cram onto a ship?" That and how much of your ship to dedicate to solid blocks of metal to absorb incoming fire. Above all else, the Dev team seem to has no idea what to do. They go with the fist draft of an idea and almost never look back. Sometimes they get an idea right, like with Hydrogen thrusters. Thrusters that need fuel instead of power were a long requested feature, and people were happy when they were released. I was too, because I figured I could use them to make smaller and lighter ships - surely a fuel tank and a few thrusters is lighter than a big heavy nuclear reactor. Well, we were happy until we found out even sparing use of thrusters drained their fuel reserves in mere seconds. They had much better thrust, but at mindbendingly low effeciency. So low, in fact, that Keen immediately patched them to something more reasonable. They're still stupidly ineffecient - a Mercury/Redstone rocket from the 50s has preformance far superior to anything ingame - but at least you could fly for a minute or two instead of 15 seconds. Cyberhounds are the exact opposite end of the spectrum. Nobody wanted self-destructing bomb dogs that bring death and ruination upon any planetary base, but we got them. I could rant like this all day, so here's one final point. It's just not a very pretty game. Starmade might be basic but its graphics are far more polished. It does a very, very good job with what it has. Space Engineers has a DX11 powered rendering engine with 1999 level texturing and modeling work. Hell, Shores of Hazeron and Homeworld 1 more visually pleasing than this. Don't buy this game. Not now, anyway. It has a very, very long way to go and you're only gonna burn yourself out on an incomplete product. Maybe in six months they'll have addressed all these issues.

number of helpful: 22 of 37 people (59%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								My rule is never buy early access games. Only exception is beta versions. Its kind of like flushing your loved ones down the toilet. Yes, I was talking about money. Well, i blame steam sales. Actually, never buy early access games, unless steam sales, and pricing under 10 bucks.After barely five hours......Like most people here, I really like what i see. Even though some may find it tideous, the game makes you WANT to build and explore. And with the co-op with friends or anyone, it makes up for a rather exciting game. If this game also get a broader and more intriguing npc factions, wildlife with both grass eaters and predators, heck maybe even fishes....it could become a great game indeed. It certainly have potential. Forget then about all those silly zombie survival games that also never vill be finished....There seems to be huge graphichs issues with this game. At 1920 x 1080, with a Radeon HD 7870, I have to put everything to low, to have liveable framerates. Says a lot about this game, considering its not exactely high fiedlity in graphics. As a comparison, Battlefield 4 plays with everything on high at 2560 x 1440 or something like that. Also there seem to be a bug with saving game? Game only saved when i use "Save as". Like most early access games, I wouldnt exactely bet on them to finish it. But atleast I hope they iron out excisting bugs.I recomend this game if you dont mind to flush you loved ones down the toilet. Or if its on steam sales for max 10 bucks. Else, like always, dont waste money.

content:

Early Access Review
								Space Engineers is decent if you want to get creative by building ships or pass the time by mining resources, but it has numerous fallthroughs that will likely never be worked on. The game doesn't come together in the way that it should. Animations are clunky, optimization and perfmormance are pretty bad, glitches are very common, and the game structure itself isn't anywhere near user-friendly.This game cannot be defended by claiming that it's early access. The devs have had plenty of time to polish the weaker aspects of the game, yet seem to lack the insight or skill to address and solve these issues. Instead, their ambition as game developers pushes them to mash in more half-functioning or barely relevant content, which often overcomplicates the game and adds numerous bugs. Keen Software House has bit off more than they can chew, and it shows when they try to conquer something like planets and AI. The "monsters" are of absolute amateur quality, the planet rendering is atrocious, and everything comes off as awkward. The world design is horrific, in my opinion. The aesthetics of the planets are very out of place, not to mention the overbearing lack of purpose. The game suffers from what many open world games like this do, and that is the extreme lack of feeling like there's anything the player actually -has- to do. TL;DR The game feels empty. It's nice for the first few hours, but the dark underbelly of Space Engineers reveals that it is simply a hollow, awkwardly assembled shell of an amazing idea. I would not recommend it.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								Stay far away unless you are content to build alone in creative mode only.I purchased this game June 2014.  As of this writing, that was 1 1/2 years ago.  The game is so bugged now that I cannot even stomach launching it any more.  Let me explain..I have a deep love for the concept and great hope that KSH can pull this game together.  When I first purchased it, I played solo survival for a month and had a blast.  I then moved on to survival multiplayer PvP and had some of the most thrilling fulfilling gameplay of any game ever.  I made a dozen new friends, had factions and teams.. what a truly wonderful time.But as time progressed, the Thursday patches became less of a anticipated feature gift and more of plea not to kill the game with crushing bugs.  After 6 months of almost completely killing the multiplayer community, the remaing few of us left in abject sorrow.  We could no longer play the game we loved so much.2015 came and went with dozens upon dozens of new features.  Great for the solo creative crowd, and kudos to KSH for keeping such a brisk pace.  But as 2015 closes, multiplayer is still unplayable.  The few server owners cry on the KSH forum for help just keeping their servers from crashing after 30 minutes.  A whole year and zero progress on MP.I will absolutely return to this game if KSH ever gets MP working.  Until then, it is in the "what could have been" category. And I will absolutely never ever purchase another Early Access game.  Developers have no incentive to ever finish the game, release it, and be accountable for its performance.

content:

Early Access Review
								Probably the best sandbox game I have ever played.  Space Engineers is realistic on almost every level. The graphics, the physics, the construction and of course the collisions, have just the right amount of reallity that creates an amazing experience.  Updates are another great thing, new content is added every week for just about as long as the game has been around and they seem like they are focused on the requests of the players. But of course, the game has its drawbacks, exploration is pointless, there is asolutley nothing other than a handful of static asteriods in the center of the map and thats about it. Also there is the classic "whats the point?" feeling that sanbox games generally have, which leads to a pretty boring single player.   However I definitly recommend this game, even if you only play on single player.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								Space Engineers is not minecraft in space. Ok so now that we have that out of they way, Space Engineers is a great game if you want to create ships with guns and blow stuff up. In its current state the multiplayer is playable but sometimes abit buggy, but that is to be expected from an alpha state. The game offers two modes, Creative and Survival. In creative mode you can build what ever you want with no need to collect resources, this is good if you just want to build some wonderfull ships. The Survival mode is just what its name suggests, unlike Creative mode you have to actually mine resources to build parts in this mode. In my personal opinion Survival mode is best played with friends as playing it alone can become boring very fast, but with friends it is very enjoyable and fun. The game is updated every Thursday which is nice as it is something to look forward to. In final review I would give this game in its current state a 8.9/10, it would have been a 10 if not for some multiplayer problems, but as I said the game is updated regually so prehaps these issues will be fixed soon.I hope this review was helpfull.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								In its Alpha stages the game is already cool for a few hours, but can get boring rather fast because there is not much to do yet in my opinion. It requires some patience due to its Early Access business model. It has a great deal of potential at being a nemesis to Minecraft for space exploration with better graphics, but will seemingly require a great deal of work to reach that status. You have multiple scenarios at your disposal, but in each, it is basically the same at the moment; you need to find Uranium as fast as you can while at the same time save your given energy in the games various styles of survival beginnings.There is a multiplayer mode that is not yet in the condition it should be but it is getting there slowly but surely. Things take time, of course. Dedicated servers seem to be a step for the developers in the near future so players can build huge things with their friends...and destroy them.A decently high computer is required. Mine is sort of lower mid range at the moment and there are some graphical bugs due to that and presently multiplayer seems to me impossible to play. Like I said though, if you are a player who enjoys going out and gathering resource to build a huge space station or some ships to your exact liking with not-so-many-yet building parts yet then this is a game for you. I can't wait until it has AI to fight off however, and a faster way of moving the high amount of resources you mine from asteroids into processing and storage. It has weapons and blocks designed for item transport but it isn't finished yet due to, again, the Early Access model. It's still an Alpha build and for that, is damn good already.In the end, a game with a great deal of potential. If you enjoy idea of "survival in space" then this is for you for sure.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is insanely big in it's concept. Almost anything you can think of is right here in this game regarding space. Space ships? Check. Travel between planets or around planets? Check. Work in space? Check. Build space stations, ships (from attack ships to resource ships)? Check. An intricate power supply system or conveyor belts with control panels? Check. Loads of tools to work and craft with? Check. This game can be lotus for the space fans.Space Engineers gameplay is pretty decent at the moment. The movement and frame rate is smooth but some major lag can appear in certain servers if you're playing online. All essential movements are here from sprinting, jumping and crouching. Additional features include the ability to turn off inertial dampeners, a flashlight and activate a jet pack which allows the player to move freely in all three axis. The jet pack doesn't use any fuel at the moment unless you're playing in a certain mode. Either way, I like having the ability to move around and craft without worrying if I can get to the top of the structure. The player may also zoom in the camera as they please and may even play in first person mode. Smaller ships are piloted in first person mode while larger ships are only seen from 3rd person (as you will move about in larger ships). Ships are also equipped with a flash-light ability by pressing L.Building is relatively simple in game but can take a bit of time to properly master and get what you want. The basic building unit in Space Engineers is blocks. Blocks can be cosmetically small, large, rounded and edged. The player doesn't simply build blocks and then have a ship. Power supplies (that come in blocks), doors, antennas, cockpit, connectors, control panels, conveyors, windows, seats and even guns can be added. The player will need to build a power supply for any vehicle or air unit they plan to build. Engineers can also build ground units and stations using any combination of block they please. Power is transferred through blocks once they are touching so there isn't a need to become an electrician and run wire. Some useful key shortcuts are ctrl+p (to pick a color), shift+p (to set a color to selected block), ctrl+mouse1 (hold) to place multiple blocks in a straight line and ctrl+shift+mouse1(hold) to place multiple blocks on a plane. There are currently two game modes in Space Engineers : survival and creative. Survival mode requires players to collect components/materials to construct objects. Welding also takes a lot more time in this mode. If a player dies, there is a good chance (unless the material is stored), that the material on the player will be lost. To make it even more difficult, every space suit in this mode is given a certain amount of life support. The player will need to recharge or face the ultimate consequence of not breathing oxygen. Creative mode allows the player to respawn as many times as they want without losing any of their material. Moreover, this mode allows players to build as much as they want for no cost. These blocks are also created instantly and do not need to be welded or pre-made. In either mode, random enemies can attack the player. Players do not need to worry about energy/oxygen/hydrogen levels in this mode.When I mean this game is big, it's quite big. It will take some time to learn and definitely take some time to create something significant. Players can be placed in different settings such as earthly, martian, alien, moon or even asteroids to begin building their legacy. There are scenarios to choose from in which will put the player in all sorts of scenarios. Some scenarios will come with already made stations while in others you may start with extremely minimal parts. Players will want to equip their starships (or themselves) with some fire power before exploring the wilderness. Some ship weapons include gatling guns and turrets, rocket launchers, missile turrets and warheads. Hand-held weapons are slightly limited at the moment but include an automatic rifle, a grinder and a hand drill.Graphics are pretty good at the moment but sometimes have an occasional hiccup. It's nothing game-breaking or anything but is noticeable.Overall, it's a pretty good game and the fact it's still early access and being updated is fantastic. It's a BIG game though and would recommend patience while playing. I'm very impatient myself and like simply jumping in the game and playing. This is possible but you'll catch yourself asking "how do I do..." a few times while looking up information on the internet. There is a good tutorial that will help the player discover how to properly master the game. There is still a lot that can be added to this game to make it better (like a sumo mode)!!! Some may find it's appeal fun for the first 5-10 hours then look the other way while others may indulge in such a space adventure. It's all up to the creativity of the player to determine their entertainment.EARLY ACCESS RATING : 7/10ScreenShots : (to come)[url][/url]

								My Review is about the early Access version of Space Engineers.Since its in this phase i do not want to go into details about if the game is fun or not. There are a lot of youtube videos to show the actual gameplay.( for me it is one of the best survival games out there at the moment).It is not because of the content , but more about how the developer is able to show us how early access should be.As a player, you get weekly updates ( most of the time at thursday) , which is not only content , they actually fix existing bugs and are very active in the community and also involve the community like no early access game out there ( see future patches,bugfixing etc.)If you want to see how early access should work and given that you are intrested in seeing a game getting better and better, this game is a must have.I saw a lot of people saying its minecraft on hardmode. this is not the case. You can play it on a hard difficulity (survival realistic) , yet it offers you some options to tune the amount of work needed for crafting and also offers you a creative mode where you can do whatever you want to do.TL,DR : Buy it , you wont be disappointed

								I started on the moon, wanted to get to earth-like so built a capital ship for 2 days to take me there. number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								In space engineers, you take control of a Space engineer in the middle of an asteroid belt with no way to leave, despite having multiple spacecraft around him to pilot. The goal in the engineer's mind is unknown, but it likely has to do with attempting to create the Enterprise, or Star Destroyer. The engineer has two ways to accomplish this. He can either manually mine ores and resources using his drill and spacecraft, or he can use his powers of mind control to conjure up entire ships out of nothing. When he tries to mine things using drills, his drill has an invariably long lifetime, meanwhile he must charge himself every five minutes or so, or he risks dying of being tired. As he constructs his ship, he uses parts built by an assembler, which uses robots to assemble various refined ores into complex parts. He then uses various parts to construct spacecraft while welding in an inconsistent manner, which may explain why his ships usually fall apart when shaked. When he uses his magic, however, he can remain awake forever without negative consequences.However, despite all the magic said engineer can use, he cannot stop a small meteor from blowing up his spacecraft. The meteor storm is the least of his worries, however. He must be on constant lookout to not knock his ship about before he has installed all necessary systems, or he risks it falling endlessly into the void. He must also be careful not to cut his ship in half, since engineers cannot understand the concept of welding two halves of a ship together without special "merge blocks". You can however, create a space station that does not move, no matter what, with no visible means of keeping itself in postition, but again, magic.Space Engineers also offers a heightened challenge, titled, "Cram more cool-looking sci-fi junk into your ship", under the guise of the steam workshop. Despite all attempts, no one has successfully crammed enough sci-fi into their ship.The engineers also use this "workshop" as a way to teleport to another world someone has created, and admire their works, before attempting to destroy them through all means possible, before giving a sort of rating based on Facebook.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								Note: While I do recommend this game you should be aware of the following problems:The game developer (Keen Software House) leaves much to be desired, interaction with the community is in general very poor and they have a habbit of implementing features that are poorly thought out and often untested, normally this would be okay but for some reason they do not have a development branch so player are often forced to deal with game breaking bugs, some of which can take weeks to be resolved, still they do update every Thursday which is a plus even if it's just bug fixes.Performace in the game is very bad, even with a fairly high end machine you can expect problems, planets for example can consume 6GB of memory on low textures, at higher texture settings it's possible to reach 10GB or more which is insane, multiplayer is poorly optimized with frequent crashes on the dedicated server, this is extra annoying since you die if you get disconnected while not inside a cryo chamber, you also need a DirectX 11 card, I'd suggest the GTX 970 at the minimum, performance is significantly better in space.If you like this type of game and have a good PC you may be able to overlook the bugs, it's a lot of fun when everything works and there is a nice variety of mods on the Steam workshop, I'm hopeful these issues will be fixed in the near future but for now you should carefully consider before buying.

content:

Early Access Review
								The developers and this game are broken. You will run into the most game breaking and frustrating bugs if you play this. Here is the kind of♥♥♥♥♥♥you will deal with:-The game crashes every single time you play, sometimes 5 minutes in, sometimes an hour in, but it always happens.-There are several blocks you can build that just don't work. Want to make a cool hangar door that hinges open? Use a rotor. Oh wait, too bad they randomly explode for no reason and destroy whatever you worked hard on. Want to build a cool rover like the devs claim you can do? Too bad, the wheels are basically aesthetic and usually end up making your rover fall through the planet and kill you.-Want to build on the planets and make a cool base? Tough♥♥♥♥♥♥ the planets are so poorly optimized that even a mid-high end gaming computer can barely run them.-Using one of the most critical block in the game, landing gear, instantly crashes the game most of the time.-You also can't land ships on planets. The ships will violently shake themselves to death or explodeYou would think the developers would actually make these game ruining bugs a high priority and make their games at least usable instead of cheating their customers out of their money, but nah, instead update the game to add robot dogs that self explode. At this point maybe the game is actually about keeping a ship in one piece for longer than an hour without it crashing or exploding.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have had this game for quite a while now and have been impressed with the steady development.  Updates are frequent and follow a content-bug fix-polish cycle.  New content seems to be prioritised based on what is most missing from the game after listening to player feedback.  The developers clearly have their own vision of the game they are making, but they listen to the audience they have attracted when deciding how best to go about integrating the many necessary elements.Early Access games have something of a bad reputation, but the team behind Space Engineers have behaved with integrity thus far and I definitely feel I have gotten my money's worth of fun already.The game is still clearly not a finished, bug-free, polished product.  However, barring financial considerations, I have no reason to doubt that it will be in time.I want that to happen, so I recommend this game so more people may buy it and the makers are less likely to run out of money and more likely to get a decent reward for behaving admirably.What is the game like itself?  Sort of advanced giant virtual lego in space I suppose.

								One of the better "early access" games, in that it actual feels like its moving forward and will be finished.  Most will say SE is just "Minecraft in space" but not really.
