Early Access Review
								This game had so much potential, yet it seems like that potential will never be fulfilled by the developers. I bought this game a while ago. It is poorly optimized, the AI is sloppy, and the building is tedious, but the game was "still early access" and it "has so much potential."Well, many months later, almost no new content has been added and this game is still poorly optimized. Planets were added, but they're extremely buggy and laggy. I've given up hope that the devs will make this game great, which is a shame. It really did have the potential, but instead it plays like a slightly improved version of Masterspace. And Masterspace is a garbage game, so that's not saying much.So, where's the new, meaningful cotent? Where's the optimization? Why are there still so many bugs that still haven't been fixed? Seems like the devs have put this on the backburner ever since planets were added. Don't waste your money, this game is a bad investment.

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								Space Engineers is a geat game, or at least it was. Today its pretty much dead if you ask me. The game started off well and development really kept the community interested. The major problem is the game was basic at the start so the fact that its terribly optimised really wasnt all that bad even for mid level computers. But they keep adding more and more stuff to an already poor performing game. The game has had a long development cycle at his point and barely playable for a lot of us. Even the most tricked out desktop will run this game fairly badly. Your pretty much hoping for your computers worst performance to be able to run the game smoothly. Rather than fixing any optimisation issues however they continue to add new features and more complex systems to the game making it basically unplayable nowadays. Even a simple sever with a small ship is likely to have framerate issues and generally look graphically bad which to be honest has always been the case. I just wish they would actually think about properly finishing the game instead of just throwing new gimmicks to the player base which is getting smaller by every update. It feels now like the game has fallen into that development abyss and doomed to die slowly and painfully when in reality this was and could have been a great game. Its a great idea after all. Who doesnt want minecraft in space with huge cool looking ships you can build, fly, destroy, salvage etc etc. It an awesome idea but totally dead now. Even building anything moderately big will cause major framerate issues. I enjoyed the time i played this game because i got to enjoy that slightly lighter and ealier build which worked despie all the problems. Nowadays though i dont even bother looking at it anymore because its just sad to watch a game like this run so poorly. If im honest im angry at the developers for really screwing this up soo much. It was even mentioned about an xbox one and possible ps4 port at one point. Just another development failure but not to worry, or at least they shouldnt worry because they already took your money and didnt deliver on the promises. Either way they win.

number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								Pro:+ weekly updates+ infinite space: 500.000.000 kilometers of space to explore in every direction. You can literally never find the border of the 'gameworld' / galaxy. + random encounters with NPC ships+ Aliens (after a 2 year wait), finally alien life is in the gameCon: - Open to griefplay: Work on  each design for 10 hours, in your 150 hour savegame while behind your back some random fool sabotages your desings in 10 seconds. Let your friends in, nobody else. - The weekly updates are too small. A zoom function on a an exising camera block is considered an update ? lol. - Insane learning curve: Will make 95% of your Steam friends turn around and run away screaming. - Insane depth: Infinite possibilities. It's a job, not a game. - PVE: Lack of content. No food. No crops. No anything. You only get to find ores and shoot the odd alien. - No liquids, no water, no oil, only solids.- Optimisation issues: Get a NASA approved PC before installing SE.- blueprint mayhem: The blueprint folder is a knuckledragging primitive system. IF you use it, it will turn into a giant mess very quickly.- script mayhem: Same deal for scripts. Primitive interface to manage scripts. - Maximim speed 110 m/s: This has to do with load timing, still it's very annoying to fly a ship design that can never reach over 110 m/s speed. Even though you are in frictionless space. Ugh just don't think about it. - Apart from a few YouTube people who make a living from building complex designs, I'm not sure people still bother with it. Conclusion: . 1) The game is a fun concept to think about. Infinite space, generated planets, generated asteroids, limitless possibilities. But in practice I can't find anyone with enough patience or inspiration to join me in my game. 2) The game takes too much building time to make it a viable PVP game. build for 20 hours, get destroyed in 2 seconds...The game needs way more PVE content. recipes, plants, aliens, random places to visit. Right now it has none of those. 3) The game defeats itself. You get ore to build a ship, a ship to get ore to build a ship. Then you realize survial mode build ships are garbage so you switch to creative mode and build a perfect ship. Now you switch back to survival mode and can't find a reason to actually spend 10 days to find the resources to  build the ship from the blueprint you've just made in creative mode. End game reached.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								UPDATED 2/2015Several months have passed since I purchased Space Engineers. The name of the game is exactly that: the challenge of engineering in space, being able to procure resources on site, and use those resources to become more efficient and defend your creations. Although the game is still in alpha stages, the potential is huge! The developers release updates almost weekly, most of which include new features that change game play and introduce new challenges! I don't want to be cliché and compare it to Minecraft. It's more like LEGOS in space, but you have to survive by creating all of your block from scratch, and procuring resources to keep you alive!Building ships in creative mode shows the potential this game has for creation, especially if you can imagine several people building, mining, and fighting at once. Multi-player AND survival adds a whole new kind of engineering challenge. All weapons exist and work in game, and the use of factions allows for greater organization when playing on MP servers.Space exploration is now enabled, which allows you to travel more than 6 AU's from the center point of the map. 6 AU's is 6x the distance from Earth to the Sun, so it's practically unlimited! The addition of derelict ships and stations is great, especially when you're drifting through space with the default spawn ship and little resources. Cargo ships now shoot back when you approach them, and there is a "super secret AI project" in the works.If you've been on the fence about purchasing SE, I wouldn't procrastinate any longer. The more people there are testing and making suggestions to the game, the faster it'll be released in beta, and final forms. Besides, the game is well worth it as it is!Just remember, this game is in ALPHA, which is before BETA, and you will encounter some minor problems than an unfinished game has. I personally have joined the forums at Keen Software House and have been involved in suggested features and bug reports.Pros:- Creative/survival mode- Multiplayer- Ship weapons enabled- Procedural asteroid generation / limitless map- Awesome damage and repair effects- Huge potential- Very fast development/weekly update releasesCons:- It's alpha; if you can deal with the fact that things will change over time (so far for the better), then this isn't a problem for you!

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								One of the freshest gaming concepts to come along in years. Take the crafting of Minecraft, the Zero-G insanity of Shattered Horizon and the resource gathering and tech-trees of Starcraft and you've got Space Engineers.The one element that really captured my attention to begin with, was how after mining, I'd have to float above the conveyor belts, drop the ore from my inventory and then that phsyical item would drop into the refinery and I could both hear and watch (through its own inventory screen) as it refined that ore into a usable format.You take the stuff out, select what you want to build then place it and the framework appears.. you then pull out your welder and get to work, eventually your object will be fully formed. Throw in co-op, meteor showers and the incredible ability to build and colour your own moving spacecraft and this is just an endless experience.Hit me up, I need a co-op partner!

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Space Engineers is one of those games for those who love to build things. It makes itself unique from its terrestrial counterparts in that you build everything in the weigthlessness of outerspace. Space Engineers strikes a great balance between realistic and fun. The resource system gives good meaning to what you do;collecting resources isnt as easy as punching a tree you'll either need to go out and drill it in zero-g (not easy) then refine it at your base (if you've a refinery and fuel to run it.) However attachments like the rocket launcher and placeable warhead make for some great sandbox fun.I will say my favorite part of Space Engineers has to be the damage system; things look awesome when you wreck them together. That coupled with the physics system.. is a match made in heaven. You will immediately know if your ship is missing somthing on its maiden voyage as it will hurdle out into space or charge wrecklessly into your space station. It's a blast.Best building game I've played so far in my life and I have played a lot of minecraft.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Decided to remake my review of this game, since a lot of stuff has been changed.So, what the♥♥♥♥♥♥is Space Engineers? Another Sandbox game. It's pretty much what anyone wants it to be. You can build ships as you deside to do so, make space-stations, mine minerals, make weapons, annihilate other players, you name it.In creative, you can pretty much build whatever you want, and test your creations with infinite materials. In survival, you start with almost nothing, and you have to get everything working with your own hands. You can either do this alone, or with friends, but really guys, games like these can get boring really fast if you don't get friends to play with. Things are added constantly, and the Devs actually hear what the players say, and add things that we all suggest. Of all the "Early Access" games on Steam, I would say this is the most active one. To be fair, it's not an Alpha anymore, more like a Beta.The game runs smoothly unless you do crazy stuff like crashing multiple large ships into each other, or a big fight between 15 or more players, each one with their own ship. Lag does happen at times in multiplayer, but anyone can make host their own server, so it's mainly the host fault. There are some griefing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s already in the game, these things happen, that's why the Devs will add some sort of "Faction" thingy, so groups of friends can go together, with their own big♥♥♥♥♥ship, and stuff like that. Like I said, playing alone is kinda boring, specially because you will be alone if some dumbass wants to destroy and take your stuff. Even though, it doesn't always happen, and you can set your parties to be private, or just for your friends. Also, in most servers (and in most parties, and events), people just set two teams, build their own ships, and have fun killing each other. I've been in 3 of those battles, and I can tell you, it's fun as ♥♥♥♥. Specially when you're the captain in the biggest ship of the team, trying to command your team to victory, while giving orders using Skype. Yeah, there's no communications ingame yet. That sucks.The game is quite fun already, but still, if you want to enjoy it to the fullest, get some friends to play. If not, you should wait for a sale or price drop in a Steam-event. But be aware: The base price of the game will only rise for now on.

content:

Early Access Review
								17.06.2015One of the gratest game ever created. It is a minecraft in space but with extended mechanics, physics and good graphics. Still under development, weekly updates make that we discover this game again and again. This game is recomended for engineers, roboticians, players who want something more than stupid mindless warfare, or just for those who want create simple things also. You can create spaceships with several functions, programming language is provided into game but is not necessary. This game everyone can play. Creating scripts, logic gates makes your creation alive. I've playing this game for years and still cant be bored. Space Engineers are still under development.-------------------------------------------------------------3.08.2016For 1,5 years only one update with new content. Devs are fooling arround, catching their own tail. Same bugs since 2 years. New models, features and other stuff that they were teasing more than a year ago, felt into the void of oblivion. They claim that there are 14 people developing game + 7 working on engine. With overall timeline it seems that only one lazy person is making any updates. Roadmap for the game is for next 50 years in this "developing" speed. Game is unplayable without mods and second hand - using mods is suicide. 1 update can ruin everything (What happened with DX11 support - it could be avoided with one additional script, but they didnt.). Past few updates devs are reversing updated content (like disabling by default pressurization). Still missing most basic blocks.Im also working on a game and im telling You that in one week one person can do more than 1 year develop whole team in KSH.Summary: game develop is dead, weekly "updates" are only illusion. Same thing with another KSH title: Medieval Engineers.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
Say goodbye to Minecraft-in-space sandbox games.Space Engineers is, in my opinion, a masterpiece and, while still under development, is most definitely worth your time and money if you're in to the creative sandbox 'genre.'As of now, I won't criticize it too heavily since it is still in Early Access. However, I will review the general components of the game:Graphics: The realistic graphical style of the game is quite fitting and very easy to look at, boasting a ton of high-quality textures. The lighting is also very well done.Sound: The sound design is pretty solid, even though not all of it has been implemented. Although, the music soundtracks are very engaging and fitting. If the game had its own official OST, I would buy it personally.Gameplay Mechanics: What's currently presented is quite impressive. However, there are some hiccups. As this is an Early Access game, you will most likely find bugs, glitches, and generally unfinished mechanics as you play. Once again, keep in mind that this game is still a WIP.Multiplayer/Optimization: Now this is where the game currently falls short. The lag in multiplayer can become unbearable. Same can be said on singleplayer, although it is much less severe. Both instances of dropped framerate, both in MP and SP, are usually caused by either(or both) how many objects are in the world or the host's connection. Thankfully, they have added dedicated servers, but they are still a WIP. With this kind of framerate issue, it is nearly impossible to have large-scale projects with you and/or your friends without a hint of dropped framerate. While the devs are working vigorously to optimize the game as a whole, it is probably a category of the game that won't be perfected for a while.Replayability: This is something I really don't need to go into. It's a SANDBOX game! It only ever ends when you stop playing it entirely, and since there are essentially limitless things to do, there's an infinite amount of replayability.While the game does suffer from optimization issues and unfinished mechanics, remember that this game is still in Early Access. It's not the final product.With that said, here's my take on the rating system based on the game's current state: Graphics: 8/10Sound: 7/10Gameplay: 7/10Optimization: 4.5/10Replayability: 10/10Overall rating: 7/10, a solid sandbox title, especially for the price of $20.00. However, this rating could go up or down in the future. As this is an Early Access title, this rating is based on what the game is like now, not on how it will be in the future. I have high hopes for Space Engineers, and I hope it is all the Devs and the fans want it to be when it is released as a final product.

								Bug causes clipping to death through walls and other random objects. This has been in the game since at least april. Die every 30-45 minutes, without fail, for no reason. Fix this NOW.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Normally I'm not an early-acess type of person, but I saw the developers of this game are EXTREMELY competent and consistent with a schedule of weekly updates every thursday which include new features and bugfixes.I'm happy with the game's current direction really. The developers enabling modding support was a really smart move on their part because modding communities often contribute fantastic gameplay and features (much like Garry's Mod!). Gameplay-wise the game is just a sandbox survival with a main focus on construction and resourse gathering. For anyone to have more of an experience of that they need to roleplay or create their own sub-games.What I'd like to see now is different game-modes and less focus on construction/manipulation. Even something simple like a Science Unlocking system would work, or more random events like direlect space stations with aliens in them to explore (and explode!)The game is going a great direction, is plenty of fun to mess around in, however can get quite boring over time if you're playing by yourself in survival.

content:
Posted: April 17
Early Access Review
								Ahhh, Tricky review again. I love this game but can't recommend it yet.The game mechanics are simply great and that allowed me to spend quite some time in the solo game, though, as soon as you hit the multi player game... it becomes a nightmare.Let's start from the beginning.You've got 2 modes: Creative and survival.But also Solo game and multi player. They both differ greatly in terms of playing experience.As I enjoy the challenge, I always play in Survival where all the game mechanics are in place.Maps:It's absolutely great that you can choose between different environments for your survival.Choose between an asteroid field or a star system and you will have to fight very different issues.The asteroid field will force you to wander from asteroid to asteroid with your space suit that has limited oxygen and energy supply... so... it will be hard.But this is absolutely great as you can engineer your way through most of the problems with tons of solutions.- Build a tiny transport ship to resupply yourself and put your ore in it maybe ? Oh... you forgot that the ore was weighting a lot and your thrusters are so weak that you need 2 minutes to stop ? ah well, if you didn't explode your ship, maybe go back to the drawing board ?- Build a driller ship ? so easy to eat the asteroid without having to collect stone by stone- Transport your platform anchored in an asteroid in a huge barge that will bring your production to the resources and not the opposite way around ?- Oh your platform is a bit too huge to rework ? Well, just build a welder ship !You chose the survival on a planet ? Well... first learn that the mechanics with the air and gravity are a bit differentThen, learn that even if oxygen is not a problem anymore, the local animals might be an even greater pain.Great features:- The ore- The ease of construction (if you have the resources of course)- Flight and ship creations- Moving parts and well thought docking abilities- Very smart conveyor system for resources, including filters- Gravity generator and Newtonian movements, though physics are approximated.- Realistic demolitions / crashes (though... see CONS related to that)- Blueprints that allow you to save and copy items- The really beautiful planets and seamless transitions with space- Oxygen pumps/generators and pressurised structures.Game killers:- The weakness of the parts in general. I kinda love the fact that you can destroy a landing gear because you landed... HOW DARE YOU LAND ! You'd better use the wheels as landing gear instead (as they can't be used for wheeling purposes anyway...see further down)- The deadly "I'm a thruster and I will stop working because I just decided to" that will basically destroy your ships on planets due to gravity- The wonky wheels that are so bugged that your vehicle will bounce in the air and flip every 2 minutes. Which is actually a pretty fun problem to solve in itself as you'll have to engineer you out of this situation again.- Characters getting stuck everywhere. HOW DARE YOU JUMP ON A VEHICLE !- The elastic effect : sometimes you think you are somewhere but the game never let you go at this place at the first time and you will feel some kind of elastic force preventing you from going further from your real position. very very annoying as any stair or corner will trigger that problem- Similarly to the above, you think you were welding an object...but...remember, you are not where you think you are ! therefore you can't be welding. Basically you can be welding and not at the same time hence why I called my welder Schroedinger- The steel nibbling wolves. Yep, you heard me. On planets, wolves will spawn once in a while which is great for the survival aspect... though... they are light-speed demons, first, and then they will literally nibble whatever metallic structure that is touching the ground... and believe me, they've got a fierce appetite. This is killing the survival as the turrets are kinda inefficient and they destroy rare resources.- The incredibly annoying collisions. whatever design you make, the slighest proximity of another cube (its edge, its corner or its face) will provoke a grip that will soon lead to a very spectacular explosion of your structure soon. It ruins the building experience of mechanisms as you can't really see what is happening. The collision blocks are often not corresponding to what you see.- The air tightness is incredibly painful too. Some blocks are strangely configured and even if they look like sealing your ship, they don't, and your cockpit will never get pressurised.Minor things they could improve in the future:- more parts because you always need more- More dynamic events (not necessarily deadly) like missions with rewards- elastic or spring parts that would allow more flexibility in your parts- allow lifts in shafts as it destroys the structure when you do that nowI have to admit they made a great leap forward recently since I played the game for the first time. The multi-player is now kinda playable but still so irritating.Globally the game is a gem still in the rough. I wish the developers could assess those problems first as this is really what prevents the game from being a hit.I wish they could make me change my review as I really love the game but I would feel unfair recommending the game for the moment.Some might say "you're harsh, it's a Beta". Well, yes, this is why I waited quite some time before reviewing it.

Early Access Review
								This is one of the most fun sandbox games. It allows you to build ships and stations, create logical operations, make scripts in game, and anything else you can come up with. Another great thing about this game is you can construct things with precision without have to having to place thousands of cubic meters of wool to create it (*cough* Minecraft *cough*). It gets weekly updates, has Steam workshop mods, worlds, and ship blueprints support, and you don't have to port forward just to host you're own online game. The only cons I can see with this game is community griefers, but that's an issue with any sandbox game and there aren't that many now (At least what I've played). So why not get it!?

content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is a great game that can provide hours of fun building complex machinery in the vastness of the cosmos.So long as you don't use any moving parts.Or play with your friends.By no circumstance should you allow your friends to play with the moving parts you made.If you do, then I hope you're okay with everything clipping into everything else and exploding. Yes, making things not explode is an essential part of being an engineer, true. But I'm not so sure about changing the laws of physics themselves, or controlling how physics operate when you load your game. Yes, I could lock all the moving parts with landing gears before saving and quitting so they don't spaz out when I reload the game. The point is I shouldn't have to compensate for a failure of the game code.I mean, if you can't use moving parts and have them function reliably then it's not really about engineering, now is it?It's just architecture.

								Unfortunately I cannot recommend this game. The premise is great, and the game that *could* have been made was also great. content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
Early Access Review
Space Engineers ReviewNeedless, to say, Space Engineers is a great sandbox set in the vastness of space.  I became consumed by my own personal projects, meticulously piecing together a ship which would dwarf my friends'.  If you don't feel like reading, the game's a great combination of physics and creativity, definitely a game worth checking out.  The game's most recent update added planets to the game and I can't wait to see how the developers expand on their ideas.  If you are into sandbox games and wish to dive into something new, Space Engineers will definitely be worth your money.Gameplay 8.5/10The game sports 2 primary game modes: creative and survival.  Players can choose to join a friend's game as long as they are willing to host a session.  The objectives of each are self-explanatory.  Hostile AI has been implemented into the game, but in survival mode, most of the challenge comes from the extraction of resources from mineral-rich asteroids, which the player must drill into for resources.  Players start off survival mode with a tiny yellow ship equipped with drills for extracting minerals.  I gave it as score of 8.5/10 for gameplay, provided that players actively seek out creative ways to have fun in the game and make full use of its wonderfully made sandbox, though survival mode is a bit too unforgiving to appreciate the game's design in my opinion.Lore N/AAs of now, the game has no lore, nor does it require lore, therefore its absence doesn't affect the scoring.Visuals 8/10There's honestly not much to look at in space.  The newest update which introduced planets is a huge step forward for this game, the shaders prove their worth and the physics serve as enough of a spectacle.  Sadly the demanding nature of this game drags down the score, but just a bit.  Optimisation can always be fixed and will only affect the player for a second or two.  Personally, my framerate takes a nosedive during large-scale ship collisions and the firing of projectiles.  I have to admit that I had been carried away with the ship's firearms at the time, so your experience may be different.ConclusionI have to say, I'm deeply impressed by the quality of this game and its focus on creativity.  A friend of mine taught me how to manipulate the game's physics to create a "hyperdrive", sending your ship shooting off in a straight line.  It's moments like these when you realise how much freedom you are given in Space Engineers, and how much fun you can get from exploring a game.  The game's attention to physics, detail and developer support net this game a whopping 16.5/20, the higher end of the indie game spectrum.  I truly believe that this game has great potential and if you like sandbox games, the $20 price tag is a more than reasonable price to pay for countless hours of fun.  16.5/20

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								I wrote a review over a year ago recommending this game. At it's current state, I don't recommend it. It crashes regularly, has texture tearing issues, the AI is abysmal, numerous frustrating bugs, very poor resource spawning...Here's my recent experince: I try planets because it sounds cool. I spawn in a lander and spend AGES flying to find resources. Navigating on planets feels awkward. The enemies are so poorly designed that I just turn them off. Minecraft has better AI enemies than Space Engineers and yet Minecraft's enemies AI is simplistic and uninteresting. It's amazing they managed to do something WORSE than Minecraft's enemy AI. So, I decide planets need more work so I start a world in space, my old favorite. I spawn in a respawn ship and instantly die. I try again and instantly die. I try every respawn ship and instantly die and the only one that worked was the planetary lander, WHICH DOESN'T WORK IN SPACE. It has atmospheric thrusters! So, that mode was unplayable. I made a new space map, this time starting at a platform station. No problems respawning. I think this is great now. I go around getting resources and building stuff. However, every 5-10 minutes it would crash randomly. I have Windows 10, gtx970, 16GB ram, 3.5GHz processor, and no other applications running that should interfere with it. Yet I get consistent crashes at random. I put up with the crashes and keep playing, saving constantly. I realize that for no reason, my assemblers stop automatically taking resources they need to build. So I have to MANUALLY DRAG INGOTS INTO IT. This is something basic that used to work just fine. Another major pain for me was finding resources. My starting asteroid had iron, ice, Pt, Ni. So I had to search for the other resources on other asteroids. No big deal. I go around searching asteriods and I leave a GPS marker at each to keep track of the ores that I find. I had to search over TWENTY ASTEROIDS to find silver! And I only found two little patches of silicon and magnesium. It took way too long. It was a tedious and unfun experience, which used to be no problem. They've made many changes to the game that introduced instability, frustrating bugs, poorly designed AI and poor random generation. Do not buy SE until they fix these things. It used to feel like a Beta, now it feels like an Alpha.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								Even after two years in “Early Access”, Space Engineers still has: long loading times, plenty of bugs, visual glitches and clipping, some clearly incomplete elements, and a plethora of performance issues (stuttering, frame rate drops, audio hiccups, and generally not the best optimisation)… But at the same time, its gameplay model is a true sandbox with almost endless possibilities, with brilliant music and sound design, its graphics are more than decent, and most importantly of all – when played with friends – this unfinished indie game from Czechia has the potential to give you more entertainment and playtime than many big budget AAA productions from the gaming industry’s giants.The tools you are given here are truly complex with so many options giving you opportunities for interesting contraptions, from tiny planetary outposts and starfighters to enormous subterranean metropolises and Death Stars – the galaxy is your playground. The similarities to Minecraft and its cousins are obvious, but the two things that really set Space Engineers apart from many other creation/crafting/survival games are its carefully developed physics system and atmospheric setting. Moreover, unlike with many other Early Access titles, Keen Software House cannot be accused of reaping the benefits of this scheme without putting effort into the project, as Space Engineers has actually grown in scope.Substantial performance problems are the main hindrance that can get in the way of the amount of fun you are having with it. Although some might argue that this is justifiable because Space Engineers is not yet finished, I disagree; they are charging you for it and so it should be in as stable a state as possible. However, minus those technical hitches, this game is masterfully designed.If you are patient enough to accept that, then you should buy this game. If you are unsure – wait for a sale. If you know you are the kind of person who does not tolerate games with such problems, then hold on until it leaves Early Access, but at some point you just have to get it and bring your friends with you. The things you can do with them in multiplayer are the key selling point.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Sigh, A year ago this game was relatively playable and quite enjoyable. I could go on about dozens of sleepless nights playing with friends on a PvP server, building our little fleets across the stars; claiming asteroids and looting other people’s bases while they slept. Mapping out the entire map with GPS coordinates and a 3D calculator + spreadsheet was something that gave us an edge. Here we stand almost what--ten months? from when I left and the game still memory leaks and crashes to the desktop. I just don’t know how a game, when I got it, goes from a playable and very basic Alpha version to whatever SE is today that’s completely broken. And I mean it: I can’t even load a blank creative world without the game memory leaking and then crashing. So when you see my 700hrs, make a note to yourself. That’s the game from three to one year ago.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								Perfect start, now plummeting into a bad crash landing...The game was great. I really love it. It clicked into everything I've wanted from a sandbox. It's a great time consumer, it's a game I've always wanted to be made. Bought it ages ago for a relatively huge amnount of money, but I didn't regret it. Until since about half a year things went worse. The once smooth performance went drastically low, the game itself is plagued with bizarre glitches after every update. None of those things seem to be addressed - adding more irrelevant content took all the shiny spotlight. I don't have the best computer but it used to run satisfyingly good; now it's a 800x600 nightmare in about 30 fps... if I don't build too much. Maybe if there was some sort of a warning that I'll have to buy a 3x times more powerful PC after a certain number of patches I wouldn't be ranting.And even if I had a real gaming rig, Space Engineers would still be unplayable. Multiplayer is a distant memory; there's no real way of enjoyably playing with someone. Single player is not much better.Everything just explodes, lags, disconnects and crashes. Rotors and landing gears generate more explosive force than actual warheads in the game. Nothing works like it's supposed to. Mining anything is a suicide either literally or performance-wise. Wheeled vehicles can't go a hundred yards without making tons of collision noises, eventually falling apart and exploding or plummeting into the void under the planet surface. Explosions? Explosions! Mr. Torgue must have approved.Not to mention that actual content is dusty and lacking (What about ladders? hatches? hinges? treads? everything in the workshop?), and must be expanded through gazillion mods that put a strain on the dying performance - or just don't load. The devs weekly address those issues through their own vision of needed content: the likes of self-detonating dogs (as if eveyrthing wasn't exploding anyway), different colored "new" tool variants no one cares about or "modding support" to things that have been already modded ages ago. What's the point of forcing weekly updates and showing off unneeded things if people want a functionable game ?Sorry KEEN but unless you start making the actual game playable after all these terrible months, I'll have to tell people: don't waste your money on it like I did. And I was a real maniac, I really loved the thing. I know you're just a bunch of indie devs and you always had my sympathy for making this experience possible. I would still be building tons of stuff for the sake of enjoying it... if this game worked.    Start listening to your players, they're the ones funding this ordeal. It's been long enough.

content:

Early Access Review
Terribly optimized and by terrible, I mean 5 -10 FPS. Maybe something's wrong with my rig or so, but I seem to be able to run every other game in my library just fine. Some problems I've ran into: crashes every now and then, corrupted save files, complete lag when standing on planets. Multiplayer makes it lag even more. There are ways to tweak the game yourself based on your rig, but they're quite a pain to figure out eventually ranging to editing your game files, trying to find the right version of your graphics driver, etc. Don't get me wrong, once I got this game working for a while it was actually really fun, but at the moment, unless you're a diehard alpha tester, I would recommend staying out of this game until this game gets an optimization update. I still have faith for this game in the future though, the concept is really neat, it's just the terrible current optimizations that bothers me. I wasted most of my hours in this game trying to tweak it myself.TL;DR You literally need a NASA computer to run this thing without any sort of bugs/crashesEDIT: Some typos and other things I wanted to mention

content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								Space Engineers may still be an Early Access title, but this game is definately worth it and I strongly recommend this game to those who enjoy sanbox/survival type games. The game does a great job at making you feel small. Flying around space and mining off asteroids gives you a good perspective to how big the universe really is. This game does support the Steam workshop and mods are frequently being uploaded to the workshop to provide the game with new or improved content to suit your playstyle or needs. With that being said, I feel it'd be best to start with the negatives...As I've mentioned before, this game is still in early access and is expected to have bugs and crashed here and there. From what i've experienced so far, here are some things you should take note of:- Don't try to load a world with more that 15 mods enabled, your game will most likely freeze or crash to desktop. (However, this may just be my system) - This game does require a beefy PC when it comes to running planets. I was only able to get a max framerate of 40 on a planet without foilage and on the lowest possible graphical settings. For those who do have a decent system shouldn't have any issues however. - Whilst playing on a relatives server, i've noticed anything that a client does, would also appear for the server host. E.g - I take my helmet off, it'll come up with the same message for the host. Or if I had ran out of materials for an upgrade, it'll not only tell myself, but it would also tell the host. - When connecting to lets say, a friends server with mods enabled, sometimes the mod will not install correctly and will not work. I'm having this issue currently on a relatives server and are still trying to solve it. - Changing your graphics setting from lowest to highest or vice versa can cause your game to crash. - The camera is a bit dodgy at times, especially when it comes to crouching or mining in small spaces.  (There are many more that I could go into detail about, but those are the most obvious)Seeing there will be problems with any game that's in early access, don't feel it should stop you from buying it. The game is updated every now and again and the devs are trying their hardest to fix the problems. That being said, this game will keep you occupied for hours and in my opinion, is definately worth a try.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								WARNING: This game MIGHT embrace the Paid Mods feature. If this happens, consider not buying this game.This is a game that was made for people just like me. It looks like Minecraft in space, but it's more than that. It gives you the tools to solve problems, and the fulfillment you get after coming up with your own solution is a feeling sorely lacking in other sandbox games.The survival mode in this game gives you a lot of content. I've been playing it for more than forty hours and I haven't even managed to set up a decent mining operation. You can also hijack other ships and take them apart to build new ones. You can stop them in a craft that you made or even just in your spacesuit (if you know what you're doing) - they're all coasting on autopilot and  with automated weaponry that makes approaches tricky. The fun is in the trial and error, and figuring out the best way to do a seemingly simple task.Is your mining drill inefficient? Build a mining ship. Is the hand welder too slow for you? Make a welder-equipped craft. Do you need to strip and salvage a giant capital ship you just captured? Maybe a corvette with six  grinders is what you need. Creativity and resourcefulness is rewarded.The creative mode is also great for shooting things with other people and making fantastic designs of ships on your own. There are ways to save schematics or blueprints of your designed ships so that you can build and use them in survival mode. The devs are also great in that they update really often, and for an alpha version (I rarely buy games on Early Access) my money has already been well spent. BUY IT AND PLAY WITH ME AND YOUR OTHER FRIENDS!

number of helpful: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
Early Access Review
(Review as of January 27, 2016)I will preface with this:This is most certainly an early access peer review. Space Engineers updates weekly, sometimes even more frequently, and constantly changes, adjusts, and updates factors that may alter gameplay.I'm an aspiring aerospace engineer. I've set my sights on attending the ever prestigious Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where some say aerospace engineering was founded. Naturally, I immediately devoted some attention to Space Engineers for this reason. Using voxels, modules, and some ingenuity, you can create incredible entities. One may pay homage to great movie and show starships, or develop real-life historic vehicles largely responsible for mankind's presence in space..... or you can do whatever you want, create whatever you want, and play however you want.Let's get down to brass tacks and discuss what currently works and what could use improvement:What works:An innovative ship and space station creation system with robust options in function and form through voxels and parts.Some realistic grounding with physics, especially with inertia and momentum.Two varied game modes (enduring survival and imaginative creative) with adjustable environments and settings.A mod-friendly execution.What could use improvement:Multiplayer. Long time veterans knew this would be first on the list. Network optimization is poor and gameplay frustrating.Performance in general. This is a pressing issue to Keen Software House's Marek Rosa and should likely be addressed within the year. Let's hope!Static animations most certainly testament to the game's early access nature. (Most evident with astronaut movement.)Painting. Painting is the stuff of nightmares. Be prepared to fight the poor paint-application system.What doesn't work:Building two separate station / habitats and connecting them together with voxels. (Some things are just too difficult to cut-and-paste.) This is an exercise in patience.Ultimately, Space Engineers is a fascinating game. If you have any desire to design, create, and fly your own spacecraft, then this is a wonderful experience. Share your creations with your friends, enjoy the vast network of mods available to you, and start your own space empire!

number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								The short of it: don't buy Space Engineers. If you're honestly interested, check up on it every once in a while, read the forums and reviews, consider it if it ever reaches a far more playable state. But right now? I cannot recommend a purchase.Now for the long expository part. I've played a lot of Space Engineers, and from quite some time ago. Back then, it had its problems and was rather clunky, but it was still for the most part playable without too much complication. Yet as this game has continued to progress, and this is especially true within the last numerous months, it has regressed into something even worse than its earlier states, riddled with bugs far more compromising and unacceptable.I am no stranger to Early Access titles, owning more than a handful. While EA games certainly have their ups and downs, in its more recent versions, Space Engineers has been down after down after down.I would first have to say that planets, while they were greeted with much hype within the community, are completely uninteresting. They offer no intrinsic value by their own right, having no resources exclusive to planets while still having to deal with atmospheric navigation which is less convenient than space navigation, and not to mention that, last time I tried, which admittedly was a while ago, using your landing gear could potentially destroy your ship due to its glitchiness. Your ship could start to jitter and shake until something finally breaks on it, or at worse, blow up. Not to mention that any kind of rubber-banding could also lead to the destruction of your ship as you could suddenly find yourself crashed into the ground.Or that ship speed used to be consistent. While I can understand that due to revamps, there may be problems, what I have to consider as unacceptable is that the developers have yet to properly fix the problem, and in doing so seems to have shifted the bugginess from one area to another. Earlier, if there was a server desync or even if a player joined a game, your ship would lose considerable speed, as well as simply losing speed over time. If I may digress, this review is spurred on by my experience earlier today when I decided to kill some boredom and play Space Engineers again. While the aforementioned speed problem has seemed to be alleviated, with speed fluctuating at roughly the same m/s, instead walking has been severely crippled. I tried on multipe servers and the issue was recurring on most of them. When I got out of the cockpit after my ship moved, not even at a particularly high speed or expansive distance, walking would become significantly hindered as the game would refuse to let my character stop moving. Now, I do not mean that he continued to "walk," but more as continuously jerk forwards, like trying to scoot himself forward while going through a seizure.And that is not to mention long-standing bugs and issues that have been with the game for months or even over a year. Or that, due to a myriad of bugs and patches of instability, multiplayer is more of a chore and experience in patience against frustration than a fun sandbox to play in.I cannot recommend this game in its current state, and barring an incredible transformation, likely in the near future, either. Not until there is a clear indication that these complications get ironed out, that the development of this game isn't so helter skelter and destabilizing, and that multiplayer is in a state of respectable operation. During its EA development, while it attempts to improve, it seems to be a case of one step forwards and two steps back, leading to an arguable even worse state than it was over a year ago. At best, keep an eye on it and see if it improves; otherwise, save your money and maybe wait for a different game with similar themes and genre to come along.

Early Access Review
								The biggest problem with Space Engineers, which threatens its entire future...Keen's overall lack of progress and commitment to the game. The second issue...the bootlickers who cry "it's Alpha".Well, Alpha means full steam ahead for development. This is NOT the case with SE. If anything, the original team packed up long ago and the game is floundering. I would almost classify the game as abandonware. There are huge issues with the game (mostly multiplayer) which have existed for months. If they can't address these, how can they claim the game is in Alpha and moving forward? It's ridiculous.Somehow, they have reached the point where they cannot seem to move it forward without breaking things severely. Patches are something to be afraid of. The game has incredible potential, it's just struggling to find someone to take it there. We spend HOURS and DAYS trying to make things work. Lost hours and days of time working on bases, ships, etc...only to lose them due to bugs. The neat screenshots and videos you see? Most of your experience will be just trying to keep the game running.

This speaks for itself.Don't buy this game. You'll regret it.

number of helpful: 15 of 26 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17
Early Access Review
								I have had this game since just after planets came out, and I loved playing it. It always had bugs, but they were tolerable and not game breaking. As you play and develop more complex things, more bugs keep showing themselves.  The developers are good about coming out with updates every week, but somehow the game just seems to be getting more buggy. They will fix some bugs, then 3 or 4 updates later the same things break again. Sorry Keen, this is a great idea for a game and I got some great times playing it, but I cannot recommend it anymore. I sincerely hope the issues get fixed, and will try back in a couple of months.

number of helpful: 28 of 51 people (55%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								This review is based on the lifetime of the game thus far.  Early Access is understandable, and things are going to break and become buggy.  Everyone that's buying EA games should know this, and it's written as disclaimers in a lot of games prior to even playing it.The Developers of this game have always operated under the idea that people want content, and more content they shall have.  I don't believe this is actually to please their fanbase, but it's more of an in house quota that they're trying to meet as a business.I am not recommending this game to anyone that's currently thinking about purchasing this game.  I am also recommending that anyone who has played this game for a relatively long time that has written a review, or is thinking about writting a review to give your true honest opinion for whether or not you recommend this game given the track record of the company.I will say the cliche thing that you read time and time again, "I really want to recommend this game and give it a positive review, but with it's current state I feel I cannot."  However, the current state that is being referenced is not just this weeks most recent Forced Update (the game needs PATCHES, not updates) but more so how this game has been pumped with more content than it can currently handle given the underlying bugs from previous content pushes.I will change my review at a later date if the KeenSWH developers start polishing up the current state of the game, and by polish I mean, don't add new content, don't change animations, don't give us new sounds.  Putting lipstick on a pig, still makes it a pig, and the people that understand that will not stick around and endorse your game to their friends and especially not on an Anonymous Review board.TL:DR - Don't buy it.  Don't let the 91% positive feedback rating persuade you into thinking that the developers listen to their fanbase.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								Already fun!In creative mode it gets boring quite fast as there is not that many components yet, but it does allow you to tweaka and test designs so you know what to build.In survival, building a large ship requires a lot of ore, so it will take some time to get it going.Which is great as you can create the framework and then work together in multplayer to fill it in.Inventory management is a bit of a pain, but hopefully the process will be improved in future patches.The refinery supplies directly to the assembler, but currently that is the only autmated process.It would be very helpfull if one or more storage container could be used to handle the input and output.Also moving the ore from your drills to the storage on a platform or large ship would be very helpfull.A collector hooked to a container and a jettison option on the drill could solve the problem in a realistic way.It could also allow for slightly more efficient mining with all the small blobs or ores floating around during mining.Creating a mobile gravity platform with collectors on it would automatically scoop up everything and place it into connected storage (or just require a little bit of sweeping or kicking the ore around to get it all in there).It's early access so I expected a few problems, but so far only storage management and the slow auto-save are the only two. The rest is solid and fun.I am looking forward to what the future brings for space engineers!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Space Engineers is the epiphany of what Legos in Space would be, you can create from the most simple ship with barely anything but your imagination, to a Hulking behemoth-class capital ship that could rival with the deathstar itself, the potential offered in this game is gigantic, and its very well playable despite being on alpha stage (at the moment of this review). The creative mode allows you to create at your hearth's content without worries of materials or energy usage, and the survival mode requires critical thinking by the number of materials you can get, energy consumption, meteor showers and the size of your ship based on your ability to micromanage each and every resource, and to have at least some degree of anticipation for a backup plan in case something goes wrong. Lastly, the online space battles while are limited for now in resources and needs optimization, do not dissapoint, specially on the collision models, just looking at the capital ships with major damages and still battling is enough to keep you entertained for lasting hours.edit: oh and you can mod the game on steam workshop, which i ve found easy to use!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Space Engineers is actually an impressive and  indepth space survival building and simulation space design concept. If you like building with creativity and making impressive Ships, Structures, Stations, Systems and work in a team this is the game for you. I find SE as the most realistic asteroid multiplayer exporation and realistic simulation I have played thus far.The game is complex and equipped with indeepth material, you will have survive and gather materials and think how to use realistic concepts such as energy, rotors, wheels, thursters, gravity generators, refinaries, assemblers, conveyors, solar panels, grinders, welders.You will have to survive asteroid showers or to capture anomaly npc ships that fly by or engage in pvp. Trust me you dont just pick up a rifle and hike in space...If you like to just pop in for 5 minutes blast around in other games and have a 15 second attention span this game is not for you.I highly reccomend to detailed and inclined gamers that use intelligence in all aspects of life not just in a game.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								After attempting to play this game multiple times with friends I can honestly say there is something interesting there.  However you have to dig through a mountain of bugs and glitches to be able to play anything on multiplayer at all.  Solo play seems to be a bit more stable.  My biggest complaint is that I shouldn't be punished if the game crashes when playing multiplayer.  I've built bases time and again only to have some glitch crash the game.  Oh you want to log back in to the base you've spent an hour building....sorry here's a new lander.  Oh you found the landscape where you had originally built your base to land.  Whoops your entire base has been wiped from the server.Theres a good game there if it actually worked

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game has most of the features I've been waiting to see in a single game for along time now. If you ask anyone else, They will compare this game to Minecraft. And for good reasons. However, this game (even in its early access alpha) has far greater potential. Anything you build, can fly. (provided the design includes necessary blocks) even your base. In its current state, the game is playable. Play some Single player Asteroids then when you're good, Jump into some online games.I can only think of a few downsides to new comers.1-Learning curve. This game takes sometime to get use to. I recommend practicing your controls.2-As of the time that I am writing this, The game has some poor optimization. Don't let that deture you. The game is worth it. and will improve over time. 3-This game can be one hell of a time sink.Other then those few problems and others that aren't worth mentioning. Updates and patchs are weekly (Thursday mornings) players look to patch days like early Christmas.

content:

Early Access Review
								If you grew up with lego's, or you simply just love constructing and deconstructing things, or just blowing up your creations... This game is for YOU. This is probably the best $15 bucks I've spent yet on any Early Access Game. The developers are pushing updates out like hotcakes, at least 1 big update every 1-2weeks. The game is very playable, and has plenty of workshop content to keep you in awe. All your favorite sci-fi shows, movies, books and the like are available to be made or looked at from other peoples creations. Battlestar Galactica? Check! Star Wars? Check! Star Strek? Check! Starship Troopers? Check! Star Citizen? Check! You name it, you'll find it in the workshop from somebody already exploring ways on how to create it and make it to scale and share with the community. Or why not just built it yourself? It's all here and available to YOU. Don't hesitate, if you've been on the fence like I was, just BUY it! You won't regret it.

Without counter thrusters, gyroscopes and either too much or too little mass, you wont be able to do much with your ship.I like this game. Def got my upvote.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Let me first say that regardless of my small playtime in this game, I've still been keeping tabs on the development and workings of it.Quite honestly, this game is the model by which all other early access indie games should abide by.Most early access games will put out a game and do a billion bug fixes in their update and/or attempt to release some new content that just leads to loads more bugs to fix, and they all rely on the excuse "Oh, but it's early access." These guys are not the same. Although things do have their bugs (as does all code), the developers of this game always tend to pump out new things that add another nice element to the game in addition to fixing the bugs that may have existed from older builds.What's even better about it is that bugs are far less common in this game than in other early access games! It's great to see quality work in such a small span of time (every 7 days or so). This shows me that there are still some indie devs out there that don't take complete advantage of the "Well, it's an alpha" excuse, which is such a rarity amongst the top indie game devs (no offense to them, I'm only speaking my honest opinion). Due to this, I can confidently say that even though this game is amongst the top selling steam games, I truly think it deserves more attention and credit that it already has. Why? I've just explained it all to you, but allow me to list it:1.) Consistent weekly updates2.) Clean work-even though their updates are weekly, they're not sloppy or just tossed in to satisfy the consumer3.) When bugs do arise, they fix them in a timely manner4.) This game has immense potential to be an amazing sandbox experience, and is already pretty awesome as isNow everyone who reads this might say "Oh, stop kissing the devs asses so much!" To that, all I have to say is, "Why?" This game deserves every bit of praise I gave it. People may try to bring up this bug and that bug, but in the end, this is an early access game done right. No ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, no "It's alpha, so it's okay if there's loads of bugs, many of which may break the game", no waiting horribly long for updates, nothing but quality work. If the devs of this game can do this, I don't see why other indie devs cannot, especially when this game isn't even recieving as much attention as some others.Those working on this game put in truly hard work, no matter who you compare them to. If that's not worth the 20 bucks, then I don't know what is. A sincere "thank you" to the devs for keeping my hopes in quality indie game devloping alive.*Disclaimer*Don't get me wrong, there are some other good indie developers out there, just not many, and this is just the team that got my attention.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Extremely fun space game!As far as I know it's the only game based in space with real physics, this is an excellent game and can be ran on medium spec computers without any issues. Considering this is an early access game it has a very little amount of bugs and it's rare they'll happen. The game feels like it's influenced somewhat from Minecraft however it's still got a good level of detail.The game is extremely fun and realistic but not too realistic on survival but creative is great for learning what everything does.It's kinda a spacey sandbox game, you can build whatever you want out of blocks and ship parts and fly your ship around to do whatever you want however it'd be nice if you could do more in this game ( I understand that it's early access and this game is updated all the time.)It's definitely worth buying this game at this state and it's more than worth the money, if only my friends could run it with their terrible computers I'd be playing it more. This game is great for killing time and if I could get friends to play it'd be even more fun for longer, this game has real potential it just needs time.10/10 This game is awesome the way it combines realistic physics with building blocks is fun in a way.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								When it comes to survival games, Space Engineers is very well done. I've spent more time than I like to admit on this game due to the fact that it allows for a challenging, but rewarding experience. As a space engineer, you are unable to perform too many tasks on your own, as your inventory is severely limited and welding/grinding/mining speeds are too slow for massive builds. While that may sound as a bad thing, it is quite the opposite! It forces you to build ships/contraptions to perform the tasks for you, which is an aspect of the game that I really enjoy. If you think you're mining too slow, build a bigger/more efficient ship! If it's taking hours to weld your base, create a ship that can hold more building components and weld faster.Overall, I highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Update July 2014  While the game is still missing some key features, It's a great buy.  Of the Early Access games I've gotten it has by far the most substantial updates on a regular basis.  Update March 2014 Now with Survival & Multi-Player. Well the game had multiplayer before, and it still has a long way to go on that front, it's buggy, prone to lag issues, as well as lacking some obvious multiplayer features. However the update is a big step in the right direction. There are still a lot of things that clearly don't work as intended, or are just poorly balanced, but it's easy to spend quite a few hours in this game, and have a fun time.Feb. 2014 I picked up Space Engineers because it looks interesting and was on sale, so why not.  I have to say if you are thinking about getting this, and want a playable game, you would be better to wait.  It's not so much a game as a somewhat buggy physics demo with an editor.  It's a pretty rough alpha, and not as playable as it looks in the videos.  You don't get to see the game breaking lag you will encounter in multiplayer when anything interesting happens, or all the graphics glitches.  There are much better games you can get now for $10, and come back in a year to see if this one has delivered on its potential.  I'm not saying it's bad, it's just not a game yet.      This is a rather negative review, so you might ask 'why the thumbs up?'.  This one should definitely be on your watch list if you have an interest in space games.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								Let me preface this by saying that I have over 275 hours logged at the time of writing this.  I purchased the game right before 1.033 was released and I have never regretted it.Space Engineers is an absolutely fantastic game where the only limits to what you can build is that of your imagination, and engineering skills to make everything fit together exactly how you want it.  If you enjoy Minecraft, but find it unrewarding or unchallenging, this might be a good step for you.  If Starmade felt too simplistic or too blocky and unrealistic, Space Engineers can fill that gap.Space Engineers is clearly labeled as an alpha game, so don't let 1.0 versions fool you.  The very nature of the game makes it rather performance intensive, stacked with the lack of optimization due to more and more content being pushed every week.  I'd recommend you have a beefy system, or be prepared to deal with a slide show, before purchasing.  There are too many people who whine and beg for optimization that isn't coming because they want it to.  Being an alpha, stuff is unstable in multiplayer, a lot.  Stuff can break, float off, spontaneously explode, or just quit working.  Play on dedicated servers with caution.Now Sierra, what's so great about this game after all that?Well, for one, you can build capital warships, and then take them against hostile craft or duel your friends.  Build a milenium falcon replica!  The limits of what you can create is your own imagination and your CPU strength.Instant-build too easy for you?  Try out survival mode where you have to aquire the resources & refine them.  Make the compoments, and then weld every block.  You don't just build ships piece by piece, you build each block, piece by piece.  There's a lot of respect for large, amazingly detailed capital ships done in creative, but the ones done in survival, although rarely as big, carry a lot more prestige knowing that ship literally came out of an asteroid.You wanna build your UNSC Infinity replica in survival?  Good on you and good luck!  Manage your full production process from mining and refining the ores to manufacturing and welding on the components to laying down the ship's framework for the welding crews if you have help.  Improve your efficiency by building small, and later large ships to drill, weld and grind.  Build small strike fighters and later larger frigates to defend your operations.You can build a small mining colony or a huge piracy empire.  Play alone, with friends, or on larger servers where the targets are almost limitless.  Watch out for griefers though, who will try and steal your stuff for themselves.  Throw up some guns, stockpile a bunch of ammunition, and show them who's boss!Whatever you do with this game, may you find many many hours of enjoyment in it.  Hope I was able to be of some use to people.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								Updated Review even though i said i wouldn't...So, after over 2000+ hours shown, and the other 300-400 i've played on another account... I have to say i still enjoy this game considerably. The dev's do keep track of bugs and fix them accordingly. There are of course bugs and things still in the game, but games have bugs, crashes etc, you can't judge a game based on just that. Gameplay wise, lots has changed, new blocks, new controls, new features, just so much more new stuff in general that you have to play to get your hands on... literally. There have been vast improvements from when i first played (below) and now, the game went from unplayable due to net-code and now it's playable again for me. So huge props to the dev's for looking out for all the players who were unable to play when the netcode changed!I don't really have much more to say because it really is just such a nice game to play. So just grab it, and enjoy building ships for no reason at all :)All in all, I don't think I could recommend a game better, because nothing is even close to this game. space is virtually unlimited, you can go to the GPS point for Billion, Billion, Billion and the game still runs fine. and if that isn't enough, you have multiplayer, for space battles and factions, and really just a huge amount of space to do whatever you want. it's a true Space Sandbox and I don't think anything will be on a similar scale anytime soon.I am also a server admin and have made a few mods for the game as well, so my experience is from all sides. I truly love playing this game, and I hope you will too!P.S. my server is called Hydro Survival if you are ever interested in playing mp! :)OLD REVIEW:"To start, this is a great game in it's alpha stage, granted it's been in alpha for a long time, I still have managed to rack up 300+ hours in-game. It's great in both Single player and Multiplayer, although it's a bit lacking in Single Player due to there not being alot of 'campaign' type maps to play. The focus is to really just enjoy yourself, build a base, a ship, etc. This is better with friends obviously, as you get kind of bored doing everything alone. The game has weekly updates for being in alpha, and while it is still in alpha stages, it's very much playable and enjoyable.Please take note that it is an alpha game and WILL have bugs and glitches, which are usually fixed, and new things are added, so new bugs/glitches appear. This is an alpha game and it is expected, and known that you WILL find bugs and glitches in-game. The developers are great, adding player requested features, and weekly updates fixing bugs and adding new features, which I take it as a challenge to break the game because I enjoy blowing things up... multiple times.All in all, it is a great game and very much worth it's price. If you enjoy 'creative' building games, and wish you could fly into limitless space while stopping on planets and asteroids for resources, or just want to play with friends and build a huge base in the mountains, this game is for you!Note: As stated, this is still an alpha game, and all review content in this review is for the alpha stage, which is known to have bugs and/or glitches in this state. This will not be updated and a new review will be posted as the game is fully released. "

content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								The developers choose to ignorantly add in new features and fix minor bugs rather than focus on issues which have plagued this game from the beginning. The vast possibilities of this game lie in multiplayer, which is ultimately broken and always has been. No substantial changes have been made to remedy this. Instead, new features are added and tested at what seems like a very minimal standard *on single player* (or maybe LAN).Players do not find it fun to put countless hours into creating complex grids to watch them randomly, without propulsion, and without any force applied, fly off into the depths of space. Or have a ship using landing gear suddenly fly through 3 layers of a station's hull and tear up hours of timing, piston control, and power management.Most of us generally understand how things like pistons and rotors work; push/pull and rotate, respectively. We definitely do not understand how, sitting there idle, on default values, on a stationary base, on a planet... these things explode and launch what it's connected to off into the distance or directly at the long grind of a construct ripping holes through and auto-destroying all it comes in contact with.Taking a look at their forums, several solo fan boys cheer them on. Several others voice their 'lesser' opinions. When requested to fix these ongoing issues with multiplayer (the true potential of the game), they are either ignored... OR DIRECTED TO THEIR CODE REPO! The developers are asshats. We are the gamers; the players. We are the END-USERS; the CUSTOMERS. We are not their code-lackeys. We have Steam. Then there's their own forums. They also want to throw in their repo? NEWSFLASH: when customers are looking to purchase or further support your product, we're looking at the point of sale and possibly a forum. Both of these being either ignored or deflected by the developers is an extremely poor practice.Until they fix what is actually important before adding in new shinies, I CANNOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME. That truly sucks because I have a group of friends who have been asking about Space Engineers for more than 9 months now. I know the devs couldn't give less of a crap about the little drop of 3-5 more sales in their large bucket of a scam but there's people out there waiting for some stability.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Where do I even begin on this AMAZING fantastic piece of GOLD!?!?! The physics are incredible, the controls are simple, easy to use, and I got used to them in 5 minutes, the gameplay is fun, explorotive, full of new experience everytime, and it is an overall GREAT game! Things you can do: I have built a ship and flown it, I've flown ships into other ships and watched while I was inside, I've built a ship online, and then watched it get blasted, exploded, and BOOMED across the map by other players!!!PROS: 1. Endless possibilities 2. Weapons and turrets 3. Great and fun gameplay 4. You don't have to mess with that advanced "server" crap, you can just start a game, choose how many players can join, and play and it's online!!! 5. Creative and survival modes 6. EXPLOSIONS, CRASHES, BOOMS, DENTS, SCRATCHES, AND OVER-THE-TOP MAYHEM 7. You can have UNLIMITED sized worlds and travel forever 8. Color all building pieces to make complete customizability (And not just default colors, you can CHOOSE and mix colors on a big color square) 9. Lighting is awesome (in my opinion). You can choose the radius, intensity, and color of lights!! 10 You can have hundreds of ships in ONE GAME!!! Make stations and ships and dock them, or crash them into the stations!!! 11. It is pretty cheap for everything that's in the game...20 dollars!!! (18 dollars if you're reading this during the summer sales)CONS: 1. I've been missing out for a long time now.......that's it for CONS!!!Everyone should get this game if you're into sandbox, destruction, explosions, guns, building, third person and first person, and multiplayer!!! This is a quality....QUA-LI-TY game!!! Get it...NOW!!!

content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								I highly recommend the game for those who are fans of the study of cosmology and other astronomical subjects. This game is a excellent game where you can build any type of space ship you want. Great game to play together to survive the meteor showers and for building up your own economical base.The game has good graphics, doesn`t glitch, and has frequent updating. In updates they add very good items such as sensors and newer cockpits and other building materials. I find the idea amazing of producing artificial gravity in a environment containing microgravity, the idea is great. They made the physics of this game realistic (such as the moment of Inertia, and that there is no friction in space). In the loading screen there is something to read (quotes from Astronomers like Galileo Galilei, Isaac Newton, and many others) instead of just having a screen with a picture and a sign saying: Loading...MAIN COMMENT: Good game, good physics, good ideas, great building materials (being expanded every month), and plenty of settings to create a environment which you would want. Highly recommend for astronomy/physics/space fans.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game has most of the features I've been waiting to see in a single game for along time now. If you ask anyone else, They will compare this game to Minecraft. And for good reasons. However, this game (even in its early access alpha) has far greater potential. Anything you build, can fly. (provided the design includes necessary blocks) even your base. In its current state, the game is playable. Play some Single player Asteroids then when you're good, Jump into some online games.I can only think of a few downsides to new comers.1-Learning curve. This game takes sometime to get use to. I recommend practicing your controls.2-As of the time that I am writing this, The game has some poor optimization. Don't let that deture you. The game is worth it. and will improve over time. 3-This game can be one hell of a time sink.Other then those few problems and others that aren't worth mentioning. Updates and patchs are weekly (Thursday mornings) players look to patch days like early Christmas.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								Even though this game is still in alpha at the time of this review and there is much more to be done, this game is amazing. You can compare the block styles to be similar to minecraft, only without the ugly undetailed textures. Features like being able to build anything you want and piloting it, and to destroy it with full destruction, you can either leave a ship/station full of holes or split them apart anyway you like. The potential for this game is huge and it will be extremely fun to build custom fleets to play with your friends. Once the game is finished and the developers fix the current issues. It will be a very likely 10/10 game. But I personally recommend it if you love zero gravity, building and destroying things.
