content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you like simulation games with a sense of realism and few limits this is the game for you. The physics engin in fantastic, the building system is easy and complicated all at the same time. Mining and looking for resources isn't unbearable. And the energy system with reactors and solar panels offers many options. I love the survival mode but Creative is a great way to stretch your imagination and make something epic or a world to play survival in. The ability to switch game settings and options for saved worlds makes saved games very replayable and customizable. 8.5/10 The only thing missing from this game is some PVP modes not just PVP servers and is missing mobs. Who doesn't like fighting aliens or space worm infested astroids?

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								Great potential wasted:tldr: nice ship building, but as soon as you have 5 there is huge lag; lots of bugspositive:-space survival with resources, build your own ships, moderate level of realism-mod support-turing complete through programmable block-graphics look very nicenegative:-bugs, bugs, more bugs (like thrusters randomly stop working, drills that are full make resources disappear when you continue drilling, rotors and pistons unusable because they start glichy movements that ultimately make everything explode, ...)-very bad graphics engine, eats resources as ♥♥♥♥, seems to be programmed by a unexperienced person as there are many flaws in it that experienced people would have never put in it: graphics engine is bound to physics (no interpolation) -> max 60fps, still feels jittery ->not even smoothly playable on a high end pc-very bad physics engine, again not well engineered, eats resources, is laggy, has lots of flaws that cause ship damage for seemingly no reason, no relative calculations -> gets worse the higher the speed-ship speed limit 100m/s ?????? This is SPACE there is no speed limit (except speed of light), if you mod the speed limit higher everything gets even buggier-small and large ships: every block should be able to be placed small and large on every grid, but again the programmers dont seem to have a high enough experience level to do this-planets: nice idea but eats even more resources, is even buggier etc.-weapons feel like placeholders; you can shoot yourself with your own missile because bugs-wants to be realistic on the one side and on the other side has some very unrealistic features such as your space suit braking a LOT faster than it accelerates, the jump drive that was only introduced because they couldnt fix physics for a higher speed limit, asteroids dont have gravity and all move 0 relative to all other asteroids and planets, static friction with the vacuum at very low speeds or 0 speed, ...edit after big multiplayer and graphics update (Dec 2016):graphics now look very nice, but need even more resouces. Its still buggy as hell (except multiplayer bugs, they were reduced by about 80%)(If I find an issue fixed, i will remove it from the list as soon as i notice)

								I bought this game a few years ago thinking it was going to be just Minecraft in space, and it is. Now you're thinking "baahh go away poor kid" but we are the silent majority.If you're an adult with a disposable income, go ahead and buy. Otherwise, you better keep your money in your wallet until you get a new computer.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Space exploration is the ongoing discovery and exploration of celestial structures in outer space by means of continuously evolving and growing space technology. While the study of space is carried out mainly by astronomers with telescopes, the physical exploration of space is conducted both by unmanned robotic probes and human spaceflight.While the observation of objects in space, known as astronomy, predates reliable recorded history, it was the development of large and relatively efficient rockets during the early 20th century that allowed physical space exploration to become a reality. Common rationales for exploring space include advancing scientific research, uniting different nations, ensuring the future survival of humanity and developing military and strategic advantages against other countries.Space exploration has often been used as a proxy competition for geopolitical rivalries such as the Cold War. The early era of space exploration was driven by a "Space Race" between the Soviet Union and the United States, the launch of the first man-made object to orbit the Earth, the USSR's Sputnik 1, on 4 October 1957, and the first Moon landing by the American Apollo 11 craft on 20 July 1969 are often taken as landmarks for this initial period. The Soviet space program achieved many of the first milestones, including the first living being in orbit in 1957, the first human spaceflight (Yuri Gagarin aboard Vostok 1) in 1961, the first spacewalk (by Aleksei Leonov) on 18 March 1965, the first automatic landing on another celestial body in 1966, and the launch of the first space station (Salyut 1) in 1971.After the first 20 years of exploration, focus shifted from one-off flights to renewable hardware, such as the Space Shuttle program, and from competition to cooperation as with the International Space Station (ISS).With the substantial completion of the ISS[1] following STS-133 in March 2011, plans for space exploration by the USA remain in flux. Constellation, a Bush Administration program for a return to the Moon by 2020[2] was judged inadequately funded and unrealistic by an expert review panel reporting in 2009.[3] The Obama Administration proposed a revision of Constellation in 2010 to focus on the development of the capability for crewed missions beyond low earth orbit (LEO), envisioning extending the operation of the ISS beyond 2020, transferring the development of launch vehicles for human crews from NASA to the private sector, and developing technology to enable missions to beyond LEO, such as Earth/Moon L1, the Moon, Earth/Sun L2, near-earth asteroids, and Phobos or Mars orbit.[4] As of March 2011, the US Senate and House of Representatives are still working towards a compromise NASA funding bill, which will probably terminate Constellation and fund development of a heavy lift launch vehicle (HLLV).[5]In the 2000s, the People's Republic of China initiated a successful manned spaceflight program, while the European Union, Japan, and India have also planned future manned space missions. China, Russia, Japan, and India have advocated manned missions to the Moon during the 21st century, while the European Union has advocated manned missions to both the Moon and Mars during the 21st century.From the 1990s onwards, private interests began promoting space tourism and then private space exploration of the Moon (see Google Lunar X Prize).

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								Unfortunately I've had to rereview this game. Intially it was one of my favorite early access titles, boasting some interesting features not seen elsewhere and a decent clip to the development pace.However over the last year or so the game hasn't really improved much. It's become more and more buggy and unplayable with every update, and the only really significant feature added has been planets. The game is barren of almost any core gameplay or content, leaving you with very little to do in the off chance you actually manage to get the thing to run and move past building your inital base and miner.The Creative mode is fairly fun, but there's only so many hours of entertainment availble from minecraft in space using far less parts to work with, and the game has trouble handling truly massive constructions. Plus with the multiplayer as buggy as it is, you're fairly well relegated to building things on your own and not showing them to people.This game could be a really amazing survival/builder game, as well as a very interesting pvp game, but there's no indication it's ever going to become bug free enough to reliably play online, let alone actually get the features needed to support such gameplay.Do NOT buy this game until some point in the distant future when it actually has some core gameplay and isn't more bugs than game, or it's been abandoned and you decide you're ok with paying whatever price it is for an unfinished product.Edit: Hadn't seen the latest update when I wrote this. Holy ♥♥♥♥ this just gets even more unplayable every update. Even if we could keep a server running for more than five minutes the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ dog update would make the game impossible to play.Edit:2 it's been what, almost two years since I wrote this review? Well it's still true. The progress on the game continues at a snails pace and there's more bugs than actual gameplay.If the devs would calm the ♥♥♥♥ down on gamebreaking new features and bug fix for two more years maybe this POS will be as playable as it was when I first bought it three years ago once more.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Space Engineers is one of those games that does it right for an Early Access title.Yes, the game may have bugs and yes, you are most likely to experience them.But unlike other reviews on this game, you cannot forget that you are playing an Early Access game.I don't get why everyone is giving this game bad reviews because of the bugs, unless they somehow expected a bug free environment from an early access title?Space Engineers gets updated every week on Thursday, and the developers tend to have sleepless nights to make sure they deliver an update every Thursday.Recently, planets where added to this game, and man, did they deliver.It's enjoy-full to see how this game has progressed so far -- We went from building ships and then crashing them in single player, to playing survival with friends (or crashing ships with friends) and now, we get to do it all over again, but on beautiful looking planets!Not satisfied with that? Then take your ship and go land on an alien planet, and do your best to stay alive against those "space spiders"!MultiplayerMultiplayer was added along the way to this game, as the community desired it the most.This resulted in KSH getting it added as soon as possible, which while it works, it does glitch out, but have no fear.The multiplayer is being re-worked completely and we can already see the effects from this. (EG: Space Master Mode)PlanetsAlot of users have been complaining about the performance with planets, and I guess it was slightly expected that they would have a decent performance hit.Sadly, this performance hit can make the game unplayable for most users (Altho, I don't have any issue with running them.)What does sadden me, is that people started to give negative reviews to the game because of this, claiming "they broke the game completely", but this is so incorrect.You can always just launch a world without planets (There is literately nothing preventing you from doing this),  and continue playing like you did before. And then just wait until the game receives more optimization.ConclusionFor me, this game is one of the best space building/survival type game i've played so far.Seeing the progress this game has made when it first went onto Early Access to where we are now, is quite impressive.The developers are focused and never fail to deliver new content every weekIf anyone would ask me to recommend this game, I'd give a big thumbs up and say yes....And then blow them up with my ship "Athena".

content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is really fun to play with your friends, and i know i dont have so many hours played on it, but just in the beginning of the game it was pretty fun, it takes some time to figure out the basics like fuel for you ship, how to mine, building and all that stuff. But once you know how to play the game, its fun to survive. And of course you can also ♥♥♥♥ the whole galaxy up with some crazy killer ship you build in creative mode. This game also have some random things sometimes like meteors shooting down places (you can turn those off if you dont like randomly loosing something on your ship/station or dying) Theres also other ships that will just fly in randomly like private sails and commercial satelites (of course you can turn them off) that has sentry guns that will shoot you if you get too close, and lets not forget you get to choose if you want a small, large or extreme amount of asteroids. Multiplayer is also REALLY fun both with friends and random people, survival is hard in the beginning, but becomes fun after you get more experienced while creative is fun from the beginning, but i would recommend watching the tutorial because it has some really usefull stuff. And i havent incountered any bugs yet. I give this game 9/10 because i really enjoyed the time i have played it, but i would love to see some more character animations.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								Please take notice that this is my very first reveiw of a steam game, so if I write this incorrectly please bear with me. Thanks!With that out of the way... I would really love to recommend this game, I really would.  The graphics are great, the physics are superb; and the multitude of fantastic creations by other people really makes it exciting.  But I cannot recommend it for one simple reason; Space engineers is nigh-impossible for beginners.  Its a paradox, I know that, but its true.  To start with, the tutorials are broken. Plain and simple.  I don't know if this is a weird/freak personal experience or not, but both the conveyors tutorial (#4), and the conveyors in the game proper cannot be placed.  The "small conveyor tube", an item essential to both the tutorial and the game itself literally do not exist in the inventory and there is no help on how to acquire them.  Additionally there are other known problems with the power tutorial and some other issues with the game.  Feel free to shoot me a message if you know how to fix this, until then... I have to say DO NOT BUY at anywhere close to full price.Pros-Great GraphicsPhysics is excellentLooks fun and engagingMod workshop Allows for creativityCons-Tutorials are brokenUI is counterintuitive and confusing at timesItems do not work properly (conveyors)No help from game on how to find different types of items in inventorySo far very few bug fixes...

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								Space Engineers is a fantastic game, and it excels in offering a somewhat realistic, fun, and creative experience. It's damage engine is unparalleled, creating dents, rips, and holes in the game's wide variety of blocks. In Space Engineers the player can create an infinite variety of space stations, large ships, and small ships. The player can play in creative mode, with infinite materials and electricity, or in survival mode where they must manage resources, electricity, and pprotect themselves from a variety of "cargo ships," ranging from unarmed small ships, to massive ships covered in weapons. Space engineers also offers a unique multiplayer mode in which players can work together to create ships and stations, or battle each other.PROS:- Very fun- high replayability- great physics engine- AMAZING damage engine- fun combat- fun singleplayer-fun multiplayer-lots of updates-Steam workshop compatability- highly customizeable world generationCONS:- some glitches (especially in muliplayer)- difficult to understand in the beginning if you don't have much experience with this kind of gameOverall rating:     Gameplay: 8/10     Multiplayer: 8/10     Singleplayer: 10/10     Content: 9.5/10     Mechanics: 9.5/10    TOTAL: 45/50

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is easily one of the bext examples of a early-access game done right. Content is regular, fast-paced, community inspired, responsive, well made, well presented, shockingly stable for such a rough and quickly building game, and the core premise is itself excellent. Mod support is already enacted, and the community isn't half bad and is very energetic.I speak no hyperbole when I say this is easily the best space sim sandbox I have played, and I cannot imagine a contender with even close to the same level of freedom.If you catch it on sale, it's a must-grab. For $20, anyone with even a passing interest in building-type games will want it, and anyone who has ever wanted to be a space man will love it.

								This is like Minecraft evolved, in space. The basics are the same: Mine, refine, build, repeat, but with the complexity cranked up  (Along with the upper limit of creativity) to 11. In other words, the new "Adult" Minecraft.With that said, some things are far too clumsy in Early access, there is less directed "game" than MC (No bosses to find and slay), and starting out is extremely rough, but I can see this going to amazing places. Also, the controls are atrocious but can be rebound in less than 2 mins easily enough. (Also it supports extra mouse buttons!!!)I hope there is a game roadmap somewhere, or will be soon. My only concern is what kind of polish and additional features the devs plan but even what's there now in EA is worth the price.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								I bought this game a few years ago thinking it was going to be just Minecraft in space, and it is. It's a really good game.However, KSH has evolved the specs over time, rendering the game unplayable with my hardware, even on legacy mode. It's just one big benchmark/slideshow for my card nowadays because there are no efforts being placed for serious optimization or even just a low-graphics mode (low-poly everything, minimum shaders).I cannot refund the game since it has been such a long time, Even if I upgraded my computer, my brother would require the hardware upgrade as well, amounting the upgrade costs to be roughly $400 just to play this game. Now you're thinking "baahh go away poor kid" but we are the silent majority.If you're an adult with a disposable income, go ahead and buy. Otherwise, you better keep your money in your wallet until you get a new computer.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								Unfortunately I've had to rereview this game. Intially it was one of my favorite early access titles, boasting some interesting features not seen elsewhere and a decent clip to the development pace.However over the last year or so the game hasn't really improved much. It's become more and more buggy and unplayable with every update, and the only really significant feature added has been planets. The game is barren of almost any core gameplay or content, leaving you with very little to do in the off chance you actually manage to get the thing to run and move past building your inital base and miner.The Creative mode is fairly fun, but there's only so many hours of entertainment availble from minecraft in space using far less parts to work with, and the game has trouble handling truly massive constructions. Plus with the multiplayer as buggy as it is, you're fairly well relegated to building things on your own and not showing them to people.This game could be a really amazing survival/builder game, as well as a very interesting pvp game, but there's no indication it's ever going to become bug free enough to reliably play online, let alone actually get the features needed to support such gameplay.Do NOT buy this game until some point in the distant future when it actually has some core gameplay and isn't more bugs than game, or it's been abandoned and you decide you're ok with paying whatever price it is for an unfinished product.Edit: Hadn't seen the latest update when I wrote this. Holy ♥♥♥♥ this just gets even more unplayable every update. Even if we could keep a server running for more than five minutes the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ dog update would make the game impossible to play.Edit:2 it's been what, almost two years since I wrote this review? Well it's still true. The progress on the game continues at a snails pace and there's more bugs than actual gameplay.If the devs would calm the ♥♥♥♥ down on gamebreaking new features and bug fix for two more years maybe this POS will be as playable as it was when I first bought it three years ago once more.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Space Engineers is one of those games that does it right for an Early Access title.Yes, the game may have bugs and yes, you are most likely to experience them.But unlike other reviews on this game, you cannot forget that you are playing an Early Access game.I don't get why everyone is giving this game bad reviews because of the bugs, unless they somehow expected a bug free environment from an early access title?Space Engineers gets updated every week on Thursday, and the developers tend to have sleepless nights to make sure they deliver an update every Thursday.Recently, planets where added to this game, and man, did they deliver.It's enjoy-full to see how this game has progressed so far -- We went from building ships and then crashing them in single player, to playing survival with friends (or crashing ships with friends) and now, we get to do it all over again, but on beautiful looking planets!Not satisfied with that? Then take your ship and go land on an alien planet, and do your best to stay alive against those "space spiders"!MultiplayerMultiplayer was added along the way to this game, as the community desired it the most.This resulted in KSH getting it added as soon as possible, which while it works, it does glitch out, but have no fear.The multiplayer is being re-worked completely and we can already see the effects from this. (EG: Space Master Mode)PlanetsAlot of users have been complaining about the performance with planets, and I guess it was slightly expected that they would have a decent performance hit.Sadly, this performance hit can make the game unplayable for most users (Altho, I don't have any issue with running them.)What does sadden me, is that people started to give negative reviews to the game because of this, claiming "they broke the game completely", but this is so incorrect.You can always just launch a world without planets (There is literately nothing preventing you from doing this),  and continue playing like you did before. And then just wait until the game receives more optimization.ConclusionFor me, this game is one of the best space building/survival type game i've played so far.Seeing the progress this game has made when it first went onto Early Access to where we are now, is quite impressive.The developers are focused and never fail to deliver new content every weekIf anyone would ask me to recommend this game, I'd give a big thumbs up and say yes....And then blow them up with my ship "Athena".

content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								EDIT: 12/22/2016Just recently there was a very large update to the game's multiplayer infrastructure. I participated in beta testing and have played the new update a little bit. I will be playing a bit more before coming to a final conclusion, but many of the issues addressed in this review have been more or less fixed from what I can tell thus far. Only time will tell. For now, this review will remain negative, but that may change soon.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ORIGINAL REVIEW: 7/13/2016Unfortunately, as of right now I cannot recommend this game to anyone who wishes to play with anybody but themselves. I can sum it up like this: would you want to be in the barren wasteland of space alone? Probably not.Should you play with friends, the inability to walk in a moving ship, the broken state of planets, the lack of ability to just build something massive and cool, all of that is gone. You will never be able to play this game at a decent framerate, nor will your server be able to handle anything more than about 20 blocks long and 20 blocks wide.I had fun with this game, and I really want to like it and recommend it, but until something is figured out to make it worth it to someone without a ridiculous rig or has some sort of managable multiplayer, I don't think it's worth the money.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								So this is about space. About you being a little guy / gal on your own to build. Why? I dont know, build what? Basically whatever you want. No real plot, But it works out well.  You can start in many differnt ways, but I wanted to get a feel for the 'whole' of the game, so I started in Survival mode, ( limited resources ) in a Rescue ship.  This starts you with a ship that has all the basics you need to get going, and about 15 minutes of flight time on fuel. I have been expirementing and working on learning how things do what. Its pretty amazing what all can be built.A good little game to mess with. Granted, all you do right now is mine, build and you can go after NPC ships, or online vs other people, so it may not hold your attention forever, but its well worth the time to try it out. Just remember, in space, its a cold lonely death if you fail...

content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Space engineers is perhaps the greatest sandbox game ever invented.As the name suggests, it's all about space, there are spacecraft to design, bases to build and asteroids to mine.The physics and spaceship building is incredibly well-done, newton's laws are well at play, for instance, ramming a ship will push it away, and will force your ship to move back aswell (or atleast the part of the ship that survived), by holding the movement keys in a spaceship, it will start building speed, and without thrusters put in the opposing direction (inertia dampeners), it's NEVER gonna stop moving, so you have to put trusters in all directions, should you want to move freely through the cosmos.In order to make your ship fly, you'll need power and trusters, and in order to make it turn, you need gyroscopes, wich are ALL affected by the mass of the ship.The building blocks given by the game allows you to make fantastic looking ships and new items are being added all the time.Bottom line: this game is great, if you like floating around in space and building stuff, buy it, as it is definitely worth your money.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								"I came to explore space. I left dissappointed."Before you get your panties all bunched up, this is an EARLY ACCESS REVIEW, as stated above. This is not a final review, it's merely a disclosure for people who would buy the game AS IS, NOW. The fact that it's so difficult for people to grasp is quite saddening.This game is grand. Grand is scale and looks. It has great mechanics and fantastic multiplayer potential. However it falls well short of any sort of longevity. The Survival mode itself revolves around plugging yourself into an outlet and charging up energy. In the "Survival" mode there's basically one thing you need to do. Mine. So pick up a drill, make a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ship and go dig a hole. That's it. Progression? There is none. Blueprints, unlockable schematics, anything? Nope. Earthworm Engineers more like it.Build a space station out of the same four blocks you'll use for everything else and..do NOTHING with it. Can't even decorate it with ..well..anything. It's beautiful, it has potential to be an expansive, amazing, hardcore survival / exploration game..yet the devs have recently shot down any sort of interest in including anything that would enhance a multiplayer survival mode. Expansive world to explore, but guess what..there's nothing in it! The developers decided against adding any form of AI. So no enemies, no rebel ships trying to shoot you down. NOTHING. That is what this game really amounts to. Shiny, shiny nothingness. Sure, you can mess with physics, do some fun stuff like that. Go into creative and build a massive ship. That's awesome! But what's the point? In "Survival" building..well..anything nets you..well..nothing. There's nothing opposing you, nothing. Mining nodes are not varied, random ghost ships float around and do nothing, and there are no planets or structures to go to.In my honest opinion they should hand this game over to the modding community and let some people with actual ambition and scope get on the project. The modders of Minecraft came up with a more indepth and exciting "Space" mod. I had to worry about oxygen, food, light, a home, my suit, finding blueprints, expanding my station, avoiding monsters. Just beneath the surface is something great, it's awfully sad to see the developers squandering it. But it's their game and my money, and I'll be taking it elsewhere in the future.The bottom line is that if you wan't progression and longevity of your playtime, this is not the game for you. And for me, progression and development are key. So it's not for me, and I don't have to defend that.  "General Statement. These are my thoughts on the game. Any opposing or likeminded feelings are welcome to be directed and discussed at me, however, don't be an idiot about it."

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								To cut to the chase, no I don't recommend this game. But I recommend it to ONLY people who like over complicated and relentlessly hard/sometimes annoying gameplay style, where physics in this game is very realistic, and all of your stats are based on a strict real life scenario, an engineer.Story Line/campaign: Does not exist (yet)Gameplay/replayability/learning curve: 2/10Game mechanics/GUI: 6/10AI: 10/10Graphics/art/models/animation: 9/10Functionality/performance: 6/10Content provided: 10/10Survival: 1.5/5Creative: 4/5Now why are these scores looking generous yet I'm not recommending the game? So let's start off with saying what is right with the game.Planets. 'Nuff said. Planets are huge and blow away 99% of the audience's expectations, INCLUDING mine. Planets are big, Space is big, you can jump your ship across a freaking galaxy, and when you get up to Space, OH... is it rewarding. Resources come at you generously, and you don't have to worry about gravity, and it is so... realistic. Launching a rocket up into space is both hard, and rewarding. The content levels are extreme, and visually + sounds... it's amazing. The full combinations of things you can build/make is great, and the developers of this game are excellent. The detail into imagination of creation is tons better than Minecraft, and you can program your ship to GIVE COMMANDS or MAKE IT AN AI!!!! Though it is lonely... so you should make AI to fend off against other AI.But...As much as it pains me to admit, the game Space Engineers will never be enjoyable to play. The game is fun at times, but it has a limit of fun because of how the game is played and made. Now don't get me wrong, planets is extremely perfect and the devs could NOT have made it any better. The expectations are over the top. But what is wrong with the game? Survival, the controls, and everything about the game via core mechanics and controls is HORRIBLE. You have to keep an ever watch on physics, building blocks take forever to build with limited inventory space, and running back and forth from destination to destination getting this and that component at quantities of 10-100 of EACH component, trying to remember what any object requires, topped with your oxygen AND energy AND jetpack hydrogen ticking down is the most ridiculous thing I have encountered on this entire planet! The game is not even worth playing, when things you build, die and disappear so freaking frequently, that you'll also rage quit once every play through and probably not play the game for another while.Lag is a big concern. Objects colliding is a big deal, and the attempt at generating thousands of trees is a cumbersome experience. Ship parts gets destroyed and disappear at hilarious times when not supposed to, multiplayer servers take time to respond to commands, and few other bugs/glitches to take away from enjoyment, but slightly. Still immersive in the long run, but the core mechanics of this game is extremely stupid, tacked on with bugs makes you sit there pondering at the game....replayability and learning curve is JUST NO. Why would I want to replay my game when the game keeps crashing, my ships keep crashing, I keep dying easily, and blocks are TOO DANG HARD to construct?!?!?! How are you supposed to learn any of this? Because of horrible learning curves, 85-90% of my friends don't wanna play survival, ever.Finally the GUI. What... the... hell is up with the build command complexity. You start with blocks in your quickslots you probably don't use, figuring out how to equip weapons is all tiresome, stiffly implemented, and hard to figure out. The control panel??? A mess. So many clusterfeck options that your brain goes numb, and the defaults of wheels is so WTFU, that building a vehicle on land takes AGES to figure out and get working correctly.Going back to core gameplay mechanics, sure the game is supposed to be slow. I get that, but if you have actual flaws to deal with, it is like a clog in your brain. SURE... you can store items into your containers and build welders on your ships and stuff and start weldin' but your welders if they even TOUCH objects at times, they just explode along with your resources and then that butt hurt flows through you like a disease of TROLLING... then you'll probably sit back and ponder at the screen for 5-30 minutes wondering, "what am I doing with my life?"The 300 hours I spent into this game is mostly me building up whatever I want (which is the cool part about the game), exploring planets, coding AI, and going back into the game to see new updates released every Thursday.This is why I do not recommend the game. I'm sorry. I really am... as I like this game, but I want to like it more...PS: I know it is in alpha still, but the potential in this game still exists... yet the devs ignore gameplay value over "perty graphics" and eye candy.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								-------Edit 2-------Infinite World Generation lost my job CPS took my kids cant stop playing help-------Edit 1-------Not a week after I wrote this review, the Devs did another update and added the option of spawning your own asteroids.For those of you who didn't read this review, I noted my only semi-complaint was the lack of random generation/asteroid fields etc. While not 100% random world generated, it is a massive leap in the right direction. My rating now goes to 11/10----------------------Original Review----------------------Great game. If you like sandbox-y classics like Minecraft, you will love Space Engineers. Dev's work hard to update the game as often as every week. The only con really is multiplayer (And this is kind of a big one because the game, like Minecraft, can be boring playing only by yourself.) Theres a bit of a desync issue when playing with others but Ive noticed it improve with each patch.Worth $20? At first I thought it might be a bit overpriced, but taking time to think, I would spend it again. Great community of builders and survivalists. Plenty of servers to mess around on and the convienent option to play on 'soft server/LAN' mode (you basically make your world public or friend-visible) rather than having to host your own server. Great if you don't plan on trying to build a big community and just want to mess around with a couple of friends.A real nice recent addition was Blueprints. Basically, it enables you to save your precious builds and not have to care about your stuff getting blown to hell. Before, you have to make an offline private 'hangar/shipdock' world to build your designs and save them and import them to other worlds. Now you can just make something, save it to blueprints and take them with you to other maps, worlds and servers.A small irritation, not even what I would consider a Con: The world generation options are a bit limited. I would like to see the ability to have a TRUE randomly generated world like Minecraft where every so many 100 kilometers or so, new asteroid fields spawn. However, currently, when you make a map, you select an option for a small (around 3), medium (6) or large (10+) asteroids centralized in the middle of the map. Everything outside of that is just dead space. Now granted, if you run your own server, you can spawn asteroids at locations all you want. But it would still be nice to have the randomly generated world truely.. well, generate stuff other than empty space. Small asteroid clusters and other intersteller phenemena. I think by doing so it will make the game more fun and give way to more of an exploration feeling. Plus, in Survival mode, you really cant afford to leave the asteroid fields and not have access to raw materials.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								Amazing game that anyone can enjoy. It's less about following objectives as most games are these days and more about using your personal creativity to create your own fun. Like Garry's Mod but in a much cleaners, styled fashion, give users a much more streamlined building system and the tools to do whatever their heart desires. The workshop is rich with mods and other user content, and it's easy to share your creations with others, and just as easy to download and use the creations others make. Weekly updates from the developers means there are constant improvements and fixes coming to the game at a steady pace as well.However, in my experience when ever I have been on to play the game (Most common times players in the AEST Timezone and similar would be on) The amount of players on servers is limited at best. On rare occasions a 10-15 slot server will be full, but other than that the lack of players can mean a limited interaction with others making playing on servers providing the same experience if not less in terms of player interaction plus issues you might experience with your connection to said server. To resolve this I would highly recommend talking you friend into buying this game or even buying it for them if you wish to play multiplayer, at least until the community grows. All in all there are probably plenty of games with a bigger player base and more content then Space Engineers, but the ability to sculpt the game to your needs is really unique feature to have in a game and no other game pulls this off better then this. There is plenty of room for new content and improvements but as it is now this is one of the best games on Steam right now and worth every cent. Can't wait for the player base to grow, see you in game!

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								-------Edit 2-------Infinite World Generation lost my job CPS took my kids cant stop playing help-------Edit 1-------Not a week after I wrote this review, the Devs did another update and added the option of spawning your own asteroids.For those of you who didn't read this review, I noted my only semi-complaint was the lack of random generation/asteroid fields etc. While not 100% random world generated, it is a massive leap in the right direction. My rating now goes to 11/10----------------------Original Review----------------------Great game. If you like sandbox-y classics like Minecraft, you will love Space Engineers. Dev's work hard to update the game as often as every week. The only con really is multiplayer (And this is kind of a big one because the game, like Minecraft, can be boring playing only by yourself.) Theres a bit of a desync issue when playing with others but Ive noticed it improve with each patch.Worth $20? At first I thought it might be a bit overpriced, but taking time to think, I would spend it again. Great community of builders and survivalists. Plenty of servers to mess around on and the convienent option to play on 'soft server/LAN' mode (you basically make your world public or friend-visible) rather than having to host your own server. Great if you don't plan on trying to build a big community and just want to mess around with a couple of friends.A real nice recent addition was Blueprints. Basically, it enables you to save your precious builds and not have to care about your stuff getting blown to hell. Before, you have to make an offline private 'hangar/shipdock' world to build your designs and save them and import them to other worlds. Now you can just make something, save it to blueprints and take them with you to other maps, worlds and servers.A small irritation, not even what I would consider a Con: The world generation options are a bit limited. I would like to see the ability to have a TRUE randomly generated world like Minecraft where every so many 100 kilometers or so, new asteroid fields spawn. However, currently, when you make a map, you select an option for a small (around 3), medium (6) or large (10+) asteroids centralized in the middle of the map. Everything outside of that is just dead space. Now granted, if you run your own server, you can spawn asteroids at locations all you want. But it would still be nice to have the randomly generated world truely.. well, generate stuff other than empty space. Small asteroid clusters and other intersteller phenemena. I think by doing so it will make the game more fun and give way to more of an exploration feeling. Plus, in Survival mode, you really cant afford to leave the asteroid fields and not have access to raw materials.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								To cut to the chase, no I don't recommend this game. But I recommend it to ONLY people who like over complicated and relentlessly hard/sometimes annoying gameplay style, where physics in this game is very realistic, and all of your stats are based on a strict real life scenario, an engineer.Story Line/campaign: Does not exist (yet)Gameplay/replayability/learning curve: 2/10Game mechanics/GUI: 6/10AI: 10/10Graphics/art/models/animation: 9/10Functionality/performance: 6/10Content provided: 10/10Survival: 1.5/5Creative: 4/5Now why are these scores looking generous yet I'm not recommending the game? So let's start off with saying what is right with the game.Planets. 'Nuff said. Planets are huge and blow away 99% of the audience's expectations, INCLUDING mine. Planets are big, Space is big, you can jump your ship across a freaking galaxy, and when you get up to Space, OH... is it rewarding. Resources come at you generously, and you don't have to worry about gravity, and it is so... realistic. Launching a rocket up into space is both hard, and rewarding. The content levels are extreme, and visually + sounds... it's amazing. The full combinations of things you can build/make is great, and the developers of this game are excellent. The detail into imagination of creation is tons better than Minecraft, and you can program your ship to GIVE COMMANDS or MAKE IT AN AI!!!! Though it is lonely... so you should make AI to fend off against other AI.But...As much as it pains me to admit, the game Space Engineers will never be enjoyable to play. The game is fun at times, but it has a limit of fun because of how the game is played and made. Now don't get me wrong, planets is extremely perfect and the devs could NOT have made it any better. The expectations are over the top. But what is wrong with the game? Survival, the controls, and everything about the game via core mechanics and controls is HORRIBLE. You have to keep an ever watch on physics, building blocks take forever to build with limited inventory space, and running back and forth from destination to destination getting this and that component at quantities of 10-100 of EACH component, trying to remember what any object requires, topped with your oxygen AND energy AND jetpack hydrogen ticking down is the most ridiculous thing I have encountered on this entire planet! The game is not even worth playing, when things you build, die and disappear so freaking frequently, that you'll also rage quit once every play through and probably not play the game for another while.Lag is a big concern. Objects colliding is a big deal, and the attempt at generating thousands of trees is a cumbersome experience. Ship parts gets destroyed and disappear at hilarious times when not supposed to, multiplayer servers take time to respond to commands, and few other bugs/glitches to take away from enjoyment, but slightly. Still immersive in the long run, but the core mechanics of this game is extremely stupid, tacked on with bugs makes you sit there pondering at the game....replayability and learning curve is JUST NO. Why would I want to replay my game when the game keeps crashing, my ships keep crashing, I keep dying easily, and blocks are TOO DANG HARD to construct?!?!?! How are you supposed to learn any of this? Because of horrible learning curves, 85-90% of my friends don't wanna play survival, ever.Finally the GUI. What... the... hell is up with the build command complexity. You start with blocks in your quickslots you probably don't use, figuring out how to equip weapons is all tiresome, stiffly implemented, and hard to figure out. The control panel??? A mess. So many clusterfeck options that your brain goes numb, and the defaults of wheels is so WTFU, that building a vehicle on land takes AGES to figure out and get working correctly.Going back to core gameplay mechanics, sure the game is supposed to be slow. I get that, but if you have actual flaws to deal with, it is like a clog in your brain. SURE... you can store items into your containers and build welders on your ships and stuff and start weldin' but your welders if they even TOUCH objects at times, they just explode along with your resources and then that butt hurt flows through you like a disease of TROLLING... then you'll probably sit back and ponder at the screen for 5-30 minutes wondering, "what am I doing with my life?"The 300 hours I spent into this game is mostly me building up whatever I want (which is the cool part about the game), exploring planets, coding AI, and going back into the game to see new updates released every Thursday.This is why I do not recommend the game. I'm sorry. I really am... as I like this game, but I want to like it more...PS: I know it is in alpha still, but the potential in this game still exists... yet the devs ignore gameplay value over "perty graphics" and eye candy.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
Early Access Review
								Space Engineers has potential. Never have I seen a game that so immerses you with the feeling that you are actually in space. Instead of having an obligatory "up" and "down," as is common with games to reduce frustration while also relaying a sense of rigidity, Space Engineers only has vectors. There is no "up," "down," "left," or "right." All those are lost in translation to space because all of them are relative  to gravity. This leads to comedic events, confusing orientations, and overall an enjoyable experience that seems to be subverted in similar games. The building strays from the blocky features of games like Minecraft, which is beautiful in it's own right, and instead opts to have more shapes to give angular slopes to your creations.This is a breath of fresh air in terms of appearance. However, I previously stated that this game has potential, and that is crucial to take into consideration when buying a game in its early stages of development. The game features a variety of activities that should keep you occupied at first, but grows repetitive after a while. Until weapons, multiplayer, and other essential features are added, this game is soley a singleplayer game with a limited amount of past times. If you cannot bear to have a game and little reason to play it, I suggest you wait until the full release, or, at the very least, until multiplayer is released.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								Space Engineers is an open-world sandbox game where you take on the role of a engineer of stellar proportions. While the wonderful screenshots and description of this game are very convincing; the game runs like utter garbage. The developers have built their own engine for this game, but as others have mentioned as well: The game somehow feels like a Unity game. It is well stated that the game is in fact not based off Unity, but the poor performance optimizations tend to shed some similarity between them. Because this is early access, this sort of problem at the moment; is fully excusable. If the game goes out of early access, then this will be a big problem for many gamers. As other reviewers (even positive ones have mentioned); the game's potential is great and the concepts that it lays out are very unique from other open-world sandbox titles. But if the developers don't start focusing on major performance optimizations, then I expect this game will fall short for a long crowd. My FPS in the game with a GTX 680 4GB card never goes any higher than 28 FPS, and often dips to 3 FPS with all the graphics on low. Overall, unless you have a GTX titan with 12 GB of RAM and a Core I7 with 4.0 GHz, you will probably not be able to enjoy this game (the low settings make it look really ugly.)

content:
Posted: April 23
Early Access Review
								This game is fun, but gets old pretty quickly.It allows you to mine for minerals, build surface and space bases, ships and rovers. You can also set-up an automated factory line inside your base or ship, create remote controlled vessels and build other contraptions.And that's about it.Granted, it will give you many hours of fun, but for every hour of fun you'll pay with an hour of frustration. I bought this game years ago, and I was hoping it will improve over time. Sadly, the development is not fast enough (or focused on wrong things)On to the bad things:- Multiplayer is broken. You will be stuck, you wil lexperience lag, there will be jitter, weird things will happen. And even if it works, the only interaction you may have with others is to shoot at them.- Physics is broken. Speed limit is silly, colissions are coutner-intuitive, Wheeled vehicles - so prominently displayed in promo screenshots - work in such an awful way it's ubelievable! There is 0 rewardin building a rover/jeep- There is nothing to do except to survive.tl;dr:Multiplayer broken, singleplayer boring, quality still low despite years of development.

number of helpful: 26 of 48 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								I really like this game. The idea of a spaceship minecraft-like game with an awesome physics engine was really apealling and when I first go it I wasn't dissapointed. But this game has many issues I think you should know about before buying it. When I first bought the game it was fairly buggy but not bad for an alpha title and it's weekly releases left me confident it would only improve from there. I was wrong. The developers were so focused on adding more and more content to the game it quickly became unstable. On planets as far as I can tell maintaining a solid 30 fps is difficult and 60fps is flatout impossible. The game also encounters huge performance issues when you attempt to build larger ships so you can kiss any hopes of massive battleships goodbye. The multiplayer leaves alot to be desired with simulation speeds tanking to .60 or below. But the worst part is, despite all these issues the developers continue to release weekly updates adding more flash to the game with seemingly no intent on fixing it's performance.Now if you stay inside these limitations it is a very fun game if you enjoy building spaceships and I will still come back and play it every onceand a while. If you can learn to live with framerate issues and bugs you'll probably enjoy it too but in it's current state I just can't recommend it.

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have never had the need to (or wanted to) review any game,but Space Engineers deserves all the praise it can get! I have been playing this game for some time and have 590 hours on record and in my opinion this is a brilliant game. The type of player this game best suits is someone who likes survival, resourse gathering,survival building, creative building, and has a good imagination. As I said I have been playing for a long time and I have yet to run out of ideas!There are some disadvantages such as minor bugs e.g lighting problems, the odd ship that just explodes for no reason, and that the game is very taxing on low end PCs, but most bugs are patched and there is just so much to do in the game that these disadvantages are dwarfed by the  size and enjoyment of the game, and as for running Space Engineers on your PC, once you meet the minimum requirements the game works fine (just dont go near planets)The game developers have been excellent since day one bringing out constant updates every week and fixing issues that the community have had. On top of all this there is a vibrant modding community with steam workshop support which enhances the game so so much, allowing you to build ships and contraptions from your favourite movies etc (Star wars!!)This game has been my favourite for a long time and will likely stay that way, and I would highly recommend this game to anyone who is interested. Thanks for reading and keep building!EXTRA: I have seen a few negative reviews of this game and they seem to be annoyed about the same thing, the un-stable state of multiplayer, but something you need to keep in mind is that the game is fine in solo and in small multi-player servers, the problem arises with lots of people in servers with many complex blocks. If you try and avoid these bigger servers (which can easily be done, I haven't played in one yet) you are still left with a brilliant game with near limitless possibilities.

Early Access Review
								Space Engineers is a sandbox game which should have gotten better as it slowly emerged from Alpha. However sand continues to leak out the corners and cracks. Game content needed to make the game world compelling is still not really there, new blocks and planets aren't a replacement for AI to fight, or NPCs to trade with.This game has so much potential for modding, however the ModAPI remains very incomplete. You can ask for things to be added, but months later nothing will have happened.So Keen won't add the content the game needs, and you can't mod it in yourself.Game runs slower than it did 18 months ago, and needs better hardware/OS as well.Players have taken to giving a persona to the game Physics bugs, Clang the god of random explosions or crashing into things.

number of helpful: 142 of 275 people (52%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Original Review (April 2015): This game has a lot of potential, but in its current state is difficult to play. As an early access game, perfection should not be expected. Nevertheless, there are regular problems with server crashes, components failing to work properly, disconnects causing the loss of resources you've spent ages mining, respawns considerably further away from your last position etc. Just establishing a basic medical bay (to allow fixed location respawn) had to be restarted more than 5 times because until you can build a medical bay, every time the server disconnects you, you have to respawn as a new character with no resources and start from scratch. It has a lot of potential but until at least the server issues are addressed, I would not recommend.Updated Review (April 2016): Server stability issues are not as prevalent as they once were, although server restarts are still fairly common. Unfortunately, there are a myriad of issues which have still never been addressed. For example, myself and friends have encounter bugs where a spawn ship will continually accelerate upwards, which forces you to turn upside down and attempt a crash landing. Landing gear frequently attempts to latch onto the ground (even when not set to do so). Mining by hand is still very awkward due to the physics of falling boulders. Glitches have seen players falling through sections of supposedly solid ground and ship components jumping around eratically when they should be in a fixed position. Sadly, for a game with so very much potential, it seems as though the devs are fixing graphical issues and ignoring the physics ones. To charge new players £18.99 for the privilege of a broken experience is absurd.

number of helpful: 79 of 153 people (52%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								TL;DR: Too much bulk, not enough polish. I've tried so many times to love this game. Everything about it makes it seem like a game I should love. I've played this game more than pretty much anything else in my library, watching it grow and evolve. You would think I would love the changes, the additions, the improvements... but the problem is that it feels like many of the improvements aren't really being meshed with the previous iterations. Its difficult to describe, and being a sandbox you could probably argue the you make what you want out of all the parts, but still... there is a feeling of incompletness, of disjointedness about the whole thing that I wouldn't expect out of a game that's been around this long (even in Early Access). It's a bit difficult to describe exact things, but I guess one example that goes back a little ways is the fact they introduced air, but didn't introduce a way to dock ships together that was airtight. Yes, you can make a werid, ugly, jerryrigged thing with mergeblocks and (if you want) airtight hanger doors, but nothing that makes you feel like you're handling a nice, futuristic, fancy space ship - more like you don't have all the right Lego peices because your brother took the right one and you have to make do. It just seems like a basic thing when it comes to space games - a way to get between ships in an aired-up environment. You have connector, why not make one that is the size of a door and when it locks its air tight? But instead of making a previous feature feel complete, they go and add planets (to a game called *Space* Engineers, btw...) and make a big deal out of it, but when you get there you're lucky if your ship doesn't glitch into the ground, and God forbid you want to put a block on top of the one you're looking at while on a planet - flat platforms for everyone! And somehow your drill just never seems to actually drill into anything.I love complex games. I love space games. And I want to love Space Engineers, but in the end the parts I want don't seem to exist or work properly - or they just don't *feel* right. Bulky interfaces, glitchy features, confusing development additions... I know the developers are trying, but in the end I fear they are adding bulk at the expense of polish, and a game this far along really should have some polish to make the bulk something worth admiring.

content:

Early Access Review
								I highly recommend this game. I think the key to an early access game is having good developers who are working with a flexible engine. The game is given updates very frequently, and always with new features and not just bug fixes. The developers are very intuitive, and have been laying out the bedrock of this game very practically. It's already one of the most fun games in my large library, and they only just came out with survival mode. Creative mode is really fun on its own, but when they released survival, the quality of the game as a whole doubled. If you like Minecraft, you'll love this game.Please, please, please give the developers your money, they will utilize it better than almost anyone.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is FABULOUS for anyone interested in anything building your own spaceships, experimenting with gravity and systems design; or simply jetting about in space practicing your abysmal landing skills like me. You can even be a pirate, capturing and processing the unlucky ships that pass through your system. Or take a shot at mining out a whole asteroid and hide a secret base inside. So much to do and see, with more on the way, limited only by your imagination.This title is only in Alpha, yet already has a fairly stable multiplayer option, and it updates on a weekly basis from a laundry list of things that users actually want. I've had this on my wishlist since last October, so thank you Wedgehog, so very, VERY much for gifting me this gem...even though you blow up my saves on a regular basis! <3 XDNow if I can finally get my SSD back, I'll be recording some of this...

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								OK, first off let me say this: If there were a neutral option for this game, I would select it. Let's just get that out of the way now.Space Engineers: A game where, essentially, Minecraft meets asteroids. That's not a bad thing at all. It's actually a pretty awesome thing. The graphics are good, even on low, the ships you can make are AWESOME, and the multiplayer...well, I guess it depends on the server. Here's my big problem...the controls. In the trailer, it showed an engineer flawlessly flying, building, repairing, and moving. This was not my case. The way to rotate parts is very odd making the construction of the epic mothership I have formed in my mind much, much harder. Rotating yourself is a little easier, but still a little clunky (I'm not sure how to describe it.)When, after much deliberation, I made my ship, flying was FANTASTIC. The controls for flight are very simple to grasp, and make the game so much more enjoyable. The only relatively tough part of flying is the landing "sequence." Other than that, flying = fun as hell. The destruction of ships is very fun, too. I sometimes start up a new world for the sole purpose of breaking apart ships. If I had to score this game, I would probably give it a 7.5/10. The controls were the main drawback for me. If they were...smoothened (Again, not sure how to explain) then it would be much more fun. However, as of now, Space Engineers is a very average game in my opinion.

Early Access Review
Space Engineers is amazing in many ways, I myself have played this many times (maybe not in the survival mode), where I'd either download mods, download maps or might build my own creations instead. Eitherway, this game sucks the creativity and time right out of your hands. You'll find yourself looking at the clock, wondering how you could sit for such a long time in front of the computer, without realizing daylight was gone.Story -/10 (There's none)Soundtrack 7/10Atmosphere 7/10Scenery 6/10Characters -/10 (There's none)Graphics 8/10Overall 7/10A creativity/survival based game, neither focused on story or action

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
Early Access Review
								Josh told me to buy this, and he mentioned it is not the final game so I don't know if I wanted to buy it yet, but he was having so much fun while talking on skype so I had to try it myself.I did not watch anything (videos or tutorials) and just got straight into it. It was god damn hard at first but I have been on it for hours trying to create some small ships to start with. It really does take patience to create a huge ship but its up to you on how it will look.At first, I did crash the ships that already are loaded into the quick-start options and it was so fun to see the pyhsics of the damage the ship had taken, not to mention it was fun to crash a ship into another.I then started to get used to the Camera and how it works, it's hard starting out but you will get used to it.I could ramble on a lot for how much fun you will have playing this just in single-player, yet I think they are releasing multiplayer in an update. This is what I (any I could guess a lot of others) are looking forward too. Gathering resources together, building a station, a huge epic fleet of ships to maybe have a war.I am so looking forward to updates on this game.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is truly one of the most engrossing games I have ever played! There are so many opportunities to build lots of different  ships and machines (using pistons and rotors among other things). The game style is similar to minecraft with the building aspects, but also includes modern graphics, physics (playing with gravity generators is super fun) and a full destruction engine. Also the modding community is alive and kicking with many many different blocks and new mods for the game under development.The gameplay is quite smooth for an early access game. Patches come out weekly and new features are constantly being added (but that is coming to an end in the near future as they have included nearly all intended features at this point). Some bugs are expected and present but that's what you get for an Early Access game. If you do not like bugs, wait for the full release!

content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Space engineers is... The perfect combination of Minecraft Creativity combined with fun with physics we find in games like Garry's mod. Although many early access games have been an amazing waste of time and money, this game offers the player an original and addicting experience. Creative is a lot of fun, but from the survival gamemode I still expect great things (Although not being at all boring). All of you who have not bough this game yet; BUY! BUY! BUUUUUUUY!Edited: 25-6-2015The survival has more than developped into a well run machine. The addition of mods make the experience a lot more fun as well. Besides the fun with physics we are getting more and more options to operate the ship systems. Sensors allow you to automate systems within an area for example. Ingame scripts can be run through Programable blocks.All and all, this game is worth much more than they ask for it. But they won't, because they aren't EA. SPACE ENGINEERS IS LOVE, SPACE ENGINEERS IS LIVE!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Epic timewaster game. Minecraft in space with jetpacks, vehicles, guns, turrets and huge♥♥♥♥♥spacecraft that you can build/drive around. Mine resources from asteroids and build space stations and defences and stuff and go raid other peoples' ships. LOTS of stuff to learn and see and very fun to play. The worlds are huge too, literally space infinite (well almost). Good physics engine and playable netcode even on distant servers, although the game has quite a few bugs in its current state (but that's a given for an early access title).At first I thought this was some kind of realistic space "engineering" simulator, but really it's not, it's more along the lines of very high tech Minecraft with gadgets. Can be played singleplayer or multiplayer and the worlds can be saved just like in Minecraft so you can continue from where you left off.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								This has to be one of my favorite builder games I have played in a long time. Starting off on the lone survivor difficulty it was a struggle to constantly get enough materials to supply a turret to keep the asteroids at bay (Totally optional as you can turn them off if you'd prefer but survival isn't survival without danger in my opinion) and it was chaotic. But when I finally had an operational mining ship I could expand. And expand I did. And thats the charm of this game. You spend hours putting things together, cobbling ships from whatever blocks you choose. When it finally call comes together and you have built your first ship from scratch there is a great sense of pride. Seeing what you crafted take flight, mine asteroids, construct parts at a far faster rate, tear down old stations in seconds, or whatever you made it for. It just feels great to see your creation come to life. Building a massive station with your friends makes it even better as your collective effort creates a powerful station where you can feel safe from the hazards of space.It may seem slow to craft parts but if you don't have a lot of time to sit and wait you can alter the speed of part construction  and how fast the refinery smelts down ore to x3 or x10 levels. Perfect if you only have time for a quick build before school or work. There is some basic combat right now with gatling turrets and rocket launchers to attach to ships but its not yet polished. I can see the potential though as I had one small ship made for combat. The guns had a good feel and power to them as I blasted a couple ships to little metal bits. And then I got blown up by my own rocket when a gatling turret on a ship auto targeted it as it fired out of the barrel. Sad but decoys prevent that if you have them.Only got this game a short time ago but it is definitely one of the best purchases I've made all year. I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys builder games as this one brings it to whole new level of enjoyable complexity. I can see myself playing this game for months to come, and I can't wait to see the things I can build with every patch. 9/10 highly recommended.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								There are a ton of space shooter games out there that simulate several kinds of space flight. They allow you to be merchants, pirates, fighters, traders and so on. Some space shooters allow you to travel to other worlds while others let you explore the expansive galaxy.Space Engineers takes space flight to a whole new level of space flight. This is not just a game, it's a creation tool. Space Engineers, not only allows you to fly through space and battle it out with your enemies, but this game lets you also "DESIGN" your ship the way you want it, exactly how YOU want it. Space flight is no longer about just ships, it's about designing and showing off your ship designing skills. You can design fighters, frieghters, destroyers, dreadnauts, even space stations that take HOURS to travel the entire station. YOu can even design fighter ships inside the frieghters or space stations, so you havesomething to defend your stations or frieghters. Not only can you build your fighters, but you can also travel to asteroids and drill for minerals to design stronger materials to make better ships/stations for yourself.Space Engineers also lets you do either single edit where you just edit the ship on your own without others watching you, or you can have others join you online, either as allies and team work your stations, ships, destroyers, or you can battle it out against your friends to see who will have the best fighter ships and who can build the better ships.Along with that, if you think you have designed a good ship, you can post your ship creations on the Steam site and you can also check out other designs that others have made and see how they designed their ships. (UPDATE = As of now there are over 1,000 pages of Workshop items to view and download. Ships, stations, animations, asteroids, destroyers, mechanical devices, there's just nolimit to what you can do.)Space Engineers is no longer about just space flight. It's about taking the entire "Build Your Space Empire" to a whole new level of build and destroy. Build it, design it, add on to it, tweek it, create it, and use it, any way you see fit. Space Engineers is no longer about the game, it's all about "YOU". What ship do YOU want to design, and how will you control the space empire? Space Engineers, you know you wanna be one... ^_^ (The game was still in Beta when this review was given, but during this time, they had updated the game so that you can do online battles or coop, how ever you want to play online)

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								OK, first off let me say this: If there were a neutral option for this game, I would select it. Let's just get that out of the way now.Space Engineers: A game where, essentially, Minecraft meets asteroids. That's not a bad thing at all. It's actually a pretty awesome thing. The graphics are good, even on low, the ships you can make are AWESOME, and the multiplayer...well, I guess it depends on the server. Here's my big problem...the controls. In the trailer, it showed an engineer flawlessly flying, building, repairing, and moving. This was not my case. The way to rotate parts is very odd making the construction of the epic mothership I have formed in my mind much, much harder. Rotating yourself is a little easier, but still a little clunky (I'm not sure how to describe it.)When, after much deliberation, I made my ship, flying was FANTASTIC. The controls for flight are very simple to grasp, and make the game so much more enjoyable. The only relatively tough part of flying is the landing "sequence." Other than that, flying = fun as hell. The destruction of ships is very fun, too. I sometimes start up a new world for the sole purpose of breaking apart ships. If I had to score this game, I would probably give it a 7.5/10. The controls were the main drawback for me. If they were...smoothened (Again, not sure how to explain) then it would be much more fun. However, as of now, Space Engineers is a very average game in my opinion.

Early Access Review
								Josh told me to buy this, and he mentioned it is not the final game so I don't know if I wanted to buy it yet, but he was having so much fun while talking on skype so I had to try it myself.I did not watch anything (videos or tutorials) and just got straight into it. It was god damn hard at first but I have been on it for hours trying to create some small ships to start with. It really does take patience to create a huge ship but its up to you on how it will look.At first, I did crash the ships that already are loaded into the quick-start options and it was so fun to see the pyhsics of the damage the ship had taken, not to mention it was fun to crash a ship into another.I then started to get used to the Camera and how it works, it's hard starting out but you will get used to it.I could ramble on a lot for how much fun you will have playing this just in single-player, yet I think they are releasing multiplayer in an update. This is what I (any I could guess a lot of others) are looking forward too. Gathering resources together, building a station, a huge epic fleet of ships to maybe have a war.I am so looking forward to updates on this game.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								While the movement systems may seem confusing at first, this game allows so much more of the invention and engineering feel that I was looking for in a game than I've found elsewhere, with an ever-growing selection of intriguing mechanics.Where else do you ponder how to control space fighter traffic in a carrier to make reloading quick and easy and avoid not only collisions, but also cutting each other up with thruster backblast?This game throws novel problems at me and expects novel solutions from me, without being designed with a fixed list of solutions in mind. This is a thing that has gotten much easier with the invention of modern physics engines, etc.; but is still relatively rare and something I search far and wide for.I fully recommend this game, though keep in mind it's still in development and lacks a crucial Linux port (they made some bad design decisions locking themselves into Microsoft APIs instead of using standardised libraries). Time will tell if the Wine compatibility improves, as of this writing I'm booting into Windows 7 exclusively for this game.
