								SE was one of the reasons I actually got steam in the first place, if I remember correctly, and that is not a decision I at all regret. The devs are a motley crew of awesome people, who take the time to appreciate comminty works as well as listening to their feedback nd requests. Although the game has been in Alpha for quite some time, the constant stream of updates (now split in to standard and devopment branches) is enough to justify it. But on to the game. You'll have to battle space robot dogs, giant space spiders, the need for resources and of course oxygen/hydrogen, but these can all be disabled in the world settings. In creative your biggest limit is your imagination, myself having built a ship that is 6 miles long. Don't get disheartened if your first few ships are little more than boxes, that's how it always starts!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								Let me just say I love the idea of this game.I got this game right about when it came out, maybe a little after. Sure, there were bugs, but it was still fun to fly around on spaceships with your friends and try to survive the harsh realities of space. I can remember late nights spent with a group of friends sitting around a table, all of us gripping our mouses tightly and yelling commands at each other as our ship's engines started to fail, our masterpiece heading towards an increasingly large asteroid. We built epic bases, hunted down pirates, mined precious metals, pretty much did it all. I could really see the possibility for this game. But as the game developed, it got more and more buggy. Adding giant planets sure didn't help. The technology and developement was left in the dust of the ideas. The game became more and more demanding, to the point where it was impossible to play on our laptops, and became mostly unplayable due to bugs. If you want to buy this game, check back here in a year or six months, or until the game comes out of early access. In the mean time, try Emperion or another space based survival game. Space Engineers takes the cake for creativity, possibility, and gameplay, but it is simply not developed enough to be worth buying at this point in time. I sincerely hope the developers fix the bugs and reduce the demand of the game. Just don't waste your money on it now.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Full german review:http://www.topfree.de/space-engineersGrind materials, build a Space Ship and crash it into a meteor. The dream of every kid. Actually, the game is doing good in fulfilling this dream.The game runs on a modified version of the Havoc engine and offers a decent 3D space enviroment with realistic physics in zero gravity and vacuum.With a toolset of different forms of blocks, building parts and engines, you can design really nice looking ships and are also able to fly them.With focus on realism you wont find laser guns and warp drives, but the survival in a hostile environment with the constant need of energy ressources to maintain your vital systems.The game isnt really finished and playing the survival mode doesnt feel, like its worth the time.But the core of the game is amazing:Building: You are able to build complex structures, that can do different tasks in different situations, like battlestations, refinerys, mining rigs, scouts, transporters and space stations.Factions: You are able to team up with other players, and make alliances and war with other factions. Also systems can be protected, so they are only usable by you or your teammates.Technological Playground: To play with the game-engine you have a big toolbelt of tech: Sensors, wheels, pistons and rotors, remote controls, explosives and artificial gravity. From creating an elevator to building a big racing track or an automatic repair station, you can build, what you can immagine.Weekly updates give you a feeling of safety, you dont have in other early access games. Still on an early stage, the game is constantly evolving and hopefully will be a big thing in the next years.Because of the limits to the engine, the game world currently very small and empty.If you dont have a good PC or if you are not creative and just want a space experience, the game will disappoint you.But if it is your big thing to build and create, this game already has everything you ever wanted.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								See below for my original post, as it still has merit in my opinion, however I've spent more time trying to see what this game has to offer. If you're new to it and looking to try the survival mode as I was, turn the environmental hazards off, and don't play on a planet world. They are relentless and make the game virtually unplayable for a new player. Why? Planets have robot dogs that apparently eat metal and space engineers, and prefer to spawn in packs of 3-6 every 1-4 minutes. This results in dying several times per hour, and a naturally occuring "game reset" as they consume both your body and the three blocks you've managed to build since the last time you died. Also, the environmental hazards are meteor storms that spawn centered on your head once every five minutes. They might not kill you, but they wreck any bases they touch. For example, I was robodog free on an asteroid base with a pre generated reactor and some crafting machinery. I thought the meteor storms were cool until one spawned on my head instead of somewhere else in "infinite" space and hit nothing. Except the reactor, which it obliterated. I had been playing for maybe 15 minutes at this point, so I had some components. I thought I would just build another one, but discovered I was still short some required components. I thought "No problem, I'll just craft them really fast." Pause. I need components to build a reactor. I need an assembler to build components.I need a reactor to power an assembler.Ergo, I floated off into space and died after about an hour of scrambling to find Step 1 that every sandbox survival game should have. Turns out Step 1 in Space Engineers is "Start new game" where they hand you a reactor, a refinery, and an assembler because the game is unplayable without any one of those things.Where this game currently shines is in the building. Once you turn it to safe mode and lose the dogs, you can actually make progress. Building ships in Space Engineers is immensely satisfying, requiring forethought, intentional block placement, and testing. The blocks they have are just plain cool, and each one offers a level of complexity and functionality that I find other games of this genre lack. The logic is fun and easy to use too. It almost made me forget how infuriating some of the previously mentioned content is. All of that said, I can say that I'm happy I bought it, though my negative recommendation will still stand as long as all that good stuff remains buried under so many half-baked and frustrating features. Original post:It's raw, complicated, and unpolished for a game already in development for several years. I spent 10 hours confirming that the crafting system is cyclical, meaning you can't start from scratch, and if you run out of power, which every thing in the game is trying to make happen, you will float into space and die without a single action you can take to rectify the situation. Pretty graphics, great physics, needs a metric shipload (see what I did there?) of work before I can recommend this, even at $8 on sale. Seriously, go play StarMade.

content:
Posted: January 29
Early Access Review
								You need two things for this game: patience and imagination. So I would only recommend it for people who have both.Being fresh from alpha and only just hitting beta, the game still has bugs, which, from my own perspective are being ironed out.I mention perspective, because it seems that people with different machines, seem to have different experiences. Some have had little to no trouble with bugs. Others experience a few problems and others a lot (and it doesn't always seem to be computer spec related).Having got the negative out of the way, the game has so much potential and actually runs pretty well on my "average" PC.If you're a problem solver, then this will be right up your alley.If you're the type of gamer who just wants everything to work perfectly with absolutely no effort at all on your part, then you should leave this page. Now. The game is in beta, so you'll need to be a "guinea pig" for a while.Some people like being part of the development process and some don't.If you do - then totally get it.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								Legos in Space     This is my initial impression of Space Engineers. In the time I spent with it, I built a "Space Bus" and crashed several different vehicles. The best way to explain Space Engineers is that is operates like Legos in space. You build whatever your imagination fancies out of blocks and other bits. Building is easy and efficient and really only limited to your imagination. You can also color your creation and fly it about the randomly generated space world. For those who fancy construction it does this very well.     Of course, the ying to constructions yang is destruction. And you can do this with anything you build. You can fly ships into other ships, space stations, or asteroids. This is equally as fun as building in Space Engineers.    But, Space Engineers does something even better. The Space part. The physics model is absolutely amazing. Flying ships is not like in Wing Commander or Strike Suit Zero. Space flight is based on actual physics. Thrusters are used to steer and move your ship. Bigger ships require bigger thrusters. Thankfully, Space Engineers understands it is still a game and inertial dampeners are included with your space suit. It makes moving about in space infinitely more easy. Of course, you can swith this off and have some fun just reenacting the movie Gravity. I have not spent much time in multiplayer, which traditionally is not my cup of tea, but it seemed pretty good of what I tried of it. Definitely worth a go, even in its Early Release state.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you've ever played Minecraft back in the day, during pre-release, and wanted Notch/Jeb/Whoever to expand more on the Contraption Aspect (Red Stone, Pistons, levers and buttons) than the fantasy, you're in for a treat. Space Engineers is what you've been looking for, and more! Space Engineers (SE for short) isn't your everyday sandbox game. Its a sandbox game... IN SPACE! The two main features of this game, so far, are: Creative Mode: A free build mode with the only limitations being your computer, and your imagination!- In this mode blocks are placed instantly, no resources are required to power your creations, and death is no issue (in fact, it can be turned off)- One of the newer features for Creative is the Copy & Paste funciton (Ctrl-X for cut, Ctrl-C to duplicate, and Ctrl-V to paste from clipboard) Survival Mode: In this mode, you can die. -When building only a Framework of a block is placed, and its required for you to gather materials (Through mining, or salvaging other blocks with your grinder) to weld the block to completion. - The health system is divided into two parts: Your suits power, and your actual health. If you lose power while floating in space, whelp, you gon' die, slowly. Remember "No one can hear you scream in space." The other way you can die... well there's a thousand ways to die in space: Smash your face into an asteroid, Someone puts a drill to your face thinking its sweet sweet Uranium, your ship gets blown up, Random space debris decapitates you. The posibilities are endless.Some with the vanilla items in the game to use at your disposal are:-Armor blocks (Your basic building blocks, you get Heavy and Light)-Reactors: needs Uranium for Survival. Powers your creations-Thrusters: makes you go.-Gyros: makes you go the direction you want.-Gravity Generators: Holds you to the floor (Sperical Grav Gens were just added, so you can have a planet!)-Rotors: Makes things spin!-Pistons: Makes things go up and down!-Artificial Mass: Makes your things actually fall with the gravity.-Wheels! You're no limited to just space ships.-Drills, Grinders, Welders: Typical Mine, Salvage, Repair-Guns! You can have a hand held SMG, Gattling guns( and Automated Turrets), and dont forget ROCKETS! (also in automated turrets)-MUCH MORE!SE also features Steam Workshop. "Big Whoop, All ill be able to do is download other peoples things." Wrong. Not only can you download user created ships, you can download custom maps and asteroids.Last, and most importantly, MODS! You can download user created Mods. No going into files, no making backups, not hastle. Sub, and its all done for you! Now your thinking "That sounds neat, but its still early access. Itll probably just go defunct." NOPE! Keen has been doing an amazing job and are dedicated to this game. They have weekly updates every thursday. And not just your every day hot-fix bug be gone update.Every. Single. Week. They add in new features and or Blocks. Keen also listens to the communites suggestions for new content, whilst still keeping their vision of the game true.Let your imagination run rampant!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								Let me just say I love the idea of this game.I got this game right about when it came out, maybe a little after. Sure, there were bugs, but it was still fun to fly around on spaceships with your friends and try to survive the harsh realities of space. I can remember late nights spent with a group of friends sitting around a table, all of us gripping our mouses tightly and yelling commands at each other as our ship's engines started to fail, our masterpiece heading towards an increasingly large asteroid. We built epic bases, hunted down pirates, mined precious metals, pretty much did it all. I could really see the possibility for this game. But as the game developed, it got more and more buggy. Adding giant planets sure didn't help. The technology and developement was left in the dust of the ideas. The game became more and more demanding, to the point where it was impossible to play on our laptops, and became mostly unplayable due to bugs. If you want to buy this game, check back here in a year or six months, or until the game comes out of early access. In the mean time, try Emperion or another space based survival game. Space Engineers takes the cake for creativity, possibility, and gameplay, but it is simply not developed enough to be worth buying at this point in time. I sincerely hope the developers fix the bugs and reduce the demand of the game. Just don't waste your money on it now.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								I might expected too much to an early access game, but seriously? Man, hear me out.Listen, last week, I had a chance to try out a powerful computer which's made up of i7 4770 and GTX 760, and 8 gigs of RAM. Because mine(i3-3220, GTX "The Swindle" 650) is clearly no match to it, I got very excited to test it. With... Two major CPU hummers! One is Kerbal Space Program and another is Space Engineers. But I'm not going to compare both of them. Just Space Engineers and its severe limit. Yeah, it has severe limit. Let's take a look.Space Engineers is notorious for using CPU resource a lot. No wonder why weaklings like i3 3220 is not enough. But since I now have full control of i7 4770, if I run SE(Abbreviation of Space Engineers) on there and spawn a capital ship that consists 36 000 blocks, could it maintain 60 FPS? My processor managed to make it visible on screen, but failed to make the game playable. (Average FPS was 5.)After installing and launching SE on that beast, test preparation was done. Time to hit it. The capital ship I used for testing is 'Rangatira Carrier'. If interested, find it in the steam workshop. Aight, let's do it!From the moment when I pressed spawning hotkey, the game freezed for about 20 sec. The result was shocking. 10 FPS. I'm not joking it was literally 1/0/F/P/S. At least it was consistent but.. My poor Ivy Bridge(i3 3220) also managed to have consistent 5 FPS. Don't misunderstand, I was keep talked about average FPS, not highest...I mean seriously, where was Haswell working to? She was working really hard. All cores were loaded to 90%. My i3 can - barely but - do that too! A pity. What a pity that a CPU that is three times powerful than another can't run a game on 30 FPS. Even 20, But 10! What a terribly, terribly terribly unoptimized game... :(Conclusion?Never build computer for SE. You'll need a - ahem, sorry, 'plenty of' - frickin' i7 6950! Cherry on the cake, 'it'll not enough' for rendering aforementioned capital ship at 60 FPS. I promise. Super-high-end CPU has no benefit for being super-high-end in SE. I know I pushed the game to the limit. However, can you accept the fact when you know the i3 does the 1/2 of what i7 does? I mean, i3 does 5 FPS while i7 does 10 FPS. At least I can't.Just... Imagine you're a man who passed doctors course in princeton university and yesterday just got employed where you wished to work there since you're in middle school but all they does are not helpful to company, chairman and directors are making worst decision everytime, and for the berries on a cake, they are forcing you to work so hard that you could die at any moment. Annnnnd the company was a cleaning company, which disguised as high-tech enterprise.Important: Still, buy Space Engineers to fund developers! They are consistently releasing updates every friday. So don't worry about developers. This is nothing like Towns. More crucially, this game has potential. We just need to wait until it leaves early access, and become fully playable! I suggest you to wait 2 years after purchase. I bought this since 2013 and was♥♥♥♥♥♥ determined to wait for 2 years, after two years I played SE and was still♥♥♥♥♥♥ See, this game has some consistency, It'll never betray you. Same pattern goes on, and on, and on...P.S. Don't ask me why important message is placed way down below.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15
Early Access Review
								Space Engineers has great potential, but it is let down by the out-of-touch developers who refuse to fix bugs and instead opt to keep cramming the game full of new features instead. This game is a lesson similar to what happened with Skyrim: Your game can be incredible, but it doesn't matter if I can't play it.That is exactly the case here. However unlike Bethesda who got Skyrim playable to an acceptable standard within months, I still see GAMEBREAKING bugs in this game that were around in 2014 still being present three years later. It is clear to me that Keen Software has no interest in fixing this broken game and I am concerned with their statements about the game "Never being finished." or perpetually "In a state of Early Access." SE is fun, until you get invested enough to past the sugary coating, only to find the filling of cake is actually feces instead of chocolate. I write this, having played the game for years now and just having to delete my longest ever save (Which I invested many, many hours into) due to gamebreaking bugs that Keen refuses to fix. Don't buy this. Instead, check out Empyrion: Galactic Survival. Sincerely, a thoroughly annoyed veteran player.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								Let me just say I love the idea of this game.I got this game right about when it came out, maybe a little after. Sure, there were bugs, but it was still fun to fly around on spaceships with your friends and try to survive the harsh realities of space. I can remember late nights spent with a group of friends sitting around a table, all of us gripping our mouses tightly and yelling commands at each other as our ship's engines started to fail, our masterpiece heading towards an increasingly large asteroid. We built epic bases, hunted down pirates, mined precious metals, pretty much did it all. I could really see the possibility for this game. But as the game developed, it got more and more buggy. Adding giant planets sure didn't help. The technology and developement was left in the dust of the ideas. The game became more and more demanding, to the point where it was impossible to play on our laptops, and became mostly unplayable due to bugs. If you want to buy this game, check back here in a year or six months, or until the game comes out of early access. In the mean time, try Emperion or another space based survival game. Space Engineers takes the cake for creativity, possibility, and gameplay, but it is simply not developed enough to be worth buying at this point in time. I sincerely hope the developers fix the bugs and reduce the demand of the game. Just don't waste your money on it now.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Full german review:http://www.topfree.de/space-engineersGrind materials, build a Space Ship and crash it into a meteor. The dream of every kid. Actually, the game is doing good in fulfilling this dream.The game runs on a modified version of the Havoc engine and offers a decent 3D space enviroment with realistic physics in zero gravity and vacuum.With a toolset of different forms of blocks, building parts and engines, you can design really nice looking ships and are also able to fly them.With focus on realism you wont find laser guns and warp drives, but the survival in a hostile environment with the constant need of energy ressources to maintain your vital systems.The game isnt really finished and playing the survival mode doesnt feel, like its worth the time.But the core of the game is amazing:Building: You are able to build complex structures, that can do different tasks in different situations, like battlestations, refinerys, mining rigs, scouts, transporters and space stations.Factions: You are able to team up with other players, and make alliances and war with other factions. Also systems can be protected, so they are only usable by you or your teammates.Technological Playground: To play with the game-engine you have a big toolbelt of tech: Sensors, wheels, pistons and rotors, remote controls, explosives and artificial gravity. From creating an elevator to building a big racing track or an automatic repair station, you can build, what you can immagine.Weekly updates give you a feeling of safety, you dont have in other early access games. Still on an early stage, the game is constantly evolving and hopefully will be a big thing in the next years.Because of the limits to the engine, the game world currently very small and empty.If you dont have a good PC or if you are not creative and just want a space experience, the game will disappoint you.But if it is your big thing to build and create, this game already has everything you ever wanted.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								So I got this from the humble survival bundle. This is the only reason I'm not demanding a refund. I've been playing through the training missions. In one, you need to "bridge power" across a section of asteroid. It's four sections wide, and it should be easy, right? Well, the third section won't place, no matter what I do. So I go up and over, and get past..but it's clunky and ugly. A different training mission, I'm supposed to assemble a conveyor belt. Add two sections to two pre-existing sections and weld it all to get it working...one section "snaps" in the air a fraction of an inch off from the existing conveyor. I have to re-start the training session because there is no way to remove that component. THIS is fixable by including a grinder in the chest! It's a no-brainer! A few "training" missions later, you're building your first ship...step one. Snap a "landing gear" to a pillar to start construction...guess what won't snap to any solid surface? So you can place it, in mid-air, and work while it's floating. Eventually it might land and snap...mine landed and snapped to the ceiling on the far end of the hangar. Building upside down without gravity isn't fun, but it's doable..but comon, guys. Also, the instructions on how to change from "large" components to "small" components is not explained... On the wall it says "start a new small ship". Trust me when I say, "Start new small ship" is written nowhere in the interface. And, on the next to last training session, I inadvertendly grab the fuel out of one of the ships. Guess what? That ship was built in such a way that you can't access the reactor...so I can't put the fuel back in. I can remove it from the ship interface...but I can't install it. What gives? I honestly don't know why I'm forcing myself through the training missions when they show me I should just uninstall the game and move on, but part of me wishes this game wasn't a steaming pile of wasted potential. Don't waste your money. Don't waste your time. If the training missions aren't playable...what the hell does it say about the rest of the game?

content:
Posted: April 15
Early Access Review
								Space Engineers has great potential, but it is let down by the out-of-touch developers who refuse to fix bugs and instead opt to keep cramming the game full of new features instead. This game is a lesson similar to what happened with Skyrim: Your game can be incredible, but it doesn't matter if I can't play it.That is exactly the case here. However unlike Bethesda who got Skyrim playable to an acceptable standard within months, I still see GAMEBREAKING bugs in this game that were around in 2014 still being present three years later. It is clear to me that Keen Software has no interest in fixing this broken game and I am concerned with their statements about the game "Never being finished." or perpetually "In a state of Early Access." SE is fun, until you get invested enough to past the sugary coating, only to find the filling of cake is actually feces instead of chocolate. I write this, having played the game for years now and just having to delete my longest ever save (Which I invested many, many hours into) due to gamebreaking bugs that Keen refuses to fix. Don't buy this. Instead, check out Empyrion: Galactic Survival. Sincerely, a thoroughly annoyed veteran player.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is a great building game and is a fun game to play overall. For lack of a better way of putting it, think minecraft in space except a heck of alot better. It uses technology we could conceivably have or hopefully will have in the near future. The game itself is great and will provide you with many hours of entertainment be it in survival mode or creative. Pros: -Design your own fighters/large ships and stations. -Full mod support-can host your own server-variety of mods and blueprints available in the workshop-many different play modes and worlds-wide variety of celestial bodies to explore ranging from asteroids to planets and moons-virtually unlimited space to explore-ships and stations only limited by your time and imagination. if you can think it you can build it-devs are usually very quick to acknowledge bug reports and to start getting fixes outCons: -combat not fully optimized yet and can be a bit laggy-game can be a bit unstable at times though typically not very long-hydrogen tanks take way too long to fill imo. (really more of a nit pick but one gripe i had with survival)-display information not as detailed on objects as I would like. for me there are a few more items I would like to see on the hud or displays for cockpits, such as a fuel gauge and a few other measurements. again kind of a nit pick but still something I wouldn't mind seeing.Overall this is a very great game. At the end of the day though I would advise people to keep in mind this game is still technically in Alpha and hasn't even made it to beta testing yet. As the game is refined, polished and made better, there are going to be changes. Issues that you see now and even ones that I posted in this may not be issues tomorrow. This game has some great potential considering that it's still in Alpha and they already have this much stuff done for it. The final product will be epic. If you're looking for a fun game that you can play with your friends, or team up to take on the enemy computer factions, then this game won't disappoint. The game will only get better as time goes.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game has a love-hate relationship with me. I shall name some pros and cons.Pros:* Graphics are nice, decent textures, nice models.* Music is cool (though doesn't change with the progress of the game, it's a playlist)* The concept is nice, it's not your average survival game.* Decent ammount of options to build your things (small ship blocks, large ship blocks and a whole loot of different  blocks  to make your ship do different things.Cons:* Buggy, (landing gear exploded, thrusters broke down for no reason, Died leaving ships. I could go in, in one piece, I have to come out in one piece right? Lose health or even die when seemingly tripping over nothing, pistons break for no reason)* Beginning of the game is very hard. ''Great there's no uranium on my starting asteroid...'' finally found uranium after 20 km's... Also running out of uranium in the beginning, better dump the world and start a new one... Killed by large pirate ships in the very beginning, also destroyed my refinery. Time for a new world...* Very few weapon options, A gatling gun and some rockets, that's about it. We can create the biggest nuclear most advanced stuff, but we cannot build a simple lasergun?* Game is unforgiving and hard to get the hang off. Play without tutorials? gl with that... I'm not bad at this game but it's hard enough to suppress the experience and fun.* Power generators are not balanced. Nuclear generators are OP, solar panels are the exact opposite, aka needing HUGE fields of panels to get stuff working.* Ships are weak... of course, it's not meant to be that you bump into something but i dont want to lose half my ship after doing that. one rocket on your cockpit and its bye bye character. It would be nice to introduce a shielding module.It's not a bad came but stuff is poorly executed. And it needs fixing and optimisation. I can run skyrim on ultra high with 2 k textures and very decent FPS. For this game, I have to set things the lowest settings, and low resolution to get that.Why the thumbs down? I had to choose. If you are willing to overlook the bugs and if you are feeling masochisitc, you can try this game. Don't buy it if you want immediate pay off.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								Space Engineers is a masterpiece of computer programming and design by KeenSWH that has a level of physics and space engineering that allows the player to create an almost infinate amount of complex engineering designs.Space Engineers has come a long way since I first bought the title and continues to be updated on a weekly basis with great new features and then fast bug fixes in the following few day's.If you like building and experimenting with all manner of space related project designing, fully fuctional space ships of all kinds, bases, stations and such you should love Space Engineers because the things you can build is endless.I have played for over 1.900 hours and in all that time I have never not been able to play Space Engineers due to a bug and I have enjoyed every minute.I have a five year old mid range computer with a duo core 2.4Khz , 8GB ram , and a G-Force GT610 1GB and I can build massive ships and worlds with no problems at all.Now with procedural asteroids and exploration mode you can litterally travell your whole life in the game and not get from one side to the other.It is not just empty space either as they're adding player subscribed ships and stations to the world of which so far we have had the first batch with more to follow.The game is also open to modding and these modders really add some fantastic things to the workshop and being all with ships.As I only play single player or with just a couple of friends I have not had much issues with this problem but if you want a pvp massive multiplayer experience then maybe you should wait until Keen optimize the game engine because as with all early access games the multiplayer always suffers simply because more players equalls more code, internet veriables and so on.I have absolutelly no doubt that this will improve in time and when optimized will be a really great multiplayer experience.All in all Space Engineers is a fantastic game with a fantastic development company content:

Early Access Review
								By far, one of my favorite physics sandbox games. The gameplay might not seem very deep, and a little over-complicated at first, but once you get the hang of it you'll be engaging in stupidity like the rest of us.Smashing your friends ships into reentry, loading yours with warheads and practically cutting an ai ship in half, or taking on a pirate station and trying to recreate the scene from star wars where the A-wing kamikazed into a star destroyer. Endless possibilities, and so much trolling potential. It's only a matter of time before they make survival mode playable, so you might be able to play it like a real video game too eventually, but for now it's hilarious destructive fun and well worth the price of admission.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game has a love-hate relationship with me. I shall name some pros and cons.Pros:* Graphics are nice, decent textures, nice models.* Music is cool (though doesn't change with the progress of the game, it's a playlist)* The concept is nice, it's not your average survival game.* Decent ammount of options to build your things (small ship blocks, large ship blocks and a whole loot of different  blocks  to make your ship do different things.Cons:* Buggy, (landing gear exploded, thrusters broke down for no reason, Died leaving ships. I could go in, in one piece, I have to come out in one piece right? Lose health or even die when seemingly tripping over nothing, pistons break for no reason)* Beginning of the game is very hard. ''Great there's no uranium on my starting asteroid...'' finally found uranium after 20 km's... Also running out of uranium in the beginning, better dump the world and start a new one... Killed by large pirate ships in the very beginning, also destroyed my refinery. Time for a new world...* Very few weapon options, A gatling gun and some rockets, that's about it. We can create the biggest nuclear most advanced stuff, but we cannot build a simple lasergun?* Game is unforgiving and hard to get the hang off. Play without tutorials? gl with that... I'm not bad at this game but it's hard enough to suppress the experience and fun.* Power generators are not balanced. Nuclear generators are OP, solar panels are the exact opposite, aka needing HUGE fields of panels to get stuff working.* Ships are weak... of course, it's not meant to be that you bump into something but i dont want to lose half my ship after doing that. one rocket on your cockpit and its bye bye character. It would be nice to introduce a shielding module.It's not a bad came but stuff is poorly executed. And it needs fixing and optimisation. I can run skyrim on ultra high with 2 k textures and very decent FPS. For this game, I have to set things the lowest settings, and low resolution to get that.Why the thumbs down? I had to choose. If you are willing to overlook the bugs and if you are feeling masochisitc, you can try this game. Don't buy it if you want immediate pay off.

content:

Early Access Review
								The game is a fun little thing. There is much to do and see- especially with yesterday's addition of planets. There are also A.I. enemies that will attack your base. There are multiple types of ships you can build- such as an atmospheric plane, a star fighter, station, probe, drill, star ship, rover, etc. Multiplayer is very well rounded and the game is mostly well optimized. However, glitches, clunky movement, and a steep learning curve keep this one from full marks. I recommend for Sci-Fi fans, KSP fans, and those who want to built their own X-wing and put it in their own U.S.S Enterprise.

content:

Early Access Review
								Maybe this game just wasn't for me, but I found it honestly a bit dull, not very user friendly, and multiplayer seemed lacking, probably because of the smallish community. I could see myself growing to like this game, maybe after some more investment and getting to know some folks on the servers, but from what i've been reading on these other reviews, the game seems to be stuck in a development cycle where they don't fix bugs and they don't seem to be working towards a release. I question buying the game now, will it be completed? Will the true experience the game should have ever be realized? Or have the developers grown content with the money they are earning and pushing out a new update once a week with flaws and some small changes.I'm skeptical, though I bought this game for a reason: I saw potential. I still do. I'm not saying that others shouldn't get this game, I'm saying you should realize what you're investing in before you play and know it's risky.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								WARNING, THIS GAME IS COMPLICATED.     What you have here is a mighty fine space sim here.  Although what you may see at first may be like, Wtf, this is Minecraft, but it is not.  Go jump right in survival mode and try to figure things out, or you could go on Youtube and watch a Let's Play. Either is fine. The gameplay is a little slow at first, but then it goes to be one of the most immersive games you will ever play. The survival constantly gives you things to do and gives you more objectives to do solo or with your friends.  For an example you need to go build a mining ship to get uranium ore for your reactor.  Or then, you need to collect resources to build a refinery so you can convert the uranium or into ingots.     Although if you dont like slower-paced build-it games then go back to CoD.  Like I said, the gameplay is slow at first but you wont even care when you have so many things and oppertunites to take and do.I highly reccomend this game, but only to some people, because not one game can please everyone.

content:
Posted: January 24
Early Access Review
The GoodOne of the greatest games I've ever played. It's very much like Minecraft, in that it's a survival game where you build things out of materials you gather. You go mining for materials, and can place block like objects in the world to create massive structures.However, the game obviously has much better graphics and gameplay. It also has an awesome system for building vehicles and ships. The physics are (for the most part) absolutely amazing. Space travel feels real, and you get fully immersed as if you really are exploring the vastness of space.Space Engineers allows for tons of creativity and exploration. Also, the modding community is quite awesome, so there's a lot of things to try out. It's also very easy to submit creations you make into the Workshop.The BadThe game JUST went into beta, so obviously there's still going to be a lot of bugs.Multiplayer is practicaly unplayable right now, due to severe lag. It's not due to the servers, it's all the servers, no matter what, due to the fact of how the game is programmed. Realistically, this game is SOOO complicated and expansive that I can't imagine how multiplayer could ever work (just because of system load), but who knows, they might work it out (it is still in beta!).Also, another terrible bug is that ships will randomly fly into the air for no reason, and there's no way to stop it. Basically, that ship is now lost. INCREDIBLY annoying if it happens on a server, especially if it's your landing craft when you start, and even worse if it happens twice in a row (as just happened to me).Even though I'm incredibly salty right now, I still highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								I made the mistake of going to youtube and seeing people play this game... it seemed easy... simple to play and it looked like a lot of fun...  So I purchased it in Steam, installed it and got some mods...  I liked the fact that you could play it offline, since I travel extensively, I use my laptop to work and play while traveling...It is a disaster... The learning curve is painful, I realized that I WAS MISSING SOME CRITICAL KEYS... becuase laptops dont usually have numeric keypads...  I looked at the keys that could be assigned to compensate, just to realize that almost all the keyboard is assigned to some function or another...  Like in the era of text only games...  and keyboard only games...  So it became more and more painful...When traveling abroad, the charges for internet services are very high... and this little game proceeded to download the mods every time I started a new world...  I think the game could have been an incredible success, if the developer team had gotten out to the world of people, and realized that there are starndard controls, like when you right click, a menu appears so you can select options...  And that you can click on controls to get something to rotate or move....  :(Maybe next time guys...  I never even tried the community game...  I consider myself an adept to using systems, but a game is for enjoyment, not for pain, frustration and steep learning curves...my advise is: DO NOT BUY THIS GAME, if you have a laptop and like to play on it... if you travel abroad, if you like simple, logical, business standard mouse clicking practices...  DO NOT BUY IT...What a disappointment... is like if LEGO had decided to have not only circular pegs, but also squares, triangles and you could only match the blocks if the pegs matched the holes...  :(

content:
Posted: February 12
Early Access Review
								Well, I purchased this (in beta) expecting a playable item. It is...to a degree.   I started a 'Lone Survivor' custom game - which is set in space. After a few hours, I decided to build a mining ship.  I saw a handy utube video and thought I'd give it a try. Oh dear! The starting point is impossible. Landing gear ALWAYS snaps upside down so that is impossible as a starting point. I tried just placing blocks then manoeuvring the ship up then add the landing gear later.  Oh dear! The starting block I placed ALWAYS sits off any platform and even with a gravity generator pumping out 1g if you move into the placed blocks they float away. Now, I have to say this is only when trying to use small-sized blocks but, unless you want to build a ship that only has large blocks...you are screwed.  So, unless this game improves into a 'gamma' build, or a workable stable offering, you may be advised to wait...or try some other, similar title.I would guess that if one started on a planet then these multiple build problems may disappear but that handicaps the entire experience. Sometimes the sound disappears so silence is all one has.It would be great to also have the option to relocate items without having to rebuild.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have played this game for more than 200 hours and I expect to play it a great deal more.  This game started out as an iteresting "build stuff in 3D space with physics" thing, and building on that solid foundation has become so, so much more.The game now has fully alterable planets at 1/4 actual earth size with no load times between space and the surface. You could watch an object (or yourself) fall in real time from orbit if you wanted. Or fly a ship or lander into space from the ground.The recent graphical update is stunning, and you'll find yourself pausing every now and then just to say "wow, look at the light reflecting off the hull of my ship, that's beautiful."You can:-Mine asteroids with your hand drill, small custom build mining ships, or gigantic dreadnaught that swallow asteroids whole (all built by you).-Travel through the infinite expance of space to prospect rich ores, dangerous drone protected fortresses, and abandond stations waiting to be salvaged (many are contributions from the steam workshop).-Build huge stations and ships (designing the layout and functions piece by piece) in survival, or full creative modes.-Play with friend to work together / engage in full fps and ship-based warfare, or go it alone and pit yourself against the emptyness of space. Hope you brought your oxygen tank.This game is worth so much more than what they are asking, and will only increase in value. A truely rare gem of a game. I absolutely recomend it. (PS: does require a pretty good computer to run at high fps (on planets), but the developers are continuously increasing the performance and optimization)

Early Access Review
								Okonomiyaki (お好み焼き) literally means “grilled as you like it” in Japanese. As the name implies, what goes into it and how it’s prepared depends largely on your preferences. That’s why it’s sometimes known as a “Japanese pizza” in the US.In most versions okonomiyaki is made with shredded cabbage and a pancake-like batter, but that’s where the similarities end. Some people like a soft custardy interior, while others prefer a ton of fillings with the batter merely binding the ingredients together. Since there are no hard and fast rules for the filling and toppings, it’s a great way to use up scraps from the fridge.That said, there are a two general styles of okonomiyaki: Hiroshima-style and Kansai-style. Hiroshima-style okonomiyaki is layered like a giant omelette and often includes yakisoba on the inside, with a fried egg on top. Kansai-style okonomiyaki on the other hand is mixed together before being cooked like a pancake.NagaimoNagaimo, which literally means “long potato” is a key ingredient in Kansai style okonomiyaki. It’s a species of yam consumed all over Asia. In Japan, it’s often eaten raw in salads and grated into sauces, but it has a thick mucus-like texture that tends to put people off who weren’t raised eating it. When cooked though, the sliminess dissipates and it provides a wonderful moist, creamy quality to batters like this one. One thing to remember though is that if you have sensitive hands, be sure to wear food-safe gloves when handling nagaimo as it can make your hands itchy.Another key point to getting a soft custardy Kansai-style okonomiyaki is to limit the development of gluten in the batter. That’s why it’s important to minimize mixing once you’ve added liquids to the flour. I’ve found that mixing the flour in with the cabbage first, and then adding the liquids, keeps the mixing to a minimum while evenly incorporating all the ingredients.Okonomiyaki ToppingsOnce cooked, the pancake is slathered with okonomiyaki sauce, though chuno or tonkatsu sauce are both similar and work perfectly fine). Typical toppings include Japanese mayonnaise, aonori (green nori flakes), katsuoubushi, and benishouga (red pickled ginger), but similar to the filling, what you put on top is largely up to your own preferences. Chili sauce, cheese, and even curry are fair game, making it a lot of fun to pair condiments with what’s inside each pancake.I’ve outlined the process and ingredients for a very basic okonomiyaki below, but like pizzas, it can be filled and topped with anything you like. Here are some ideas to show you how versatile okonomiyaki can be.Mentai Cheese OkonomiyakiMake the basic okonomiyaki below (minus the bacon), but add mentaiko and cheddar cheese to the mixture. The mentaiko adds spicy bits of salty pollack roe in every bite, while the cheddar melts, to form pools of cheese on the inside and crisps on the outside. Topped with chopped tomatoes and mayonnaise it presents beautifully and adds a fruity sweetness that goes well with the cheese.Smoked Salmon Thyme OkonomiyakiMake the basic okonomiyaki below (minus the bacon), but add smoked salmon and thyme and top with hollandaise sauce and aonori. With salty, smoky bits of smoked salmon in every bite and a tart creamy hollandaise sauce, this tastes more European than Japanese, but that doesn’t make it any less delicious.Prep Time 5 minutesCook Time 14 minutesIngredients400 grams cabbage (~half a small head)60 grams scallions (~2 scallions), thinly sliced10 grams katsuobushi140 grams flour - all-purpose (~1 cup)280 grams nagaimo peeled and grated2 large eggs1/2 cup dashi or cold water9 slices baconokonomiyaki saucemayonnaiseaonorikatsuobushibenishoga

content:
Posted: November 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've been playing space engineers for some time and it was  a fun sandbox for anyone with even a Mid range video card. For months I've been seeing the hype for planets along with all the updates to support them. I waited and waited for the update to be released and finally it does!!! YEAH! Fun Day!Only one small problem, though the requirements says DirectX 9.0c planets requires DirectX 11 and my trusty old Nvidia 9800GT which I've been playing the game on for a very long time suddenly isn't enough...If you want to be able to enjoy all the features of Space Engineers, your going to have to look toward the High end of the system requirements now because the developer is aparantly abandoning  full support of the previously stated system requirements. I recommend the game, just be aware that if your not running a tio end system, your not going to get everything!

content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Great game concept. I love the feel of the game. Its very atmospheric and has great depth. But I have had many issues with the game that really spike some problems. 	1. There are way to many bugs, that should have been fixed a while ago.		I. Like how when your ship is moving when you try to move you instantly die.		II. Home screen lags because of a background video change		III. Even when on lowest render quality, game still runs on 3.1GB of RAM 	2. My computer isn’t id say the “Best” or “Crazy $” but still should be able to play it even on normal quality, “which it cant even run it on lowest,” so I believe that its very difficult for some people to play it, or at all if they don’t have a $3,000 computer. 	3. Game crashes A LOT! 		I. I haven’t played 5 minutes worth of the game without a crash are a stall for more than 10 minutes… I even had to manually shut the game down in task manager because the sound was continuous even as the game was shut down. 	All in all though I still like the game, it is frustrating that its buggy and a pain in the butt. But I believe that sometime they could fix all those issues and make it a step faster and work on it. And indeed if that happens I will be back on in a flash. Great game.. But just needs a little / or a lot o TLC.

It’s a species of yam consumed all over Asia. In Japan, it’s often eaten raw in salads and grated into sauces, but it has a thick mucus-like texture that tends to put people off who weren’t raised eating it. When cooked though, the sliminess dissipates and it provides a wonderful moist, creamy quality to batters like this one. content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								Do i like this game? HELL YESDo i recommend it? No, just no, not right now details belowPros:80 % of friends made from SEMade your childhood design spaceship REAL!You can be anything, no limit, no rulesYou can build anything(if you have the imagination)Cons:The game is buggy like hell(fun sometimes)Stable is unplayable in both single player and multiplayerMultiplayer is practically impossibleCrash every 5 minRubberbanding is strong with this oneDesync happen every now and then between client and serverClang GOD hate you when you play with rotors, piston, and wheelsDont get me wrong on this review, I love this game, i really really do, but seeing how it develop in these past few years, the game gone from bad, to worse. why you ask? The game is now being split into two variant that is develop and stable. while the develop keep getting weekly update, patch and hotfix, stable on the other hand receive all of that once a month. Recent update 01.144 (http://forums.keenswh.com/threads/update-01-144-stable-update-01-149-dev-bug-fixes-and-improvements.7386481/) have made the game pratically impossible to play both single player and multi player. The develop however is more playable in singleplayer but not multiplayer.Conclusion:If you can withstand the bug and clang destroyed your precious 20 hours of hardwork, i recommend you to get this gameif not, well.. stay away until full release(Will update the review once the game is much better)(29.08.2016)

content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have an amazing time playing Space Engineers, but at the same time I get very frustrated with how ineffecient the game works. I feel like I am at a point where my ambitions and ideas have exceeded what the game can handle. I.e - Projector rooms, Refining rooms, etc. When I have elaborate bases, the game can't handle how much wiring is in my base. I would reccomend the game for sure, but I reccomend the developement team work on effeciency first, rather than adding more things to the game. It's severely innefecient, and I am running an amazing Rig. So, I know it's not me.

Early Access Review
								I bought this game as I thought it would fullfill my need for an open world space exploration survival game. I must say I enjoyed the creative mode, which basically gives you an infinite amount of space-Legos to build whatever crazy you want. I experienced no lag with even huge ships, and had fun for a couple of days with that.Other than that, the survival mode sucks major♥♥♥♥♥♥at the moment -> drilling for materials will most likely clip you through whatever you're trying to drill, resulting in an inevitable suicide. Also, -- !! WARNING !! -- if you are expecting Kerbal Space-like physics realism, this game will not be for you. As a sandbox, it is fun, but for survivalists - DO NOT BOTHER, this is just another broken survival early access which will not work, just in a different environment than usual

content:
Posted: February 20
Early Access Review
								A long time ago I purchased Space Engineers, I was a young man back then, filled with joy and excitement for this brand new game that I yearned to play. I gleefully downloaded the game, waiting patiently, knowing all my waiting will soon be rewarded with glorious gameplay. The download finished and in a tizzy, I started the game. The main menu booted up and I was astounded by the wonderous UI. I click join on my friend's game as he waited patiently so that good times could ensue. I join my friend's server and selected where I wanted to spawn. I left click respawn and after a little bit of lag, the game starts but one second after I have a glimpse of joy, I face a frozen screen and no audio, my game has crashed and I've got no escape. I'm an old man now, and have been waiting for years, filled with hope that one day my game will unfreeze. But until then, go ♥♥♥♥ yourself Keen Software House.EDIT:It's been almost two weeks since I've written this review, and nothing has changed, I've been glued to my computer, just waiting for the moment the game unfreezes. I know it will be a glorious day and my celebration is planned. The cake is starting to get moldy and my days are coming to an end. Please Keen Software House, save me from this endless hell and fix your ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game.

Early Access Review
								While it may be early access, this is a fantastic game if you love building stuff and anything space related. The developers are great too. They don't update once in a blue moon, making you think the game's dead between updates, but actually every thursday (sometimes friday if its late but shush). They listen to the community and fix any issue and add in new features that the masses want, without affecting their vision for the game. Recently planets were added. Giant, fully destroyable planets that exist in the same world as the rest of the game, theres no load time or anything as you plummet through the atmosphere because you put the wrong thrusters on your landing ship. Its not all creation focused too, theres enemy pirates and sabiroids to deal with too. Feel free to wait for a sale, but this game is worth your money, even in this early state.TLDR: Buy it now.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								I want to love this game. I really, really do. But it runs like complete and utter garbage. If you think "Oh, it's been in early access for a couple years, it must be relatively stable by now" you'd be absolutely dead wrong. If anything, it seems to run even worse than it did when I played it on a free weekend a year or so ago.I've sat here with a stop watch, and loading a new mod-less world on the "Easy Start Moon" takes 28 minutes. And when it does finally load, you have a roughly 25% chance that it will just crash. And if it doesn't crash, you'll run into too many bugs to keep track of. Here's a few I ran into just in the last few hours alone:1) Spawned into moon world, entire screen was white with black square artifacts floating around. Had to restart game. There goes another 20-30 minutes.2) Spawned into world and couldn't move at all. Had to reload world, another 20-30 minutes gone.3) Loaded a workshop ship (that used no mods) from blueprint, and 90% of the blocks in it had no collision model (you could fly right through them).4) Loaded a different ship from blueprint (which again used *no* mods), only 10~% of it loaded, and when I flew near it, I randomly died (in Creative mode, where you shouldn't be able to die at all).Oh, and the game constantly freezes for 2-5 seconds at a time, every 30 seconds or so, and does so even longer (30+ seconds) if you attempt to do almost anything (spawn a block, open a menu, etc.).This is absolutely unacceptable, especially considering how long this game has been out.System specs before someone claims I'm running this on a potato:i7 3770 with cores unparked8GB DDR3MSI 9707200rpm HDDNo viruses, all drivers up to date, all other non-essential programs closed down, drives regularly defragmented. I run other "demanding" PC games like ArmA 3 and Planetside 2 at max settings with no issues in either general performance, or load times specificially.Easily 2/3rds of my total playtime is in a loading screen. The other 1/3rd is fighting bugs. I don't think I've actually played this game yet, over hours of play time. Something is very, very wrong with this game. Don't trust Youtube videos that make this game look playable; it isn't, and you should avoid it like the plague.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Planets?  Well, the planets are really bugged, in my opinion.  You can't build a vehicle and drive it without it flying or bouncing up into the air.  Atmosphere ships tend to crash more than anything.  There is no air resistance designed in, so traditional winged craft is out of the question.  You either have thrust, powerful enough to raise the mass of your ship, or you nose dive into the surface.  EDIT: Removed speed comment, as I was in the wrong.  - Thanks for replies.They have added so much, but everything comes with bugs, they don't test much and they tend to ruin things that previously worked ok.There are a lot of fan boys who when you ask a question on the game forums or demand answers in exchange for having spent your money on their product tend to just spout hatered at you for daring to question their Lord Keen.It is my belief that planets in this game were the first test of Medievil Engineers, was a flop, so they started over and rather than abandon their work, put it into this game instead.  It is my belief that they hope to skim off a few more sales of this before they completely abandon it.Patches seem to come once per week, but usually are pretty small with not a lot of anything fixed.  They typically are some very small patch that sometimes has to do with nothing else but to be a distraction.Because of the way they release patches and the way they do things now, it is rare that you can continue with a map into a new large patch.  You usually have to restart a map from scratch.  If you like survival, like me, that really isn't anything to get too excited about.  It is very difficult to get going from nothing.  The bugs then make is very frustrating to do a lot of things.  A lot of people like creative mode, but that is just building things at random until you get bored of putting blocks together.  Not worth it if that is what you want to do at all, in my opinion.They opened the code to a source code so anyone can manipulate it.  My guess is that is so that people can fix the bugs and add it as a mod, which is what has been happening.  - Isn't this what the company is supposed to do?  Maybe those people who create mods to fix the bugs should be getting paid for making the game playable.I'll get flamed for this review, but I don't care.  I bought this game for myself and a friend of mine a few years ago, and it was once great to play.  Now, though, it is littered with bugs and seems to only be getting worse with anything they add.

Early Access Review
								I bought this game when it was in a very young alpha state.  And I hated it.  My first instinct was to get my money back, I hated it that much.  And I don't return games.  It was buggy and frankly just boring as♥♥♥♥♥♥  But I waited.  I kept tabs on it while I played other games and (this might be a shock to some) lived a life outside of Steam.  Today I decided to give it another go after seeing it was now in Beta and read some fairly encouraging reviews.  I have to say, this is a very fun game now.  I'm only two hours in as of this writing, but I can see myself pouring a lot of time into it while my 3D prints chug away on the desk next to me.  As a space advocate and a lover of all things sci-fi, I give this game two thumbs up and look forward to spending hours I'll never get back in a world that doesn't exist.  As every good game should encourage us to do.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Here we are. I've played this game a lot and finally decided to write my review.Let me start with good things. PROS:- I love the idea. Really I do love it. - Modding community.  Hundreds of mods, thatever you like you will probably find already implemented in workshop.- Since I am a patriotic guy, for me Pro is also this game is being developed in my country - Singleplayer is acceptable in terms of stability, despite of some graphical glitches. And some bugs. But you can save-load. HMm.CONS:- Enemy AI, NPC enemies. They are just dull. Disable them, as they are just screwing up the immersion- Multiplayer  If I say that stability in singleplayer is quite acceptable, multiplayer is everything but that. It's not only unstable, it's  constantly non-functional. Client-Server is most of the time out-of-sync: ignorant handling of inventory content, invisible ships, Object displayed somewhere else they actually are.  Exploding basic objects, out of the blue, e.g pistons.  This piston bug is there for a year. Hey, got it? ... Twelve. F**king.  Months!!! For all holy snakes!!- Multiplayer sucks- MULTIPLAYER- did I mention multiplayer already? There used to be so big potential in this game. It could have been a gem in space survivals genre. But it is not.KEEN had awesome idea, made a lot of money from  EA purchases, but they are failing to implement the idea. Maybe some day, but not at present.EDIT: currently Keens are trying to do something with their reputation and fix multiplayer. That is good. There is still so much of potential in this game.Also, I've removed/reworded most thrashing parts at the end of the review.12/2016EDIT2: massive update is just being downloaded for space engineers. Its description promises new netcode, and Marek Rosa's blog is announcing focus on great MP experience.I wish it was what it says. If so, I wouldn't hesitate to rewrite my review and to give thumbs up, if it's worth it!03/2017EDIT3: Well. Here we are. Couple of months passed  since my last comment. This game is still buggy. It still implements lots of featured glitches for you. But! There is light at the end of the tunnel! We tried to play MP with guys. It's almost playable! Maybe someone paid an attention and listened out our loud cry.SE Devs. Please. You are almost there. You made some progress, congrats! You have still issue with pistons, flying away grids, etc. However it seems bugs manifest in lower frequency, and sometimes there are workarounds. So, keep going. I will be more than happy to change verdict. Really.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a review from some one with over 3,091+ hours in game (as of May 27,2016).Things you need to know,- This game is still under development, (aka it has bugs)- This game is updated every Thursday and any new bugs usually get hot patched Friday- Bugs from time to time will make the game unplayable (for a day or two at most)- Multiplayer is available  it has its fair share of problems, most of which are being fixed with each new patch. But patches do break it from time to time so be aware of that when getting in to multiplayer. But for the most part multiplayer is coming nicely, and I only really have issues when playing with  20+ people. But new netcode is in the works, so hopefully this will only be a temporary issue.If you have played Minecraft, you will enjoy Space Engineers. This game has come a long way in the last 2 years. If you want to see how far this game is come, just go to YouTube and watch the weekly update videos, and you can watch this game transform before your eyes. In Space Engineers, you can do pretty much anything. The only limiting factor is what you, yourself can come up with. You start out form humble beginnings, with noting more than a respawn ship, and have to gather resources, to build new ships and stations, and to keep your medical bay operation, so you can stay alive. You will run in to pirates, military ship, and if you engage in multiplayer other players.Me personally I've been pretty involved in the PvP aspect of the game. Its fun (and good practice) to take out Pirates and NPC cargo and Military vessels. In recent patches Pirates and NPC ships are a lot riskier to attack so its really a challenge to face an enemy now that can no call for help. And when help arrives it will attempt to mercilessly hunt you down with total disregard for its own safety. Plan you attacks carefully or you will be overwhelmed and destroyed. But the real challenge (at least for me) is the human player. Hunting them down, finding their bases and ships and attempting to wipe them out before they wipe you out. PvP in this game can at times drive you mad, as I said above multiplayer is still a tad bit unstable, and every new patch makes multiplayer a bumpy road, but the Devs are working on new Netcode and are slowly, seeing improvements to multiplayer stability. Recently things have been improving at a steady pace, we gotten several huge improvements to multiplayer (saving ship tool bars, server side character and ship tracking, etc.,,) but we are still waiting on netcode, but it will come.If you give this game a chance and are willing to stick with it, even when it drives you mad at times, you will get hours of enjoyment from this game (did I mention I have 3,091+ hours?).
